TB is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The definition includes pulmonary and extrapulmonary TB, which are bacteriologically confirmed or clinically diagnosed. In GBD, TB is an aggregate of drug-susceptible and drug-resistant TB among HIV-negative people.
Globally in 2019, as in 1990, tuberculosis (TB) was the leading Level 3 cause of death by a single pathogen. Among HIV-negative individuals, the number of TB deaths was 1·18 million (95% UI 1·08–1·29) and the number of incident cases of TB was 8·50 million (7·45–9·73).

maternal-abortion-and-miscarriage-matern.Definition:
Abortion is defined as elective or medically indicated termination of pregnancy at any gestational age. Miscarriage is defined as spontaneous loss of pregnancy before 24 weeks of gestation with complications requiring medical care.
Maternal abortion and miscarriage caused 19 600 deaths (95% UI 16 300–23 400) among females ages 10 to 54, a 67·1% (60·8–73·1) decrease since 1990. There were 42·4 million (32·5–53·8) abortions and miscarriages with complications globally in 2019.

liver-cancer-due-to-nash-liverCancer.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the liver (specifically due to NASH), including ICD-10 codes such as C22.0.
There were 36 300 incident cases (95% UI 29 500–44 900), 34 700 deaths (28 400–43 200), and 796 000 DALYs (657 000–976 000) from liver cancer due to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) globally in 2019.

chronic-kidney-disease-due-to-diabetes-m.Indicator: Chronic kidney disease due to diabetes mellitus type 1
chronic-kidney-disease-due-to-diabetes-m.Definition:
This causes incorporates death and disability due to chronic kidney disease caused by diabetes type 1.
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetes type 1 was responsible for 3·22 million (95% UI 2·28–4·37) DALYs and 7·8% (5·4–10·5) of total overall CKD DALYs.

chronic-kidney-disease-due-to-diabetes-m.Indicator: Chronic kidney disease due to diabetes mellitus type 2
chronic-kidney-disease-due-to-diabetes-m.Definition:
This causes incorporates death and disability due to chronic kidney disease caused by diabetes type 2.
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetes type 2 was responsible for 9·87 million (95% UI 8·11–11·7) DALYs and 23·8% (19·8–27·7) of total overall CKD DALYs.

refraction-disorders-blindnessAndVisionL.Definition:
Refraction disorders refers to blurry vision due to the lens’s inability to focus and can be addressed through the use of corrective lenses or refractive surgery.
Refraction disorders resulted in 6·57 million (95% UI 4·43–9·29) global YLDs in 2019 and was responsible for 0·8% (0·6–0·9) of total global YLDs. Refraction disorders was the second-ranked cause of global YLDs due to blindness and vision loss modelled in GBD 2019.

near-vision-loss-blindnessAndVisionLoss.Definition:
Near vision loss is the progressive inability to focus on near objects with ageing (also termed presbyopia). Near vision loss due to uncorrected presbyopia was defined as presenting near vision worse than N6 or N8 at 40 cm when best-corrected distance visual acuity was better than 6/12.
Near vision loss resulted in 4·90 million (95% UI 2·26–9·67) global YLDs in 2019 and was responsible for 0·6% (0·3–1·0) of total global YLDs. Near vision loss was the third-ranked cause of global YLDs due to blindness and vision loss modelled in GBD 2019.

cystic-echinococcosis-neglectedTropicalD.Definition:
Cystic echinococcosis is a parasitic disease caused by infection with the Echinococcus granulosis tapeworm. Our estimates represent cases diagnosed in hospitals as well as in community surveys resulting in abdominal, pulmonary, or cerebral localisations.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) was responsible for 1350 deaths (95% UI 987–1760) and 122 000 DALYs (89 200–169 000) in 2019. In central Asia, CE was the neglected tropical disease with the greatest burden, with 30 100 DALYs (15 300–54 400) in 2019.

lymphatic-filariasis-neglectedTropicalDi.Definition:
LF is a disease in which threadlike nematodes invade the lymphatic system. The most prominent clinical manifestations are lymphoedema (a swelling of the extremities, also known in its more extreme manifestation as elephantiasis) and hydrocele (a collection of fluid in the sac around the testicles).
The global burden of lymphatic filariasis (LF) in 2019 was 1·63 million (95% UI 0·959–2·71) DALYs.

onchocerciasis-neglectedTropicalDiseases.Definition:
Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, is a parasitic disease caused by Onchocerca volvulus. Diagnosis can be made by skin snip biopsy to identify larvae, surgical removal of nodules and exam for adult worms, slit lamp exam of anterior part of the eye where larvae or lesions caused by them are visible, and antibody tests.
The global burden of onchocerciasis in 2019 was 1·23 million (95% UI 0·765–1·82) DALYs.

trachoma-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAndMal.Definition:
Trachoma is a condition in which repeated infection with Chlamydia trachomatis results in inversion of the eyelashes, causing damage to the cornea. Trachoma burden is quantified in terms of vision loss and blindness.
The global burden of trachoma in 2019 was 181 000 DALYs (95% UI 114 000–274 000), the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide.

chronic-respiratory-diseases-nonCommunic.Definition:
Chronic respiratory diseases is an aggregate category that includes COPD, asthma, pneumoconioses, interstitial lung disease and pulmonary sarcoidosis, and other chronic respiratory diseases.
Chronic respiratory diseases was responsible for 71·1 million (95% UI 64·7–77·0) YLLs and 32·4 million (26·1–38·5) YLDs in 2019. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma were the two largest contributors to global respiratory disease burden.

cutaneous-and-mucocutaneous-leishmaniasi.Definition:
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, transmitted through the bite of phlebotomine sandflies. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterised by lesions that can cause permanent scarring. 
Cutaneous leishmaniasis was responsible for 293 000 DALYs (95% UI 188 000–437 000) globally in 2019.

african-trypanosomiasis-neglectedTropica.Definition:
HAT, also known as sleeping sickness, is a vector-borne disease caused by two subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei, T.b. gambiense and T.b. rhodesiense. HAT progresses from skin manifestations that include severe itching to severe neurological symptoms.
The global burden of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in 2019 was 82 600 DALYs (95% UI 37 600–156 000) and 1360 deaths (95% UI 609–2580), a 98% decrease in deaths since 1990, reflecting efforts to eliminate transmission and improve case detection.

schistosomiasis-neglectedTropicalDisease.Definition:
Schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia or “snail fever,” is a helminth disease caused by infection with five species of the parasite Schistosoma: S. mansoni, S. japonicum, S. haematobium, S. mekongi, and S. intercalatum.
Schistosomiasis was responsible for 11 500 deaths (95% UI 10 100–13 300) and 1·64 million (1·04–2·64) DALYs in 2019, the majority of which occurred in sub-Saharan Africa.

cysticercosis-neglectedTropicalDiseasesA.Definition:
Cysticercosis is a parasitic disease caused by Taenia solium. ICD-10 codes for cysticercosis are B69–B69.9. We model prevalence of neurocysticercosis with epilepsy.
The global burden of cysticercosis in 2019 was 1·37 million (95% UI 0·874–1·96) DALYs. In Latin America and the Caribbean, cysticercosis was the neglected tropical disease with the highest burden, with 287 000 DALYs (182 000–406 000).

dengue-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAndMalar.Definition:
The estimates for dengue disease represent cases of clinically apparent illness (dengue fever, dengue haemorrhagic fever, dengue shock syndrome, and resulting chronic fatigue syndrome) and death. These estimates do not represent asymptomatic dengue virus infection.
Dengue was responsible for 36 100 deaths (95% UI 9180–44 500) and 2·38 million (0·828–3·27) DALYs in 2019. In southeast Asia in 2019, dengue had the highest DALY burden among all neglected tropical diseases and malaria.

yellow-fever-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAn.Definition:
Yellow fever is an arbovirus that causes febrile illness that in some cases progress to severe jaundice, haemorrhage, and death. Yellow fever is a notifiable disease endemic in areas of South America and Africa.
The global burden of yellow fever in 2019 was 290 000 DALYs (95% UI 107 000–598 000) and 4280 deaths (1590–8840).

oral-disorders-otherNonCommunicableDisea.Definition:
Oral disorders comprises caries of deciduous and permanent teeth, chronic periodontal diseases, edentulism (total tooth loss), and other oral disorders (a heterogeneous group including a variety of tooth, tongue, and jaw disorders and malformations not included in the other causes).
Oral disorders was the tenth-ranked Level 3 cause of disability globally in 2019, causing 23·1 million (95% UI 13·6–37·4) YLDs. It was also ranked first and third globally for prevalence (3·48 billion [3·20–3·78] cases) and incidence (4·35 billion [3·89–4·84] cases) in 2019.

caries-of-deciduous-teeth-oralDisorders.Definition:
Caries of deciduous teeth is defined as primary dentition showing unmistakable cavity, undermined enamel, a detectably softened floor or wall, a tooth with a temporary filling or a tooth that is filled but also decayed is present, or teeth extracted due to caries.
Caries of deciduous teeth caused 200 000 YLDs (95% UI 86 900–426 000) globally in 2019 among children and adolescents under 20 years old. There were 520 million (415–634) prevalent cases and 1·15 billion (0·788–1·52) incident cases in 2019.

caries-of-permanent-teeth-oralDisorders.Definition:
Caries of permanent teeth is defined as permanent dentition showing unmistakable cavity, undermined enamel, a detectably softened floor or wall, a tooth with a temporary filling or a tooth that is filled but also decayed is present.
Caries of permanent teeth caused 2·00 million (95% UI 0·915–3·88) YLDs globally in 2019. It was also ranked first and third globally for prevalence and incidence among all Level 4 causes, with 2·03 billion (1·77–2·33) prevalent and 3·09 billion (2·76–3·39) incident cases in 2019.

lower-respiratory-infections-respiratory.Definition:
This aggregate cause incorporates death and disability resulting from LRI, including clinician-diagnosed and self-reported cases of pneumonia, bronchiolitis, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and influenza-like illness.
In 2019, 489 million (95% UI 458–523) incident cases and 11·0 million (10·3–11·6) prevalent cases of lower respiratory infections (LRI) contributed to 2·49 million (2·27–2·74) deaths and 97·2 million (84·9–113) DALYs. The largest number of deaths occurred in the 70 and older age group (1·23 million [1·06–1·32] deaths).

upper-respiratory-infections-respiratory.Definition:
Upper respiratory infections include cough, acute nasopharyngitis, sinusitis, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, laryngitis, tracheitis, epiglottitis, rhinitis, rhinosinusitis, rhinopharyngitis, and supraglottitis.
Globally in 2019, there were 17·2 billion (95% UI 15·4–19·3) incident cases and 237 million (212–265) prevalent cases of upper respiratory infections, contributing to 9460 deaths (5540–14 900) and 6·39 million (3·96–9·72) DALYs.

otitis-media-respiratoryInfectionsAndTub.Definition:
Otitis media is an infection of the middle ear space. Included in the GBD modelling were cases meeting ICD-10 diagnostic criteria H65–H75.83.
Globally in 2019, there were 119 million (95% UI 103–140) prevalent cases of otitis media, with 360 million (243–523) incident cases.

meningitis-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, the membrane surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Included in the GBD model were cases meeting ICD-10 diagnostic criteria for meningitis due to bacteria or viruses: A39–A39.9, A87–A87.9, D86.81, G00.0–G00.8, and G03–G03.8.
Meningitis was responsible for 236 000 deaths (95% UI 204 000–277 000) in 2019. 112 000 deaths (87 400–145 000) occurred in children under 5 years, comprising 2·2% (1·9–2·6) of deaths for that population.

encephalitis-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Encephalitis is a disease caused by an acute inflammation of the brain. Included in the GBD model were cases meeting ICD-10 diagnostic criteria for encephalitis: A83–A86.4, B94.1, F07.1, G04–G05.8.
Encephalitis was responsible for 89 900 deaths (95% UI 76 500–123 000) in 2019. 16 900 deaths (13 100–22 100) occurred in children under 5 years, comprising 0·3% (0·3–0·4) of all deaths for that population.

diphtheria-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Diphtheria is a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
In 2019, diphtheria caused 4370 deaths (95% UI 2940–6200) globally. Of these, 3650 deaths (2320–5370) occurred in children under age 5, of which 3500 (2190–5200) took place in sub-Saharan Africa.

whooping-cough-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Pertussis is a contagious respiratory disease caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis.
In 2019, there were 19·5 million (95% UI 14·9–24·8) cases and 117 000 deaths (53 500–212 000) due to whooping cough (pertussis) globally. Death rates were highest in children aged 28–364 days, but declined in this population by 56·1% (21·0–75·7) between 1990 and 2019.

tetanus-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Tetanus is a serious bacterial disease with a high case fatality rate caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani.
Tetanus caused 34 700 global deaths (95% UI 25 900–48 500) in 2019, with a disproportionate burden in low SDI countries. 40·2% (32·6–51·9) of tetanus cases and 46·4% (38·2–57·3) of deaths occurred in countries in the lowest SDI quintile.

measles-otherInfectiousDiseases.Definition:
Measles is a contagious infection caused by the measles virus. Symptoms include cough, runny nose, fever, conjunctivitis, and red, blotchy skin.
Measles deaths declined from 802 000 deaths (95% UI 278 000–1 670 000) in 1990 to 83 400 deaths (31 000–180 000) in 2019. Still, 69 800 children (24 400–153 000) under 5 years died from measles in 2019; 78·2% (72·3–83·4) of these vaccine-preventable child deaths occurred in sub-Saharan Africa.

varicella-and-herpes-zoster-otherInfecti.Definition:
Varicella (chicken pox) is an acute infectious disease caused by primary infection of the varicella-zoster virus. Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by varicella-zoster virus reactivation in adults.
The global, age-standardised varicella and herpes zoster death rate declined by 47·6% (95% UI 40·9–53·6) from 1990 to 2019, to 0·2 deaths (0·2–0·2) per 100 000 in 2019. In 2019, most varicella-related deaths occurred in children under 5 years (5210 [4160–6480]).

neglected-tropical-diseases-and-malaria-.Definition:
This category estimates burden from Chagas, cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis, cystic echinococcosis, cysticercosis, dengue, Ebola, food-borne trematodes, Guinea worm disease, human African trypanosomiasis, malaria, lymphatic filariasis, onchocerciasis, rabies, schistosomiasis, soil-transmitted helminths, trachoma, yellow fever, Zika, and other NTDs.
Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) and malaria were responsible for 747 000 deaths (95% UI 407 000–1 250 000) in 2019.
neglected-tropical-diseases-and-malaria-.Category: Communicable, maternal, neonatal, and nutritional diseases

malaria-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAndMala.Definition:
This cause incorporates death and disability resulting from acute infection for both Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax and the long-term neurological consequences in a proportion of children who survive cerebral malaria.
Malaria was responsible for 643 000 deaths (95% UI 302 000–1 150 000) in 2019. 356 000 deaths (169 000–626 000) occurred in children under 5 years, comprising 7·1% (4·0–10·4) of total deaths in that age group.

chagas-disease-neglectedTropicalDiseases.Definition:
Chagas disease is caused by infection with Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted by Triatominae insect vectors, blood transfusion, organ transplant, and congenital transmission. Estimates include prevalent cases in non-endemic locations due to migration.
Chagas disease was responsible for 9490 deaths (95% UI 5500–16 500) and 275 000 DALYs (184 000–459 000) in 2019. Chagas is endemic in Latin American countries, but cases are also found in other locations due to migration.

endometriosis-gynecologicalDiseases.Definition:
Endometriosis is defined according to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) guidelines as cases diagnosed by pelvic exam confirmed by laparoscopy or pathology. Endometriosis is extrauterine growth of uterine tissue.
Endometriosis caused a total of 90 deaths (95% UI 49–141) globally in 2019. 0·6% (0·5–0·9) of all women—a total of 24·3 million (17·4–33·2) persons—were living with endometriosis in 2019.

upper-digestive-system-diseases-digestiv.Definition:
This Level 3 cause incorporates death due to peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, and duodenitis, and disability resulting from peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, duodenitis, and gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.
Upper digestive system diseases resulted in 6·47 million (95% UI 6·02–7·08) YLLs in 2019, a decrease of 26·2% (19·0–33·0) since 1990. YLDs due to these diseases, however, rose by 66·4% (61·2–70·5) to 8·40 million (4·93–13·8) in 2019.

other-sense-organ-diseases-senseOrganDis.Definition:
Other sense organ diseases is a residual category that captures both acute and chronic eye and ear conditions that do not map to other modelled diseases.
Acute and chronic other sense organ diseases resulted in 3·32 million (95% UI 1·97–5·13) global YLDs in 2019 and were responsible for 0·4% (0·3–0·5) of total global YLDs.

periodontal-diseases-oralDisorders.Definition:
Chronic periodontal disease is defined as Community Index of Periodontal Treatment Needs (CPITN) Class IV, attachment loss (AL) >6 mm, or gingival pocket depth (PD) >5 mm. It is caused by chronic bacterial infection around the teeth.
Chronic periodontal disease causes 7·09 million (95% UI 2·78–15·5) YLDs globally in 2019. It was also ranked seventh and 32nd globally for prevalence and incidence, with 1·09 billion (0·828–1·36) prevalent and 91·5 million (74·2–110) incident cases in 2019.

other-oral-disorders-oralDisorders.Definition:
Other oral disorders encompasses a wide variety of dental, tongue, and jaw disorders and malformations, including all oral disorders that are not included in the case definitions of permanent or deciduous dental caries, periodontal disease, or edentulism and severe tooth loss, but excluding oral cancers and congenital malformations.
In 2019, other oral disorders caused 4·22 million (95% UI 2·64–6·16) YLDs, and there were 146 million (140–153) prevalent cases.

sudden-infant-death-syndrome-otherNonCom.Definition:
SIDS is mortality in ages 7–364 days, where there is no clinical or pathological explanation for cause of death through any method, including an autopsy (ICD-10 R95).
Globally, sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) was responsible for 27 700 deaths (95% UI 12 100–60 900) in 2019. 2620 of these deaths (1480–4980) occurred in ages 7–27 days and 25 100 of these deaths (10 500–56 100) occurred in ages 28–364 days.

injuries-allCauses.Definition:
GBD defines injuries as death or disability due to the direct or indirect result of a physical force, immersion, or exposure, including accidental, interpersonal, or self-inflicted forces as well as war, conflict, violence, and natural disasters.
Injuries caused 4·30 million (95% UI 3·92–4·61) deaths in 2019, representing 7·6% (7·0–8·0) of all deaths and 11·0% (10·2–11·6) of YLLs. The age-standardised death rate from injuries decreased from 2010 to 2019 by 19·4% (-23·6 to -15·0). Injury death rates were generally higher in males.

transport-injuries-injuries.Definition:
Death or disability resulting from all subtypes of road injuries, including non-road transport injuries. ICD9: V00-V86.9, V87.2-V87.3, V88.2-V88.3, V90-V98.8. ICD10: E800-E807, E830-E838, E840-E849.
Transport injuries were responsible for 1·28 million (95% UI 1·13–1·39) deaths in 2019. 695 000 deaths (614 000–759 000) occurred in the 15–49 years age group globally, constituting 9·4% (8·3–9·8) of deaths and 10·0% (8·9–10·6) of YLLs for that population.

road-injuries-transportInjuries.Definition:
Road injuries includes death or disability due to unintentional interaction with an automobile, motorcycle, pedal cycle, or other vehicles.
Road injuries was responsible for 1·20 million (95% UI 1·06–1·30) deaths in 2019. 650 000 deaths (578 000–711 000) occurred in the 15-49 year age group, constituting 8·8% (7·8–9·2) of deaths and 9·4% (8·4–9·9) of YLLs at those ages. Road injuries was the 13th-leading Level 3 cause in terms of age-standardised death rate in 2019.

pedestrian-road-injuries-roadInjuries.Definition:
Death or disability due to collision as a pedestrian on the road with an automobile, motorcycle, pedal cycle, or other vehicles.
Pedestrian road injuries were responsible for 450 000 deaths (95% UI 387 000–503 000) in 2019. Age-standardised mortality rates (ASMRs) decreased from 7·4 per 100 000 (6·2–8·0) in 2010 to 5·6 per 100 000 (4·8–6·3) in 2019. ASMRs were highest in central sub-Saharan Africa, southern sub-Saharan Africa, Andean Latin America, eastern sub-Saharan Africa, and north Africa and the Middle East.

cyclist-road-injuries-roadInjuries.Definition:
Death or disability resulting from an unintentional incident as a cyclist or passenger on a pedal cycle.
Cyclist road injuries were responsible for 64 700 deaths (95% UI 54 300–73 200) in 2019, decreasing from 66 200 deaths (56 400–74 800) in 2010. Globally, the middle SDI quintile and low-middle SDI quintile countries had the highest age-standardised mortality rate, at 9·0 deaths per 100 000 (7·0–11·0).

motorcyclist-road-injuries-roadInjuries.Definition:
Death or disability that is caused by being a rider or passenger on a motorcycle or motorbike.
Motorcyclist road injuries were responsible for 222 000 deaths (95% UI 183 000–248 000) in 2019. 158 000 deaths (133 000–177 000) occurred in the 15–49 years age group, constituting 2·1% (1·8–2·3) of deaths in that age group. Age-standardised mortality rates decreased globally from 2010 to 2019.

motor-vehicle-road-injuries-roadInjuries.Definition:
Death or disability occurring as the result of being a driver or passenger in a motor vehicle.
Motor vehicle road injuries were responsible for 449 000 deaths (95% UI 397 000–500 000) in 2019. 267 000 deaths (235 000–299 000) occurred in the 15–49 years age group, constituting 3·6% (3·2–4·0) of deaths and 3·9% (3·5–4·3) of YLLs for that population.

stomach-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the stomach, including ICD-10 codes such as C16.
There were 1·27 million (95% UI 1·15–1·40) incident cases, 957 000 deaths (871 000–1 030 000), and 22·2 million (20·3–24·1) DALYs due to stomach cancer globally in 2019. Stomach cancer was the 16th-leading cause of death globally in 2019.

idiopathic-epilepsy-neurologicalDisorder.Definition:
Idiopathic active epilepsy is characterised by recurrent, unprovoked seizures for which there is no identified underlying disease and is presumed to have a strong genetic basis. Our case definition includes cases of active epilepsy with at least one seizure in the previous five years, regardless of treatment.
Idiopathic epilepsy resulted in 13·1 million (95% UI 9·99–16·7) global DALYs in 2019 and 0·5% (0·4–0·6) of total global DALYs.

multiple-sclerosis-neurologicalDisorders.Definition:
Multiple sclerosis is a chronic, degenerative, and progressive neurological condition typified by the damaging of the myelin sheaths of nerves. As in previous rounds of GBD, diagnosis by clinical exam or published clinical and imaging criteria was considered the reference.
Multiple sclerosis resulted in 1·16 million (1·00–1·38) global DALYs in 2019 and was responsible for 1·3% (0·7–2·0) of total global neurological disorder DALYs.

migraine-headacheDisorders.Definition:
Migraine is a disabling primary headache disorder, typically characterised by recurrent moderate or severe unilateral pulsatile headaches. The reference case definition is migraine in the last year satisfying the International Classification of Headache Disorders-3.
Migraine was responsible for 42·1 million (95% UI 6·42–95·6) YLDs, or 4·8% (0·8–10·1) of total YLDs in 2019. Migraine headache makes up 88·2% (60·7–97·7) of the burden of headache disorders.

congenital-heart-anomalies-congenitalBir.Definition:
This cause includes livebirths with any heart condition present at birth, including but not limited to malformations of great vessels, congenital valvular heart disease and patent ductus arteriosus, ventricular septal defect and atrial septal defect, single ventricle and single ventricle pathway heart defects, and complex congenital heart defects excluding single ventricle and single ventricle pathway models.
Congenital heart defects caused 217 000 deaths (95% UI 177 000–262 000) in 2019.

orofacial-clefts-congenitalBirthDefects.Definition:
Any livebirth with isolated cleft lip, isolated cleft palate, and combined cleft lip and cleft palate resulting from the tissues of the face not joining properly during foetal development.
Orofacial clefts caused 2770 all-ages deaths (1660–5440). The combined global incidence rate was 1·42 per 1000 (0·925–2·18) livebirths, and there were 4·62 million (3·76–5·67) people living with orofacial clefts in 2019.

down-syndrome-congenitalBirthDefects.Definition:
This cause includes any livebirth with the presence of a third copy of chromosome 21, typically caused by nondisjunction during the production of gametes. It is also known as trisomy 21.
Down syndrome caused 22 300 deaths (95% UI 17 800–33 200) in 2019 among all ages. 1·58 million (1·25–1·96) people were living with Down syndrome in 2019, a 25·7% (22·3–29·1) increase since 1990.

turner-syndrome-congenitalBirthDefects.Definition:
Any livebirth in which a female is partly or completely missing an X chromosome, also known as 45 XO.
The combined global incidence rate for Turner syndrome was 0·531 per 1000 (95% UI 0.367–0·715) livebirths and 784 000 individuals (577 000–1 020 000) were living with Turner syndrome in 2019, a 22·4% (20·3–24·6) increase since 1990.

klinefelter-syndrome-congenitalBirthDefe.Definition:
Any livebirth in which a male is born with an extra X chromosome in all or some of his cells. We also include other genotypes with supranumary X chromosomes, eg, XXXY, XXXXY, etc. Also known as 47 XXY.
The combined global incidence rate of Klinefelter syndrome was 0·219 per 1000 (95% UI 0·156–0·303) livebirths and 250 000 people (184 000–324 000) were living with Klinefelter syndrome in 2019, a 0·3% (–1·7 to 2·3) increase since 1990.

other-chromosomal-abnormalities-congenit.Definition:
A livebirth with a chromosomal abnormality other than Down/Turner/Klinefelter syndrome. Other chromosomal rearrangements include 47,XXX (triple X syndrome), other meiotic nondisjunction events, and other female sex chromosome abnormalities.
Other chromosomal abnormalities caused 20 700 all-ages deaths (14 100–35 600). The combined global incidence rate was 5·45 per 1000 (4·32–6·84) livebirths, and 3·20 million (2·73–3·75) people were living with chromosomal abnormalities in 2019.

congenital-musculoskeletal-and-limb-anom.Definition:
Congenital musculoskeletal defects is an anomaly of the muscles or skeletal system present at birth that is not caused by a defined chromosomal syndrome. We explicitly model three sub-categories: polydactyly and syndactyly, limb reduction defects, and all other congenital musculoskeletal anomalies.
Congenital musculoskeletal defects caused 11 200 deaths (95% UI 8020–15 900) in 2019 among all ages. 17·7 million (13·6–22·2) people were living with congenital musculoskeletal and limb anomalies in 2019, a 24·8% (21·2–29·3) increase since 1990.

conflict-and-terrorism-selfHarmAndInterp.Definition:
Conflict is armed violence between states, governments, and societies with destruction, mortality, and use of military forces. Terrorism is the unlawful or threatened use of force or violence against individuals to achieve political, religious, or ideological objectives.
Conflict and terrorism was responsible for 63 000 deaths (95% UI 57 200–69 300) in 2019. Of these deaths, 47 500 (43 100–52 300) occurred in locations with low SDIs and 34 (31–37) occurred in locations with high SDIs.

scabies-skinAndSubcutaneousDiseases.Definition:
Scabies is a skin disease caused by the microscopic mite Sarcoptes scabiei. The main symptom is an itchy, pimple-like rash (ICD-10: B86).
Globally, scabies was responsible for 4·84 million (95% UI 2·68–7·73) DALYs and 565 million (499–634) incident cases in 2019.

cataract-blindnessAndVisionLoss.Definition:
Cataracts form due to protein buildup that clouds the lens of the eye and impairs vision.
Low vision and blindness due to cataract resulted in 6·68 million (95% UI 4·76–9·01) global YLDs in 2019 and was responsible for 0·8% (0·7–0·9) of total global YLDs. Cataract is the first-ranked cause of global YLDs due to vision loss and blindness modelled in GBD 2019.

age-related-macular-degeneration-blindne.Definition:
In macular degeneration, deterioration of the macula leads to central vision loss.
Low vision and blindness due to age-related macular degeneration caused 564 000 global YLDs (95% UI 393 000–789 000) in 2019.

age-related-and-other-hearing-loss-sense.Definition:
Age-related and other hearing loss includes causes not identified as meningitis, chronic otitis media, or congenital. The dominant cause is presbycusis, the gradual loss of hearing with age caused by the breakdown of neurons in the inner ear.
In 2019, age-related and other hearing loss resulted in 40·2 million (95% UI 27·4–57·1) YLDs. It was the fourth-ranked cause of YLDs in 2019 for non-communicable diseases.

other-vision-loss-blindnessAndVisionLoss.Definition:
Other vision loss is residual category of eye diseases that cause vision loss. These include diseases of the retina, strabismus, and aphakia.
Low vision and blindness due to other vision loss resulted in 3·10 million (95% UI 2·21–4·24) global YLDs in 2019. Other vision loss is the fourth ranked cause of global YLDs due to vision loss and blindness modelled in GBD 2019.

esophageal-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the oesophagus, including ICD-10 codes such as C15.
There were 535 000 incident cases (95% UI 467 000–595 000), 498 000 deaths (438 000–551 000), and 11·7 million (10·4–12·9) DALYs due to oesophageal cancer globally in 2019.

liver-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the liver, including ICD-10 codes such as C22.
There were 534 000 incident cases (95% UI 487 000–589 000), 485 000 deaths (444 000–526 000), and 12·5 million (11·4–13·7) DALYs due to liver cancer globally in 2019.

liver-cancer-due-to-hepatitis-b-liverCan.Indicator: Liver cancer due to hepatitis B
liver-cancer-due-to-hepatitis-b-liverCan.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the liver (specifically due to hepatitis B), including ICD-10 codes such as C22.0.
There were 219 000 incident cases (95% UI 186 000–255 000), 192 000 deaths (162 000–224 000), and 5·80 million (4·91–6·77) DALYs from liver cancer due to hepatitis B globally in 2019.

liver-cancer-due-to-hepatitis-c-liverCan.Indicator: Liver cancer due to hepatitis C
liver-cancer-due-to-hepatitis-c-liverCan.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the liver (specifically due to hepatitis C), including ICD-10 codes such as C22.0.
There were 152 000 incident cases (95% UI 132 000–175 000), 142 000 deaths (122 000–162 000), and 2·88 million (2·44–3·32) DALYs from liver cancer due to hepatitis C globally in 2019.

liver-cancer-due-to-alcohol-use-liverCan.Indicator: Liver cancer due to alcohol use
liver-cancer-due-to-alcohol-use-liverCan.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the liver (specifically due to alcohol use), including ICD-10 codes such as C22.0.
There were 98 500 incident cases (95% UI 79 000–120 000), 90 700 deaths (73 300–109 000), and 2·18 million (1·76–2·65) DALYs from liver cancer due to alcohol use globally in 2019.

larynx-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from malignant neoplasms of the larynx, including ICD-10 codes such as C32.
There were 209 000 incident cases (95% UI 194 000–225 000), 123 000 deaths (115 000–133 000), and 3·26 million (3·03–3·51) DALYs due to larynx cancer globally in 2019.

leishmaniasis-neglectedTropicalDiseasesA.Definition:
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, transmitted by phlebotomine sandflies. Visceral leishmaniasis is the most serious manifestation, characterised by swelling of the liver and spleen. Individuals with cutaneous leishmaniasis develop lesions that can result in permanent scarring.
Leishmaniasis was responsible for 5710 deaths (95% UI 1690–18 700) and 697 000 DALYs (375 000–1 620 000) in 2019.

acute-myeloid-leukemia-leukemia.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the blood and bone marrow (specifically acute myeloid leukaemia), including ICD-10 codes such as C92.0.
There were 124 000 incident cases (95% UI 109 000–136 000), 94 100 deaths (82 600–101 000), and 3·06 million (2·77–3·37) DALYs due to acute myeloid leukaemia globally in 2019.

chronic-myeloid-leukemia-leukemia.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the blood and bone marrow (specifically chronic myeloid leukaemia), including ICD-10 codes such as C92.1, C92.2, and C93.1.
There were 65 800 incident cases (95% UI 59 400–74 100), 29 900 deaths (27 000–33 500), and 1·05 million (0·924–1·19) DALYs due to chronic myeloid leukaemia globally in 2019.

thalassemias-trait-hemoglobinopathiesAnd.Definition:
Thalassaemia trait is defined as heterozygous, or carrier, state for either the haemoglobin (Hb) beta mutation (beta thalassaemia trait) or E mutation (HbE trait). Milder forms of alpha thalassaemia are not included in the case definition.
There were a total of 6·34 million (95% UI 5·49–7·34) people born with thalassaemia trait in 2019 and a total of 398 million (348–462) living with it. Thalassaemia trait caused a total of 3·23 million (2·10–4·91) all-ages YLDs in 2019, a 7·3% (2·8–11·5) increase since 1990.

sickle-cell-trait-hemoglobinopathiesAndH.Definition:
SCT is defined as heterozygous, or carrier, state for the sickle mutation of haemoglobin (HbS). HbC and HbD are not included in the case definition.
There were a total of 10·1 million (95% UI 8·92–11·4) people born with sickle cell trait (SCT) in 2019 and a total of 438 million (384–499) living with SCT. SCT caused a total of 2·42 million (1·58–3·54) all-ages YLDs in 2019, a 38·5% (33·9–43·3) increase since 1990.

g6pd-trait-hemoglobinopathiesAndHemolyti.Definition:
G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive genetic disorder that is defined by reduced chemical activity of the G6PD enzyme. G6PD trait occurs only in females when one copy of the X chromosome has a mutation in the G6PD gene.
There were a total of 18·7 million (95% UI 18·0–19·5) females born with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) trait in 2019 and a total of 1·03 billion (0·998–1·07) living with G6PD trait. G6PD trait was responsible for 23 600 YLDs (15 700–34 200) in 2019.

environmental-heat-and-cold-exposure-uni.Definition:
Deaths or disability resulting from exposure to high or low temperatures in the environment, not including contact with fire, heat, or hot substances.
Environmental heat and cold exposure (EHCE) was responsible for 47 500 deaths (95% UI 32 200–54 400) in 2019. Age-standardised mortality rates decreased from 0·9 per 100 000 (0·7–1·0) in 2010 to 0·6 per 100 000 (0·4–0·7) in 2019.

ebola-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAndMalari.Definition:
Ebola virus is a relatively rare viral pathogen characterised by high case fatality. Clinical cases typically present initially as a febrile illness, which can be subsequently followed by haemorrhagic complications and death.
Ebola virus disease was responsible for 3680 deaths (95% UI 3020–4350) and 195 000 DALYs (160 000–231 000) in 2019, reflecting the 2018–2019 outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

acute-lymphoid-leukemia-leukemia.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the blood and bone marrow (specifically acute lymphoid leukaemia), including ICD-10 codes such as C91.0.
There were 153 000 incident cases (95% UI 129 000–171 000), 47 600 deaths (39 400–53 000), and 2·66 million (2·19–3·01) DALYs due to acute lymphoid leukaemia globally in 2019.

chronic-lymphoid-leukemia-leukemia.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the blood and bone marrow (specifically chronic lymphoid leukaemia), including ICD-10 codes such as C91.1.
There were 103 000 incident cases (95% UI 93 500–119 000), 44 600 deaths (40 400–50 100), and 948 000 (874 000–1 070 000) DALYs due to chronic lymphoid leukaemia globally in 2019.

non-melanoma-skin-cancer-(squamous-cell-.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive non-melanoma neoplasms of the skin (specifically squamous-cell carcinoma), including ICD-10 codes such as C44. Incident cases coded to C44 but without morphology codes were proportionally split to basal-cell and squamous-cell carcinoma.
There were 2·40 million (95% UI 2·12–2·71) incident cases, 56 100 deaths (50 400–59 800), and 1·18 million (1·08–1·26) DALYs due to squamous-cell carcinoma globally in 2019.

non-melanoma-skin-cancer-(basal-cell-car.Definition:
This cause includes disability resulting from invasive non-melanoma neoplasms of the skin (specifically basal-cell carcinoma). Incident cases coded to C44 but without morphology codes were proportionally split to basal-cell and squamous-cell carcinoma. No mortality is estimated for this cause.
There were 3·95 million (95% UI 3·49–4·46) incident cases and 1700 (782–3190) DALYs due to basal-cell carcinoma globally in 2019.

other-digestive-diseases-digestiveDiseas.Definition:
This residual cause encompasses a wide range of digestive diseases that do not map to other diseases in the GBD cause list, such as diverticulitis, polyps, haemorrhoids, hyperplasia of appendix, acute dilatation of stomach, and obstruction of duodenum.
Other digestive diseases caused 104 000 deaths (95% UI 84 400–119 000) and 2·50 million (2·12–2·80) global DALYs in 2019. These diseases are estimated to have also caused 319 000 YLDs (224 000–430 000).

neurological-disorders-nonCommunicableDi.Definition:
This aggregate cause incorporates death and disability from Alzheimer’s and other dementias, Parkinson’s, epilepsy, multiple sclerosis, motor neuron disease, headache disorders, and other neurological disorders (excluding stroke, meningitis, tetanus, brain cancer, and trauma).
Neurological disorders was responsible for 97·7 million (95% UI 55·9–159) DALYs, or 3·8% (2·2–6·2) of total DALYs in 2019.

tension-type-headache-headacheDisorders.Definition:
TTH is characterised by a dull, non-pulsatile, diffuse, band-like (or vice-like) pain of mild to moderate intensity in the head or neck. The reference case definition is TTH in the last year satisfying the ICHD-3.
Tension-type headache (TTH) was responsible for 4·54 million (95% UI 1·40–15·0) YLDs, or 0·5% (0·2–1·6) of total YLDs in 2019. Tension-type headache makes up 11·8% (2·3–39·3) of the burden of headache disorders.

motor-neuron-disease-neurologicalDisorde.Definition:
Motor neuron disease is set of chronic, degenerative, and progressive neurological conditions typified by the destruction of motor neurons and the subsequent deterioration of voluntary muscle activity. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common motor neuron disease.
Motor neuron disease resulted in 1·03 million (95% UI 0·980–1·09) global DALYs in 2019 and was responsible for 1·1% (0·6–1·9) of total global neurological disorder DALYs.

other-neurological-disorders-neurologica.Definition:
Other neurological disorders is a residual category.
Other neurological disorders resulted in 4·26 million (95% UI 3·46–5·17) global DALYs in 2019 and were responsible for 4·7% (2·7–7·6) of total global neurological disorder DALYs.

urogenital-congenital-anomalies-congenit.Definition:
Any livebirth with a urinary or genital condition, including congenital malformation of the collecting system, ureter, bladder, and kidney; bladder exstrophy and epispadias; hypospadias; ambiguous or indeterminate sex; and other genital malformations.
Urogenital congenital anomalies caused 10 200 all-ages deaths (95% UI 7550–13 400). The combined global incidence rate was 8·38 per 1000 (5·88–12·0) livebirths and 6·28 million (4·98–7·72) people were living with urogenital congenital anomalies in 2019.

digestive-congenital-anomalies-congenita.Definition:
This cause includes any livebirth with an anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract present at birth, including but not limited to congenital diaphragmatic hernia, malformations of the abdominal wall (gastroschisis, omphalocele, and prune belly), and atresia/stenosis of the digestive tract.
Digestive congenital anomalies caused 47 300 deaths (95% UI 30 300–75 100) in 2019. The combined global incidence rate was 5·69 per 1000 (4·10–7·41) livebirths, and 2·90 million (2·28–3·60) people were living with digestive congenital anomalies in 2019.

other-congenital-birth-defects-congenita.Definition:
Any livebirth with any condition present at birth that is a result of abnormalities of embryonic development and not represented in the aforementioned causes.
Other congenital birth defects caused 133 000 all-ages deaths (93 800–205 000) and was the ninth-ranked Level 4 cause of under-5 DALYs in 2019. 14·2 million (8·39–23·2) people were living with congenital birth defects in 2019, a 4·7% (–3·7 to 12·6) increase since 1990.

skin-and-subcutaneous-diseases-nonCommun.Definition:
This aggregate cause incorporates death and disability resulting from acne, alopecia, bacterial skin infections, decubitus ulcer, fungal skin diseases, pruritus, psoriasis, scabies, urticaria, viral skin diseases, and other skin diseases.
Globally, skin and subcutaneous diseases was responsible for 42·9 million (95% UI 28·6–63·4) DALYs and 4·86 billion (4·68–5·06) incident cases in 2019.

dermatitis-skinAndSubcutaneousDiseases.Definition:
Dermatitis, or eczema, refers to inflammation of the dermal layer of the skin, with disruption of the epidermal barrier. This aggregate cause incorporates disability resulting from atopic, contact, and seborrhoeic dermatitis.
Globally, dermatitis was responsible for 10·1 million (95% UI 5·96–15·8) DALYs and 418 million (361–478) incident cases in 2019.

executions-and-police-conflict-selfHarmA.Definition:
Police conflict and executions includes the lawful or threatened use of force or violence against individuals or groups of people or property in an attempt to achieve political or socioeconomic objectives for a state.
In 2019, age-standardised police conflict and executions death rates (per 100 000) were highest in north Africa and the Middle East (0·5 [95% UI 0·4–0·7]) and tropical Latin America (0·5 [0·3–0·6] ). Among high-income countries, rates were highest in the USA (0·4 [0·3–0·4]).

drug-susceptible-tuberculosis-tuberculos.Definition:
Drug-susceptible tuberculosis (among HIV-negative individuals) is distinguished as being responsive to isoniazid and rifampicin treatment.
Among HIV-negative individuals, there were an estimated 8·02 million (95% UI 6·96–9·19) incident cases of tuberculosis (TB) that were drug-susceptible and 1·06 million (0·924–1·19) deaths due to drug-susceptible tuberculosis in 2019.

zika-virus-neglectedTropicalDiseasesAndM.Definition:
Zika is a mosquito-borne virus that causes a mild febrile illness. In rare cases, Guillain-Barré syndrome or death can result. Congenital Zika syndrome represents a group of birth defects associated with infection during pregnancy, including microcephaly and motor impairments.
The global burden of Zika virus disease in 2019 was 347 DALYs (95% UI 256–455).

guinea-worm-disease-neglectedTropicalDis.Definition:
Dracunculus medinensis is a nematode that causes dracunculiasis, also known as Guinea worm disease. Guinea worm disease is characterised by the adult worm exiting the body, typically emerging from the lower extremities, causing pain and reduced mobility.
The global burden of Guinea worm disease in 2019 was 0·813 DALYs (95% UI 0·460–1·34), compared to the burden of 24 900 DALYs (15 600–36 800) in 1990, when large-scale eradication efforts began across Africa.

alcoholic-cardiomyopathy-cardiomyopathyA.Definition:
Alcoholic cardiomyopathy, a Level 4 sub-category of cardiomyopathy, is defined as heart failure due to the toxic effects of ingested alcohol.
Alcoholic cardiomyopathy was responsible for 2·44 million (95% UI 2·05–2·78) DALYs in 2019. In 2019, there were 448 000 prevalent cases (315 000–618 000) of alcoholic cardiomyopathy among those aged 40–70 and 208 000 cases (139 000–300 000) for those above the age of 70.

sexual-violence-interpersonalViolence.Definition:
Experiencing at least one event of sexual violence in the last year, where sexual violence is any sexual assault, including both penetrative sexual violence (rape) and non-penetrative sexual violence (other forms of unwanted sexual touching).
Sexual violence occurred in 4·2% (95% UI 3·7–4·9) of the all-age global female population and 2·4% (2·1–2·8) of the male population in 2019. The highest prevalence per capita was in women aged 20–25 in the region of Oceania for 2019.

myocarditis-cardiomyopathyAndMyocarditis.Definition:
Inflammation of the myocardium due to viral infections, autoimmune conditions, and other non-ischaemic causes. Chronic heart failure following the acute period of myocarditis is modelled separately and reported as heart failure due to myocarditis.
Myocarditis was responsible for 977 000 DALYs (95% UI 804 00–1 130 000) in 2019. In 2019, there were 728 000 incident cases (585 000–879 000) of myocarditis in males and 538 000 incident cases (436 000–651 000) in females.

other-leukemia-leukemia.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability from invasive neoplasms of the blood and bone marrow (specifically leukaemias not otherwise specified as AML, ALL, CML, or CLL), including ICD-10 codes such as C95.
There were 197 000 incident cases (95% UI 171 000–224 000), 118 000 deaths (103 000–132 000), and 3·94 million (3·38–4·47) DALYs due to other leukaemia globally in 2019.

other-cardiomyopathy-cardiomyopathyAndMy.Definition:
Other cardiomyopathy is a remainder category within the Level 3 cardiomyopathy and myocarditis cause, and estimates burden for all other cardiomyopathies not otherwise estimated. It excludes alcoholic cardiomyopathy, acute myocarditis, and other heart failure.
There were 236 000 deaths (95% UI 195 000–259 000) due to other cardiomyopathy in 2019, a 43·3% (30·7–56·5) increase from 1990. In 2019, there were 3·46 million (2·81–3·94) DALYs due to other cardiomyopathy in males and 2·26 million (1·90–2·52) DALYs in females.

tracheal,-bronchus,-and-lung-cancer-neop.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the trachea, bronchi, and lungs, including ICD-10 codes such as C33 and C34.
There were 2·26 million (95% UI 2·07–2·45) incident cases, 2·04 million (1·88–2·19) deaths, and 45·9 million (42·3–49·3) DALYs due to tracheal, bronchus, and lung cancers globally in 2019. Tracheal, bronchus, and lung cancers were the fifth-leading Level 3 cause of death globally in 2019.

breast-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the breasts, including ICD-10 codes such as C50.
There were 2·00 million (95% UI 1·83–2·17) incident cases, 701 000 deaths (647 000–752 000), and 20·6 million (19·0–22·2) DALYs due to breast cancer globally in 2019. Among females, breast cancer was the ninth-leading Level 3 cause of death globally in 2019.

cervical-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from malignant neoplasms of the cervix, including ICD-10 codes such as C53.
There were 566 000 incident cases (95% UI 482 000–636 000), 280 000 deaths (239 000–314 000), and 8·96 million (7·55–9·98) DALYs due to cervical cancer globally in 2019. Among females, cervical cancer was the 21st-leading Level 3 cause of death globally in 2019.

uterine-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes malignant neoplasms of the uterus and includes ICD-10 codes such as C54.
There were 435 000 incident cases (95% UI 397 000–480 000), 91 600 deaths (82 400–102 000), and 2·33 million (2·09–2·56) DALYs due to uterine cancer globally in 2019.

prostate-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the prostate, including ICD-10 codes such as C61.
There were 1·41 million (95% UI 1·23–1·83) incident cases, 487 000 deaths (420 000–594 000), and 8·64 million (7·55–10·6) DALYs due to prostate cancer globally in 2019. Among males, prostate cancer was the 18th-leading cause of death globally in 2019.

colon-and-rectum-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the colon and rectum, including ICD-10 codes such as C18, C19, C20, and C21.
There were 2·17 million (95% UI 2·00–2·34) incident cases, 1·09 million (1·00–1·15) deaths, and 24·3 million (22·6–25·7) DALYs due to colon and rectum cancer globally in 2019. Colon and rectum cancer was the 15th-leading Level 3 cause of death globally in 2019.

lip-and-oral-cavity-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from malignant neoplasms of the lips and oral cavity, including ICD-10 codes such as C00–C08.
There were 373 000 incident cases (95% UI 341 000–404 000), 199 000 deaths (182 000–218 000), and 5·51 million (5·00–6·03) DALYs due to lip and oral cavity cancer globally in 2019.

nasopharynx-cancer-neoplasms.Definition:
This cause includes death and disability resulting from invasive neoplasms of the nasopharynx, including ICD-10 codes such as C11.
There were 177 000 incident cases (95% UI 156 000–200 000), 71 600 deaths (65 400–77 600), and 2·34 million (2·14–2·54) DALYs due to nasopharynx cancer globally in 2019.

ff-inv-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

ff-gen-on-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

ff-gen-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

ff-cap-on-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

ff-cap-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

be-inv-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Bioenergy use falls into two main categories: “traditional” and “modern”. Traditional use refers to the combustion of biomass in such forms as wood, animal waste and traditional charcoal. Modern bioenergy technologies include liquid biofuels produced from bagasse and other plants; bio-refineries; biogas produced through anaerobic digestion of residues; wood pellet heating systems; and other technologies.

rh-inv-all-totalRenewable.Definition: The basic principle of hydropower is using water to drive turbines. Hydropower plants consist of two basic configurations: with dams and reservoirs, or without. Hydropower dams with a large reservoir can store water over short or long periods to meet peak demand. The facilities can also be divided into smaller dams for different purposes, such as night or day use, seasonal storage, or pumped-storage reversible plants, for both pumping and electricity generation. Hydropower without dams and reservoirs means producing at a smaller scale, typically from a facility designed to operate in a river without interfering in its flow. For this reason, many consider small-scale hydro a more environmentally-friendly option.

mr-inv-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Multiple renewables - see IRENA documentation for full definition.

sp-cap-off-totalRenewable.Definition: Photovoltaics (PV), also called solar cells, are electronic devices that convert sunlight directly into electricity. Solar PV installations can be combined to provide electricity on a commercial scale, or arranged in smaller configurations for mini-grids or personal use. Using solar PV to power mini-grids is an excellent way to bring electricity access to people who do not live near power transmission lines, particularly in developing countries with excellent solar energy resources.

sp-cap-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Photovoltaics (PV), also called solar cells, are electronic devices that convert sunlight directly into electricity. Solar PV installations can be combined to provide electricity on a commercial scale, or arranged in smaller configurations for mini-grids or personal use. Using solar PV to power mini-grids is an excellent way to bring electricity access to people who do not live near power transmission lines, particularly in developing countries with excellent solar energy resources.

Solar PV installations can be combined to provide electricity on a commercial scale, or arranged in smaller configurations for mini-grids or personal use. Using solar PV to power mini-grids is an excellent way to bring electricity access to people who do not live near power transmission lines, particularly in developing countries with excellent solar energy resources.

se-inv-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Energy can be harnessed directly from the sun, even in cloudy weather. Solar energy is used worldwide and is increasingly popular for generating electricity or heating and desalinating water. Solar power is generated in two main ways: Photovolatics and Concentrated Solar Power.

owe-gen-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Wind is used to produce electricity using the kinetic energy created by air in motion. This is transformed into electrical energy using wind turbines or wind energy conversion systems. Wind first hits a turbine’s blades, causing them to rotate and turn the turbine connected to them. That changes the kinetic energy to rotational energy, by moving a shaft which is connected to a generator, and thereby producing electrical energy through electromagnetism.

owe-gen-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Wind is used to produce electricity using the kinetic energy created by air in motion. This is transformed into electrical energy using wind turbines or wind energy conversion systems. Wind first hits a turbine’s blades, causing them to rotate and turn the turbine connected to them. That changes the kinetic energy to rotational energy, by moving a shaft which is connected to a generator, and thereby producing electrical energy through electromagnetism.

ge-inv-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Geothermal energy is heat derived within the sub-surface of the earth. Water and/or steam carry the geothermal energy to the Earth’s surface. Depending on its characteristics, geothermal energy can be used for heating and cooling purposes or be harnessed to generate clean electricity. However, for electricity, generation high or medium temperature resources are needed, which are usually located close to tectonically active regions.

rh-gen-on-totalRenewable.Definition: The basic principle of hydropower is using water to drive turbines. Hydropower plants consist of two basic configurations: with dams and reservoirs, or without. Hydropower dams with a large reservoir can store water over short or long periods to meet peak demand. The facilities can also be divided into smaller dams for different purposes, such as night or day use, seasonal storage, or pumped-storage reversible plants, for both pumping and electricity generation. Hydropower without dams and reservoirs means producing at a smaller scale, typically from a facility designed to operate in a river without interfering in its flow. For this reason, many consider small-scale hydro a more environmentally-friendly option.

n-inv-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Nuclear power is the use of nuclear reactions to produce electricity. Nuclear power can be obtained from nuclear fission, nuclear decay and nuclear fusion reactions. Presently, the vast majority of electricity from nuclear power is produced by nuclear fission of uranium and plutonium in nuclear power plants.

sb-gen-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Bioenergy use falls into two main categories: “traditional” and “modern”. Traditional use refers to the combustion of biomass in such forms as wood, animal waste and traditional charcoal. Modern bioenergy technologies include liquid biofuels produced from bagasse and other plants; bio-refineries; biogas produced through anaerobic digestion of residues; wood pellet heating systems; and other technologies.

ff-gen-off-totalNonRenewable.Definition: Fossil fuels include coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shales, bitumens, tar sands, and heavy oils. All contain carbon and were formed as a result of geologic processes acting on the remains of organic matter produced by photosynthesis.

one-cap-on-totalNonRenewable.Definition: There are four major types of nonrenewable resources: oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear energy. Oil, natural gas, and coal are collectively called fossil fuels. Fossil fuels were formed within the Earth from dead plants and animals over millions of years—hence the name “fossil” fuels.

one-cap-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: There are four major types of nonrenewable resources: oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear energy. Oil, natural gas, and coal are collectively called fossil fuels. Fossil fuels were formed within the Earth from dead plants and animals over millions of years—hence the name “fossil” fuels.

rmw-cap-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Municipal solid waste (MSW), often called garbage, is used to produce energy at waste-to-energy plants and at landfills in the United States. MSW contains: Biomass, or biogenic (plant or animal products), materials such as paper, cardboard, food waste, grass clippings, leaves, wood, and leather products. Nonbiomass combustible materials such as plastics and other synthetic materials made from petroleum. Noncombustible materials such as glass and metals.

rmw-cap-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Municipal solid waste (MSW), often called garbage, is used to produce energy at waste-to-energy plants and at landfills in the United States. MSW contains: Biomass, or biogenic (plant or animal products), materials such as paper, cardboard, food waste, grass clippings, leaves, wood, and leather products. Nonbiomass combustible materials such as plastics and other synthetic materials made from petroleum. Noncombustible materials such as glass and metals.

This is transformed into electrical energy using wind turbines or wind energy conversion systems. Wind first hits a turbine’s blades, causing them to rotate and turn the turbine connected to them. That changes the kinetic energy to rotational energy, by moving a shaft which is connected to a generator, and thereby producing electrical energy through electromagnetism.

owe-cap-off-totalRenewable.Definition: Wind is used to produce electricity using the kinetic energy created by air in motion. This is transformed into electrical energy using wind turbines or wind energy conversion systems. Wind first hits a turbine’s blades, causing them to rotate and turn the turbine connected to them. That changes the kinetic energy to rotational energy, by moving a shaft which is connected to a generator, and thereby producing electrical energy through electromagnetism.

one-gen-on-totalNonRenewable.Definition: There are four major types of nonrenewable resources: oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear energy. Oil, natural gas, and coal are collectively called fossil fuels. Fossil fuels were formed within the Earth from dead plants and animals over millions of years—hence the name “fossil” fuels.

one-gen-all-totalNonRenewable.Definition: There are four major types of nonrenewable resources: oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear energy. Oil, natural gas, and coal are collectively called fossil fuels. Fossil fuels were formed within the Earth from dead plants and animals over millions of years—hence the name “fossil” fuels.

rmw-gen-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Municipal solid waste (MSW), often called garbage, is used to produce energy at waste-to-energy plants and at landfills in the United States. MSW contains: Biomass, or biogenic (plant or animal products), materials such as paper, cardboard, food waste, grass clippings, leaves, wood, and leather products. Nonbiomass combustible materials such as plastics and other synthetic materials made from petroleum. Noncombustible materials such as glass and metals.

rmw-gen-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Municipal solid waste (MSW), often called garbage, is used to produce energy at waste-to-energy plants and at landfills in the United States. MSW contains: Biomass, or biogenic (plant or animal products), materials such as paper, cardboard, food waste, grass clippings, leaves, wood, and leather products. Nonbiomass combustible materials such as plastics and other synthetic materials made from petroleum. Noncombustible materials such as glass and metals.

me-gen-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Tides, waves and currents can be used to produce electricity. Although still at the research and development stage and not yet commercially available, promising ocean technologies include: Wave energy, tidal energy, salinity gradient energy, and ocean thermal energy conversion.

me-gen-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Tides, waves and currents can be used to produce electricity. Although still at the research and development stage and not yet commercially available, promising ocean technologies include: Wave energy, tidal energy, salinity gradient energy, and ocean thermal energy conversion.

me-cap-on-totalRenewable.Definition: Tides, waves and currents can be used to produce electricity. Although still at the research and development stage and not yet commercially available, promising ocean technologies include: Wave energy, tidal energy, salinity gradient energy, and ocean thermal energy conversion.

me-cap-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Tides, waves and currents can be used to produce electricity. Although still at the research and development stage and not yet commercially available, promising ocean technologies include: Wave energy, tidal energy, salinity gradient energy, and ocean thermal energy conversion.

rh-gen-off-totalRenewable.Definition: The basic principle of hydropower is using water to drive turbines. Hydropower plants consist of two basic configurations: with dams and reservoirs, or without. Hydropower dams with a large reservoir can store water over short or long periods to meet peak demand. The facilities can also be divided into smaller dams for different purposes, such as night or day use, seasonal storage, or pumped-storage reversible plants, for both pumping and electricity generation. Hydropower without dams and reservoirs means producing at a smaller scale, typically from a facility designed to operate in a river without interfering in its flow. For this reason, many consider small-scale hydro a more environmentally-friendly option.

rh-cap-off-totalRenewable.Definition: The basic principle of hydropower is using water to drive turbines. Hydropower plants consist of two basic configurations: with dams and reservoirs, or without. Hydropower dams with a large reservoir can store water over short or long periods to meet peak demand. The facilities can also be divided into smaller dams for different purposes, such as night or day use, seasonal storage, or pumped-storage reversible plants, for both pumping and electricity generation. Hydropower without dams and reservoirs means producing at a smaller scale, typically from a facility designed to operate in a river without interfering in its flow. For this reason, many consider small-scale hydro a more environmentally-friendly option.

sb-gen-off-totalRenewable.Definition: Bioenergy use falls into two main categories: “traditional” and “modern”. Traditional use refers to the combustion of biomass in such forms as wood, animal waste and traditional charcoal. Modern bioenergy technologies include liquid biofuels produced from bagasse and other plants; bio-refineries; biogas produced through anaerobic digestion of residues; wood pellet heating systems; and other technologies.

Modern bioenergy technologies include liquid biofuels produced from bagasse and other plants; bio-refineries; biogas produced through anaerobic digestion of residues; wood pellet heating systems; and other technologies.

ge-gen-off-totalRenewable.Definition: Geothermal energy is heat derived within the sub-surface of the earth. Water and/or steam carry the geothermal energy to the Earth’s surface. Depending on its characteristics, geothermal energy can be used for heating and cooling purposes or be harnessed to generate clean electricity. However, for electricity, generation high or medium temperature resources are needed, which are usually located close to tectonically active regions.

ge-gen-all-totalRenewable.Definition: Geothermal energy is heat derived within the sub-surface of the earth. Water and/or steam carry the geothermal energy to the Earth’s surface. Depending on its characteristics, geothermal energy can be used for heating and cooling purposes or be harnessed to generate clean electricity. However, for electricity, generation high or medium temperature resources are needed, which are usually located close to tectonically active regions.
