rfti-ict-readinessForFrontierTechnologie.Definition: This is the level of ICT infrastructure. Using, adopting and adapting frontier technologies requires sufficient ICT infrastructure, especially since AI, IoT, big data and blockchain are internet-based technologies. Two aspects of ICT infrastructure need to be considered: the prevalence to ensure that everyone has access and that no one is left behind; and the quality of infrastructure that allows for more advanced and efficient use. For these purposes, internet users as a percentage of the population captures the prevalence of internet infrastructure, while the mean download speed measures the quality of internet connection.

rfti-skills-readinessForFrontierTechnolo.Definition: Using, adopting and adapting frontier technologies needs people equipped with relevant skills. These may be advanced but are generally lower than those required to originate the technologies. Two types of skills need to be considered: skills acquired through education, and skills acquired in the workplace through practical training or learning-by-doing. The overall educational attainment of the population is measured through expected years of schooling, while the skill level in the labour market is measured by the extent of high-skill employment – defined by the ILO as the sum of managers, professionals and technicians and associate professionals following the International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO). These indicators need to be interpreted with caution, especially in developing countries, because of the emigration of highly trained or skilled people, the “brain drain”, as a result of which the actual skill level could be lower than the official estimate.

rfti-rd-readinessForFrontierTechnologies.Definition: R&D activity is needed not just for the production of frontier technologies, but also for adoption and adaption, as these technologies often require adjustment or modification for local use. R&D activities are measured using the number of publications and patents filed on the 11 frontier technologies in a country. The publication and patent search queries used are the same as shown in the Technical note in Annex B, the only difference being the year of interest – a single year for the index instead of 1996-2018. The countries of publication of authors and patent assignees were analysed. It should be noted that, especially in developing countries, there are informal R&D activities that do not result in a publication or patent so the R&D scores might not reflect the actual scale of activities.

rfti-industry-readinessForFrontierTechno.Definition: Industry activity – This building block aims to capture ongoing activities in an industry related to the use, adoption and adaption of frontier technologies. It considers three sectors that are early adopters: manufacturing, with high-tech manufacturing as the frontrunner; finance; and ICT, which tends to interact with other technologies. Then it uses export data, on high-technology manufactures, as well as on digitally deliverable services which cover both finance and ICT. However, especially in developing countries, activities are also undertaken by firms in the informal sector – which are often outside official statistics. The scores from these countries could therefore be lower than the actual activity.

rfti-finance-readinessForFrontierTechnol.Definition: This assesses the availability of finance to the private sector. Better access to finance could accelerate the use, adoption and adaption of frontier technologies. For this purpose, domestic credit to the private sector as a percentage of GDP was selected as part of the index. This indicator measures resources provided by financial corporations such as finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds and foreign exchange companies. It also includes various financial instruments including loans, purchases of non-equity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable. However, there could also be other, unconventional financing providers or financial instruments that are not covered sufficiently by this indicator

rfti-score-readinessForFrontierTechnolog.Definition:
The index comprises five building blocks: ICT deployment, skills, R&D activity, industry activity and access to finance. Only a few countries currently produce frontier technologies and in the short run this is unlikely to change.
But all countries need to prepare for them. To assess progress this report has developed a country readiness index. This takes into account technological capacities related to physical investment, human capital and
technological effort, and covers national capacities to use, adopt and adapt these technologies:43
Use – This requires basic capacities, passive skills and effort along with infrastructure, and some
technological knowledge. This might involve, for example, following AI-driven recommendation
from an e-commerce website, or using a chatbot.
Adopt – Active use for one’s own purposes requires more advanced capability levels. This
could mean using AI to produce recommendations or run a chatbot for a business website.
Adapt – Modifying the technologies requires further advanced capabilities – such as for tailoring
AI-driven recommendations or localizing the features of a chatbot.

rfti-rank-readinessForFrontierTechnologi.Definition:
The index comprises five building blocks: ICT deployment, skills, R&D activity, industry activity and access to finance. Only a few countries currently produce frontier technologies and in the short run this is unlikely to change.
But all countries need to prepare for them. To assess progress this report has developed a country readiness index. This takes into account technological capacities related to physical investment, human capital and
technological effort, and covers national capacities to use, adopt and adapt these technologies:43
Use – This requires basic capacities, passive skills and effort along with infrastructure, and some
technological knowledge. This might involve, for example, following AI-driven recommendation
from an e-commerce website, or using a chatbot.
Adopt – Active use for one’s own purposes requires more advanced capability levels. This
could mean using AI to produce recommendations or run a chatbot for a business website.
Adapt – Modifying the technologies requires further advanced capabilities – such as for tailoring
AI-driven recommendations or localizing the features of a chatbot.

rfti-group-readinessForFrontierTechnolog.Definition:
The index yielded results for 158 countries with the United States, Switzerland and the United Kingdom
receiving the highest scores on a scale of 0 to 1 (Table 1). Based on their rankings, countries are placed
within one of four 25-percentile score groups: low, lower-middle, upper-middle, and high values of the index.

ssi-1-basicNeeds.Definition: Indicator: Prevalence of undernourishment (percent). Sufficient food is defined as the availability of at least the minimum level of dietary energy for each person. It is one of the very basic conditions for people for proper development.

ssi-2-basicNeeds.Definition: Indicator: Percentage of population using at least basic drinking water. According to the definition of WHO, access to an improved water source means that at least 20 liters of safe drinking water per person per day should be available within one kilometer of a user’s dwelling. An improved water source includes: household connections, public standpipes, boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs and rainwater collection.

ssi-3-basicNeeds.Definition: Indicator: Percentage of population using at least basic sanitation services. Sanitation means the collection, transport, treatment and disposal or reuse of human excreta or domestic wastewater, whether through collective systems or by installations serving a single household or undertaking. Improved sanitation includes any of the following excreta and wastewater disposal facilities: connection to a public sewer, connection to a septic tank, pour-flush latrine, simple pit latrine and ventilated improved pit latrine.

ssi-4-personalDevelopmentAndHealth.Definition: Indicator: Gross enrolment ratio, primary to tertiary, both sexes (%). The combined Gross enrolment ratio expresses the number of students enrolled in primary, secondary and tertiary levels of education, regardless of age, as a percentage of the population of official school age for the three levels. Since all students are included, regardless of age, the ratio can be more than 100%. This happens when students younger or older than the official school age are enrolled.

ssi-5-personalDevelopmentAndHealth.Definition: Indicator: Life expectancy at birth, total (years). Commonly, life expectancy at birth is used as a measure for the level of a country’s health care. However, WHO has refined this measure in 2002, resulting in the Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE). This is the number of years that a newborn is expected to live minus the number of years spent in poor health. HALE thus not only takes into account the average number of years people are living, but also their health.

ssi-6-personalDevelopmentAndHealth.Definition: Indicator: Gender Gap Index. The Gender Gap Index, yearly published by World Economic Forum, is a comprehensive index, based on 14 indicators aggregated into 4 categories: 1.  Economic participation and opportunity (salaries, participation levels and access to high-skilled employment). 2.  Educational attainment (access to basic and higher level education). 3.  Political empowerment (representation in decision-making structures). 1.  4. Health and survival (life expectancy and sex ratio).

ssi-7-wellBalanceSociety.Definition: Indicator: Ratio of income share held by lowest 10% to income share held by. This indicator assesses the level of equality of the distribution of income of the richest 10% to the poorest 10% of the people in a country. A low level of inequality is supposed to contribute to a stable society, whereas a high level of inequality provokes unrest or worse in a society.

ssi-8-wellBalanceSociety.Definition: Indicator: Average yearly 5-years change in Population, total. More inhabitants on earth mean a larger demand for the limited available space and other resources on our planet, many of the latter not being renewable. For nature, for food supply, for resources etc. fewer inhabitants would be better. In this respect a negative population growth, i.e. a decreasing number of inhabitants instead of the continuous and rapid population growth we nowadays face in many countries, is positive.

ssi-9-wellBalanceSociety.Definition: Indicator: Sum of the values of the six Worldwide Governance Indicators. Yearly the World Bank publishes the level of Good Governance, based on the assessment of six major issues: 1.  Voice and Accountability, 2.  Political Stability, 3.  Government Effectiveness, 4.  Regulatory Quality, 5.  Rule of Law and 6.  Control of Corruption. The World Bank uses a scale of +2.5 to -2.5 for each item, so by adding up one gets a scale of +15 to -15. For the SSI these six issues have been integrated into one indicator, expressing the level of Good Governance.

ssi-10-naturalResources.Definition: Indicator: 10-years change in a) Forest area (% of land area) and b) Terrestrial. Biodiversity is expressed by two sub indicators: the 10-years change of forest area and the size of protected land areas in % of the total land area of a country.

ssi-11-naturalResources.Definition: Indicator: Total freshwater withdrawal. To monitor the sufficiency and the depletion of fresh water resources, the indicator Renewable Water Resources expresses the water consumption per year as a percentage of total available renewable water resources. This total includes internal and external (flowing in from neighboring countries) water resources.

ssi-12-naturalResources.Definition: Indicator: Ecological Footprint (gha per person). As a proxy for consumption the Ecological Footprint has been used minus the Carbon Footprint. The latter is already included in the SSI, by the indicator Emission of Greenhouse Gases.

ssi-13-climateAndEnergy.Definition: Indicator: Primary energy usage. Energy use (TPES – Total Primary Energy Supply) is defined as production + imports - exports ± stock changes.

ssi-14-climateAndEnergy.Definition: Indicator: Change in primary energy usage between 2013 and 2017 in %. In many places and regions around the world targets are set to reduce the consumption of energy. The results of energy use reduction plans and activities can be monitored by this indicator.

ssi-15-climateAndEnergy.Definition: Indicator: Total CO  emissions - Fuel Combustion (Mt of CO ). This indicator uses the common measure for Emission of Greenhouse Gases (GHG): the amount of emitted CO . Thus other GHG emissions, like CH , N O, HFCs, PFCs and SF , 2 4 2 6are not included.

ssi-16-climateAndEnergy.Definition: Indicator: Renewable energy consumption (% of total final energy. Consumption of renewable energy expresses the share of energy produced by renewable sources in % of total energy (TPES, Total Primary Energy Supply). According to the definition used by IEA, renewable energy includes hydro, geothermal, solar photovoltaic, solar thermal, tide, wave, ocean, wind, solid biomass, gases from biomass, liquid biomass and renewable municipal waste.

ssi-17-transition.Definition: Indicator: organic area share of total farmland [%]. Organic Farming is expressed by the area of fully converted and in-conversion organically cultivated land as the percentage of total agricultural area.

ssi-18-transition.Definition: Indicator: Adjusted net savings, including particulate emission damage (% of. Genuine Savings (= Adjusted Net Savings) measures the true rate of savings in an economy after taking into account investments in human capital, depletion of natural resources and damage caused by pollution. The used data are including particulate emission damage.

ssi-19-economy.Definition: Indicator: GDP per capita, PPP (current international $). Gross domestic product (GDP) is the market value of all goods and services produced within a country in a given period. It is a measure of a country’s economy as far as money is involved. To enable a fair comparison across countries GDP is calculated in Purchasing Power Parity, PPP, i.e. the exchange rate is adjusted so that an identical good in two different countries has the same price when expressed in the same currency (current international dollar).

ssi-20-economy.Definition: Indicator: Unemployment, total (% of total labor force) (modeled ILO. Employment is a common indicator to measure the status of a country’s economy. Moreover, for most people employment is an important condition for the possibilities of developing her- or himself.

ssi-21-economy.Definition: Indicator: Gross PSD, General Gov., All maturities, All instruments, Nominal. The amount of public debt of a country determines the yearly payments on interest and amortization. This limits a government in the free allocation of its budget. Thus, it is an important indicator for economy, as well as for the society at large.

ssi-bn-basicNeeds.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for sufficient food, sufficient drinking water, and safe sanitation.

ssi-pdh-personalDevelopmentAndHealth.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for education, healthy life, and gender equality.

ssi-wbs-wellBalanceSociety.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for income distribution, population growth, and good governance.

ssi-nr-naturalResources.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for biodiversity, renewable energy resources, and consumption.
ssi-nr-naturalResources.Source: FAO, World Bank, Global Footprint Network

ssi-ce-climateAndEnergy.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for energy use, energy savings, greenhouse gases, and renewable energy.

ssi-t-transition.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for organic farming and genuine savings.

ssi-e-economy.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for GDP, employment, and public debt.

ssi-hwi-humanWellbeing.Definition: A geometric average of the composite scores for basic needs, personal development and health, and a well-balanced society.

ssi-enwi-environmentalWellbeing.Definition: A geometric average of the composite scores for natural resources and climate and energy.

ssi-ecwi-economicWellbeing.Definition: A geometric average of the scores for transition and economy.

ssi-ssi-ssi.Definition: The Sustainable Society Index is based on the overall approach to sustainability based on the Triple Bottom Line which includes all three wellbeing dimensions: Human, Environmental and Economic Wellbeing. The SSI is used for monitoring the progress of a country on its way to sustainability, for setting policy priorities with respect to sustainability, to make comparisons between countries when assessing corporate risks, for education purposes, and for further research and development.

unicef-d1-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d2-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d3-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d4-demographics.Definition: Average exponential rate of growth of the population over one year.  It is calculated as ln(Pt/P0)/t where t is the length of the period. It is expressed as a percentage.
unicef-d4-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d5-demographics.Definition: Average exponential rate of growth of the population over one year.  It is calculated as ln(Pt/P0)/t where t is the length of the period. It is expressed as a percentage.
unicef-d5-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d6-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d7-demographics.Definition: The average number of live births a hypothetical cohort of women would have at the end of their reproductive period if they were subject during their whole lives to the fertility rates of a given period and if they were not subject to mortality. It is expressed as live births per woman.
unicef-d7-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d8-demographics.Definition: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d8-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d9-demographics.Definition: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d9-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d10-demographics.Definition: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d10-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d11-demographics.Definition: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d11-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d12-demographics.Definition: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d12-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d13-demographics.Definition: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d13-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d14-demographics.Definition: Urban population as a percentage of the total population.
unicef-d14-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d15-demographics.Indicator: Annual growth rate of urban population
unicef-d15-demographics.Definition: verage annual exponential rate of growth of the urban population over a given period, expressed as a percentage.
unicef-d15-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d16-demographics.Indicator: Annual growth rate of urban population
unicef-d16-demographics.Definition: verage annual exponential rate of growth of the urban population over a given period, expressed as a percentage.
unicef-d16-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d17-demographics.Definition: The number of immigrants minus the number of emigrants over a period, divided by the person-years lived by the population of the receiving country over that period. It is expressed as net number of migrants per 1,000 population.
unicef-d17-demographics.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-cm1-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm1-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm2-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm2-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm3-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm3-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm4-childMortality.Indicator: Annual rate of reduction in under-five mortality rate
unicef-cm4-childMortality.Definition: The annual percentage reduction in the under-five mortality rate (U5MR) defined as ARR=100*(ln(U5MRt2/U5MRt1)/(t1-t2)), where t1=2000 and t2=2019.
unicef-cm4-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm5-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm5-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm6-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm6-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm7-childMortality.Definition: Infant mortality rate - Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm7-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm8-childMortality.Definition: Infant mortality rate - Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm8-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm9-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm9-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm10-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm10-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm11-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm11-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm12-childMortality.Indicator: Mortality rate among children aged 5–14 years
unicef-cm12-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying at age 5–14 years expressed per 1,000 children aged 5
unicef-cm12-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm13-childMortality.Indicator: Mortality rate among children aged 5–14 years
unicef-cm13-childMortality.Definition: Probability of dying at age 5–14 years expressed per 1,000 children aged 5
unicef-cm13-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm14-childMortality.Definition: Stillbirth rate (SBR) is defined as the number of babies born with no sign of life at 28 weeks or more of gestation per 1,000 total births
unicef-cm14-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm15-childMortality.Definition: Stillbirth rate (SBR) is defined as the number of babies born with no sign of life at 28 weeks or more of gestation per 1,000 total births
unicef-cm15-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm16-childMortality.Indicator: Annual rate of reduction in stillbirth rate
unicef-cm16-childMortality.Definition: The annual percentage reduction in the stillbirth rate (SBR) defined as ARR=100*(ln(SBRt2/SBRt1)/(t1-t2)), where t1=2000 and t2=2019.
unicef-cm16-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm17-childMortality.Definition: Number of deaths among children under 5 years of age
unicef-cm17-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm18-childMortality.Definition: Number of deaths occurring within the first 28 days of life
unicef-cm18-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm19-childMortality.Indicator: Neonatal deaths as a percentage of under-five deaths
unicef-cm19-childMortality.Definition: The percentage of under-five deaths occurring within the first 28 days of life
unicef-cm19-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm20-childMortality.Definition: Number of deaths among children aged 5 to 14 years
unicef-cm20-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm21-childMortality.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-mnh1-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Number of years newborn female children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-mnh1-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects 2019. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh2-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Indicator: Demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods
unicef-mnh2-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15 49) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods.
unicef-mnh2-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), based on Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), Reproductive Health Surveys, other national surveys, and National Health Information Systems (HIS). Last Update: May 2021.

unicef-mnh3-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Number of births per 1,000 adolescent girls aged 15 19
unicef-mnh3-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations Population Division, 2019. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh4-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women aged 20 24 who gave birth before age 18. The indicator refers to women who had a live birth in a recent time period, generally two years for MICS and five years for DHS.
unicef-mnh4-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh5-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15-19 and 15-49) attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel (typically a doctor, nurse or midwife).
unicef-mnh5-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh6-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15-49) attended by any provider at least four times.
unicef-mnh6-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Dimension: At least four visits, women aged 15-49
unicef-mnh6-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh7-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged-15 19) attended by any provider at least four times.
unicef-mnh7-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Dimension: At least four visits, women aged 15-19
unicef-mnh7-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh8-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of births from mothers (aged 15 19 and 15 49), attended by skilled heath personnel (typically a doctor, nurse or midwife).
unicef-mnh8-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: Joint UNICEF/WHO SBA database, based on DHS, MICS and other national household surveys as well as national administrative data. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh9-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15 49) who gave birth in a health facility.
unicef-mnh9-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh10-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of births delivered by Caesarean section. NB: C-section rates between 5 per cent and 15 per cent are expected with adequate levels of emergency obstetric care.
unicef-mnh10-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh11-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of last live births in the last two years who received a health check within two days after delivery. NB: For MICS, health check refers to a health check while in facility or at home following delivery or a postnatal visit.
unicef-mnh11-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh12-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of newborns who received a health check within 2 days after delivery of their birth. For MICS, health check refers to a health check while in facility or at home following delivery or a postnatal visit.
unicef-mnh12-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh13-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15 49) who received a health check within 2 days after delivery of their most recent live birth in the last 2 years. NB: For MICS, health check refers to a health check while in facility or at home following delivery or a postnatal visit.
unicef-mnh13-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh14-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Number of deaths of women from pregnancy-related causes (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh14-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-mnh15-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Number of deaths of women from pregnancy-related causes per 100,000 live births during the same time period (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh15-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-mnh16-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Definition: Lifetime risk of maternal death takes into account both the probability of becoming pregnant and the probability of dying as a result of that pregnancy, accumulated across a woman’s reproductive years (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh16-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Dimension: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in X)
unicef-mnh16-maternalAndNewbornHealth.Source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-ch1-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of live births who received bacilli Calmette−Guérin (vaccine against tuberculosis).
unicef-ch1-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch2-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received the first dose of diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus vaccine.
unicef-ch2-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch3-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus vaccine.
unicef-ch3-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch4-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of the polio vaccine.
unicef-ch4-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch5-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received the first dose of the measles−containing vaccine.
unicef-ch5-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch6-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of children who received the second dose of measles−containing vaccine as per national schedule.
unicef-ch6-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch7-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.
unicef-ch7-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch8-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.
unicef-ch8-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch9-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received the last dose of rotavirus vaccine as recommended.
unicef-ch9-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch10-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
unicef-ch10-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch11-childHealth.Definition: Protection at birth (PAB) – Percentage of newborns protected at birth against tetanus with tetanus toxoid.
unicef-ch11-childHealth.Source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch12-childHealth.Indicator: Pneumonia care seeking for children with symptoms of Acute Respiratory Infection
unicef-ch12-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 with symptoms of pneumonia (cough and fast or difficult breathing due to a problem in the chest) in the two weeks preceding the survey for whom advice or treatment was sought from a health facility or provider.
unicef-ch12-childHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ch13-childHealth.Indicator: Diarrhea treatment with oral rehydration salts
unicef-ch13-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 who had diarrhoea in the two weeks preceding the survey and who received oral rehydration salts (ORS packets or pre−packaged ORS fluids).
unicef-ch13-childHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ch14-childHealth.Indicator: Malaria care seeking for children with fever
unicef-ch14-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of children under five years of age with fever for whom advice or treatment was sought from a health facility or provider. Excludes drug vendor, stores, shops and traditional healer. In some countries, particularly non−malaria endemic countries, pharmacies have also been excluded from the calculation.
unicef-ch14-childHealth.Source: DHS, MICS, MIS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ch15-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 who slept under an insecticide−treated mosquito net the night prior to the survey.
unicef-ch15-childHealth.Source: DHS, MICS, MIS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ch16-childHealth.Indicator: Households with at least one ITN
unicef-ch16-childHealth.Definition: Percentage of households with at least one insecticide−treated mosquito net.
unicef-ch16-childHealth.Source: HDHS, MICS, MIS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah1-adolescentHealth.Definition: The probability of dying between exact age 10 and exact age 20, expressed per 1,000 children aged 10
unicef-ah1-adolescentHealth.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: September 2020.

unicef-ah2-adolescentHealth.Definition: Number of deaths aged 10 to 19 years
unicef-ah2-adolescentHealth.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: September 2020.

unicef-ah3-adolescentHealth.Indicator: Annual rate of reduction in the adolescent mortality rate, Aged 10-19
unicef-ah3-adolescentHealth.Definition: The annual rate of reduction in adolescent mortality rate (AMR) defined as AMR=100*(ln(AMRt2/AMRt1)/(t1-t2)), where t1=2000 and t2=2019.
unicef-ah3-adolescentHealth.Source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: September 2020.

unicef-ah4-adolescentHealth.Definition: Number of births per 1,000 adolescent girls aged 15-19
unicef-ah4-adolescentHealth.Source: Global SDG Indicators Database, 2021. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah5-adolescentHealth.Indicator: Births by age 18, (women aged 20-24 years who gave birth before age 18)
unicef-ah5-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of women aged 20-24 who gave birth before age 18. The indicator refers to women who had a live birth in a recent time period, generally two years for MICS and five years for DHS.
unicef-ah5-adolescentHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah6-adolescentHealth.Indicator: Demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods, Aged 15-19
unicef-ah6-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15-19) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods.
unicef-ah6-adolescentHealth.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2021). World Contraceptive Use 2021. New York: United Nations; based on Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), Reproductive Health Surveys, other national surveys, and National Health Information Systems (HIS). Last Update: May 2021.

unicef-ah7-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of women (aged 15-19) attended by any provider at least four times.
unicef-ah7-adolescentHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah8-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of births from mothers aged 15-19, attended by skilled heath personnel (typically a doctor, nurse or midwife).
unicef-ah8-adolescentHealth.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah9-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of girls who received the last dose of human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine per national schedule
unicef-ah9-adolescentHealth.Source: WHO/UNICEF estimates of human papillomavirus (HPV) immunization coverage, 2020 revision. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-ah10-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of adolescents ages 15−19 who had at least one alcoholic drink at any time during the last twelve months.
unicef-ah10-adolescentHealth.Source: WHO estimates based on international surveys (WHS, STEPS, GENACIS, and ECAS) as well as national surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah11-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of adolescents ages 15−19 who had at least one alcoholic drink at any time during the last twelve months.
unicef-ah11-adolescentHealth.Source: WHO estimates based on international surveys (WHS, STEPS, GENACIS, and ECAS) as well as national surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah12-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of adolescents ages 13−15 who smoked cigarettes or used smoked or smokeless tobacco products at any time during the last one month.
unicef-ah12-adolescentHealth.Source: WHO Global Health Observatory, based on School-based surveys, other national surveys and censuses. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah13-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of adolescents ages 13−15 who smoked cigarettes or used smoked or smokeless tobacco products at any time during the last one month.
unicef-ah13-adolescentHealth.Source: WHO Global Health Observatory, based on School-based surveys, other national surveys and censuses. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah14-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of school going adolescents ages 11-17 not meeting WHO recommendations on physical activity for health, i.e. doing less than 60 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity daily.
unicef-ah14-adolescentHealth.Source: Main data sources included the Global School-based Student Health Survey (GSHS), the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), and some other national surveys; Data host: WHO Global Status Report on NCDs.  Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah15-adolescentHealth.Definition: Percentage of school going adolescents ages 11-17 not meeting WHO recommendations on physical activity for health, i.e. doing less than 60 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity daily.
unicef-ah15-adolescentHealth.Source: Main data sources included the Global School-based Student Health Survey (GSHS), the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), and some other national surveys; Data host: WHO Global Status Report on NCDs.  Last update: January 2021.

unicef-hivaidse1-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population at risk of HIV infection.

unicef-hivaidse2-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population at risk of HIV infection.

unicef-hivaidse3-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population at risk of HIV infection.

unicef-hivaidse4-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population at risk of HIV infection.

unicef-hivaidse5-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of AIDS-related deaths per 100,000 population.

unicef-hivaidse6-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of AIDS-related deaths per 100,000 population.

unicef-hivaidse7-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of AIDS-related deaths per 100,000 population.

unicef-hivaidse8-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of AIDS-related deaths per 100,000 population.

unicef-hivaidse9-hivAidsEpidemiology.Indicator: Number of children living with HIV
unicef-hivaidse9-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of children living with HIV.

unicef-hivaidse10-hivAidsEpidemiology.Indicator: Number of children living with HIV
unicef-hivaidse10-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of children living with HIV.

unicef-hivaidse11-hivAidsEpidemiology.Indicator: Number of children living with HIV
unicef-hivaidse11-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of children living with HIV.

unicef-hivaidse12-hivAidsEpidemiology.Indicator: Number of children living with HIV
unicef-hivaidse12-hivAidsEpidemiology.Definition: Estimated number of children living with HIV.

unicef-hivaidsic13-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Percent of pregnant women living with HIV receiving effective ARVs for PMTCT
unicef-hivaidsic13-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of the estimated number of pregnant women living with HIV who received effective regimens (excluding single-dose nevirapine) of antiretroviral medicines (ARVs) for prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV.
unicef-hivaidsic13-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Global AIDS Monitoring and UNAIDS 2021 estimates. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic14-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of HIV-exposed infants who received a virologic test for HIV within two months of birth.
unicef-hivaidsic14-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Global AIDS Monitoring and UNAIDS 2021 estimates. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic15-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Children living with HIV receiving ART, Children 0 - 14
unicef-hivaidsic15-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of children living with HIV who received antiretroviral therapy (ART).
unicef-hivaidsic15-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Global AIDS Monitoring and UNAIDS 2021 estimates. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic16-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Comprehensive knowledge of HIV among adolescents age 15-19
unicef-hivaidsic16-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 15-19 who correctly identify the two ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV, who know that a healthy-looking person can be HIV-positive and who reject the two most common misconceptions about HIV transmission.
unicef-hivaidsic16-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic17-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Comprehensive knowledge of HIV among adolescents age 15-19
unicef-hivaidsic17-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 15-19 who correctly identify the two ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV, who know that a healthy-looking person can be HIV-positive and who reject the two most common misconceptions about HIV transmission.
unicef-hivaidsic17-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic18-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Condom use among adolescents age 15-19 with multiple partners
unicef-hivaidsic18-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 15-19 who had more than one sexual partner in the past 12 months reporting the use of a condom during their last sexual intercourse.
unicef-hivaidsic18-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic19-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Condom use among adolescents age 15-19 with multiple partners
unicef-hivaidsic19-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 15-19 who had more than one sexual partner in the past 12 months reporting the use of a condom during their last sexual intercourse.
unicef-hivaidsic19-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic20-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Adolescents age 15-19 tested for HIV in the last 12 months and who have received results
unicef-hivaidsic20-hivAidsInterventionCo.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 15-19 who have been tested for HIV in the last 12 months and received the result of the last test.
unicef-hivaidsic20-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic21-hivAidsInterventionCo.Indicator: Adolescents age 15-19 tested for HIV in the last 12 months and who have received results

unicef-hivaidsic21-hivAidsInterventionCo.Source: Nationally representative population-based surveys, including MICS, DHS, AIS, and other household surveys 2012-2020. Last update: June 2021.

unicef-ncwh1-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: Percentage of infants weighing less than 2,500 grams at birth.
unicef-ncwh1-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: Modelled estimates from UNICEF and WHO. Last update: May 2019.

unicef-ncwh2-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Weight at birth, Unweighed at birth
unicef-ncwh2-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: Percentage of births without a birthweight in the data source; Note that (i) estimates from household surveys include live births among women age 15
unicef-ncwh2-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 49 years in the survey reference period (e.g. last 2 years) for which a birthweight was not available from an official document (e.g. health card) or could not be recalled by the respondent at the time of interview and may have been recalculated to count birthweights <250g and >5500g as missing and (ii)  estimates from administrative sources (e.g. Health Management Information Systems) were calculated using numerator data from the country administrative source and denominator data were the number of annual births according to the United Nations Population Division World Population Prospects, 2017 edition. These estimates include unweighed births and weighed births not recorded in the system.

unicef-ncwh3-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh3-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: Moderate and severe: Percentage of children aged 0
unicef-ncwh3-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 59 months who are below minus two standard deviations from median height-for-age of the WHO Child Growth Standards.

unicef-ncwh4-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh4-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: Moderate and severe: Percentage of children aged 0
unicef-ncwh4-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 59 months who are below minus two standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards.

unicef-ncwh5-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh5-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 59 months who are below minus three standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards.

unicef-ncwh6-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh6-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: Moderate and severe: Percentage of children aged 0
unicef-ncwh6-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 59 months who are above two standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards (includes severe overweight).

unicef-ncwh7-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Vitamin A supplementation, full coverage, (6-59 months of age)
unicef-ncwh7-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Definition: The estimated percentage of children aged 6
unicef-ncwh7-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 59 months reached with 2 doses of vitamin A supplements approximately 4

unicef-ncwh8-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among school-aged children, (5–19 years of age)
unicef-ncwh8-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 19 years with  BMI < -2 SD of the median according to the WHO growth reference for school-age children and adolescents.

unicef-ncwh9-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Indicator: Malnutrition among school-aged children, (5–19 years of age)
unicef-ncwh9-nutritionChildrenWomenAndHo.Source: 19 years with  BMI > 1 SD of the median according to the WHO growth reference for school-age children and adolescents.

unicef-ncwh10-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Definition: Percentage of women 18+ years of age with a body mass index (BMI) less than 18.5 kg/m2.
unicef-ncwh10-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Source: NCD Risk Factor Collaboration (NCD-RisC), based on Worldwide trends in body-mass index, underweight, overweight and obesity from 1975 to 2016: a pooled analysis of 2416 population-based measurement studies in 128.9 million children, adolescents, and adults. The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

unicef-ncwh11-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Definition: Percentage of women aged 15−49 years with a haemoglobin concentration less than 120 g/L for non-pregnant women and lactating women, and less than 110 g/L for pregnant women, adjusted for altitude and smoking.
unicef-ncwh11-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Source: Global Health Observatory, WHO. Last update: April 2021

unicef-ncwh12-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Indicator: Percentage of households consuming iodized salt
unicef-ncwh12-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Definition: Percentage of households consuming salt with any iodine (>0 ppm).
unicef-ncwh12-nutritionChildrenWomenAndH.Source: DHS, MICS, other national household surveys, and school-based surveys. Last update: August 2021

unicef-nbd1-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children born in the last 24 months who were put to the breast within one hour of birth.
unicef-nbd1-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd2-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of infants 0-5 months of age who were fed exclusively with breastmilk during the previous day.
unicef-nbd2-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd3-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of infants 6-8 months of age who were fed with solid, semi-solid or soft food during the previous day.
unicef-nbd3-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd4-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 12-23 months of age who were fed with breastmilk during the previous day.
unicef-nbd4-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd5-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 12-23 months of age who were fed with breastmilk during the previous day.
unicef-nbd5-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd6-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 12-23 months of age who were fed with breastmilk during the previous day.

unicef-nbd7-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months of age who received foods from at least 5 out of 8 defined food groups during the previous day.
unicef-nbd7-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd8-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months of age who received foods from at least 5 out of 8 defined food groups during the previous day.
unicef-nbd8-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd9-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months of age who received foods from at least 5 out of 8 defined food groups during the previous day.
unicef-nbd9-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDie.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd10-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDi.Definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months of age who received solid, semi-solid, or soft foods (but also including milk feeds for non-breastfed children) the minimum number of times or more during the previous day.
unicef-nbd10-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDi.Source: DHS, MICS and other national household surveys. Last update: September 2021.

unicef-nbd11-nutritionBreastfeedingAndDi.Definition: Percentage of children 6-23 months of age who received a minimum acceptable diet during the previous day.

unicef-e1-education.Definition: Number of children aged one year younger than the primary entry age who are not enrolled in pre-primary or primary schools, expressed as a percentage of the population of one year before the official primary entry age.
unicef-e1-education.Dimension: One year before primary entry age, male
unicef-e1-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2014

unicef-e2-education.Definition: Number of children aged one year younger than the primary entry age who are not enrolled in pre-primary or primary schools, expressed as a percentage of the population of one year before the official primary entry age.
unicef-e2-education.Dimension: One year before primary entry age, female
unicef-e2-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2015

unicef-e3-education.Definition: Number of children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in pre-primary, primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the population of official primary school age.
unicef-e3-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2016

unicef-e4-education.Definition: Number of children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in pre-primary, primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the population of official primary school age.
unicef-e4-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2017

unicef-e5-education.Definition: Number of children of lower secondary  school age who are not enrolled in primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the population of official lower secondary school age.
unicef-e5-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2018

unicef-e7-education.Definition: Number of children of upper secondary school age who are not enrolled in primary or secondary school or higher education, expressed as a percentage of the population of official upper secondary school age.

unicef-e8-education.Definition: Number of children of upper secondary school age who are not enrolled in primary or secondary school or higher education, expressed as a percentage of the population of official upper secondary school age.
unicef-e8-education.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2021

unicef-e9-education.Definition: Number of children or young people aged 3 -5 years above the intended age for the last grade of primary education who have completed the last grade of primary school.
unicef-e9-education.Source: UNICEF Global Database based on Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other national household surveys. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-e17-education.Source: United Nations Statistics Division database. Last update: June 2021.
