unicef-cp1-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 5–17 years old involved in child labour at the moment of the survey. A child is considered to be involved in child labour under the following conditions: (a) children 5–11 years old who, during the reference week, did at least one hour of economic activity and/ or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (b) children 12–14 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 14 hours of economic activity and/or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (c) children 15–17 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 43 hours of economic activity.
unicef-cp1-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp2-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 5–17 years old involved in child labour at the moment of the survey. A child is considered to be involved in child labour under the following conditions: (a) children 5–11 years old who, during the reference week, did at least one hour of economic activity and/ or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (b) children 12–14 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 14 hours of economic activity and/or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (c) children 15–17 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 43 hours of economic activity.
unicef-cp2-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp3-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 5–17 years old involved in child labour at the moment of the survey. A child is considered to be involved in child labour under the following conditions: (a) children 5–11 years old who, during the reference week, did at least one hour of economic activity and/ or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (b) children 12–14 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 14 hours of economic activity and/or more than 21 hours of unpaid household services, (c) children 15–17 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 43 hours of economic activity.
unicef-cp3-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp4-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 15 years old; percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old; percentage of men 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old.
unicef-cp4-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp5-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 15 years old; percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old; percentage of men 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old.
unicef-cp5-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp6-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 15 years old; percentage of women 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old; percentage of men 20–24 years old who were first married or in union before they were 18 years old.
unicef-cp6-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp7-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 who were registered at the moment of the survey. The numerator of this indicator includes children reported to have a birth certificate, regardless of whether or not it was seen by the interviewer, and those without a birth certificate whose mother or caregiver says the birth has been registered.
unicef-cp7-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp8-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 who were registered at the moment of the survey. The numerator of this indicator includes children reported to have a birth certificate, regardless of whether or not it was seen by the interviewer, and those without a birth certificate whose mother or caregiver says the birth has been registered.
unicef-cp8-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp9-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 who were registered at the moment of the survey. The numerator of this indicator includes children reported to have a birth certificate, regardless of whether or not it was seen by the interviewer, and those without a birth certificate whose mother or caregiver says the birth has been registered.
unicef-cp9-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp10-childProtection.Definition: Women: percentage of women 15–49 years old who have undergone FGM; (Fb) girls: percentage of girls 0–14 years old who have undergone FGM (as reported by their mothers); (Fc) want the practice to stop: percentage of women and men 15–49 years old who have heard about FGM and think the practice should stop.
unicef-cp10-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp11-childProtection.Definition: Women: percentage of women 15–49 years old who have undergone FGM; (Fb) girls: percentage of girls 0–14 years old who have undergone FGM (as reported by their mothers); (Fc) want the practice to stop: percentage of women and men 15–49 years old who have heard about FGM and think the practice should stop.
unicef-cp11-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp12-childProtection.Indicator: Want Female genital mutilation to stop
unicef-cp12-childProtection.Definition: Women: percentage of women 15–49 years old who have undergone FGM; (Fb) girls: percentage of girls 0–14 years old who have undergone FGM (as reported by their mothers); (Fc) want the practice to stop: percentage of women and men 15–49 years old who have heard about FGM and think the practice should stop.
unicef-cp12-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp13-childProtection.Indicator: Want Female genital mutilation to stop
unicef-cp13-childProtection.Definition: Women: percentage of women 15–49 years old who have undergone FGM; (Fb) girls: percentage of girls 0–14 years old who have undergone FGM (as reported by their mothers); (Fc) want the practice to stop: percentage of women and men 15–49 years old who have heard about FGM and think the practice should stop.
unicef-cp13-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp14-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of girls and boys 15–19 years old who consider a husband to be justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one of the specified reasons, i.e., if his wife burns the food, argues with him, goes out without telling him, neglects the children or refuses sexual relations.
unicef-cp14-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp15-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of girls and boys 15–19 years old who consider a husband to be justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one of the specified reasons, i.e., if his wife burns the food, argues with him, goes out without telling him, neglects the children or refuses sexual relations.
unicef-cp15-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp16-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 1–14 years old who experience any violent discipline (psychological aggression and/or physical punishment) in the past month.
unicef-cp16-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp17-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 1–14 years old who experience any violent discipline (psychological aggression and/or physical punishment) in the past month.
unicef-cp17-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp18-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of children 1–14 years old who experience any violent discipline (psychological aggression and/or physical punishment) in the past month.
unicef-cp18-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp19-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of women and men 18–29 years old who experienced sexual violence by age 18.
unicef-cp19-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-cp20-childProtection.Definition: Percentage of women and men 18–29 years old who experienced sexual violence by age 18.
unicef-cp20-childProtection.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-spe1-socialProtectionAndEquity.Indicator: Mothers with newborns receiving cash benefit
unicef-spe1-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Proportion of women giving birth covered by maternity benefits: ratio of women receiving cash maternity benefits to women giving birth in the same year (estimated based on age-specific fertility rates published in the UN’s World Population Prospects or on the number of live births corrected for the share of twin and triplet births).
unicef-spe1-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: ILO World Social Protection Report, 2017-2020. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-spe2-socialProtectionAndEquity.Indicator: Proportion of children covered by social protection
unicef-spe2-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Proportion of children covered by social protection benefits: ratio of children/households receiving child or family cash benefits to the total number of children/households with children.
unicef-spe2-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: ILO World Social Protection Report, 2017-2020. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-spe3-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of benefits going to the 1st quintile, bottom 40% and 5th quintile relative to the total benefits going to the population. social protection coverage includes: providing social assistance through cash transfers to those who need them, especially children; benefits and support for people of working age in case of maternity, disability; and pension coverage for the elderly.
unicef-spe3-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: The Atlas of Social Protection: Indicators of Resilience and Equity. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-spe4-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of benefits going to the 1st quintile, bottom 40% and 5th quintile relative to the total benefits going to the population. social protection coverage includes: providing social assistance through cash transfers to those who need them, especially children; benefits and support for people of working age in case of maternity, disability; and pension coverage for the elderly.
unicef-spe4-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: The Atlas of Social Protection: Indicators of Resilience and Equity. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-spe5-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of benefits going to the 1st quintile, bottom 40% and 5th quintile relative to the total benefits going to the population. social protection coverage includes: providing social assistance through cash transfers to those who need them, especially children; benefits and support for people of working age in case of maternity, disability; and pension coverage for the elderly.
unicef-spe5-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: The Atlas of Social Protection: Indicators of Resilience and Equity. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-spe6-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of income received by the 20 per cent of households with the highest income, by the 40 per cent of households with the lowest income and by the 20 per cent of households with the lowest income.
unicef-spe6-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-spe7-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of income received by the 20 per cent of households with the highest income, by the 40 per cent of households with the lowest income and by the 20 per cent of households with the lowest income.
unicef-spe7-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-spe8-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Percentage of income received by the 20 per cent of households with the highest income, by the 40 per cent of households with the lowest income and by the 20 per cent of households with the lowest income.
unicef-spe8-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-spe9-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income (or, in some cases, consumption expenditure) among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.
unicef-spe9-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Income Inequality Database. Last update: May 2020.

unicef-spe10-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: Palma index is defined as the ratio of the richest 10% of the population's share of gross national income divided by the poorest 40%'s share.
unicef-spe10-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Income Inequality Database. Last update: May 2020.

unicef-spe11-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: The Vast Majority Income Ratio measures the income ratio of the first 80% (vast majority) in the income ranking.
unicef-spe11-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: UNICEF estimates based on World Development Indicators. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-spe12-socialProtectionAndEquity.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current US dollars.
unicef-spe12-socialProtectionAndEquity.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-wash1-wash.Indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash1-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).
unicef-wash1-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash2-wash.Indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash2-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).
unicef-wash2-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash3-wash.Indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash3-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).

unicef-wash5-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash6-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population using an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. unicef-wash7-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash7-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash8-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash9-wash.Definition: Percentage of the population with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash9-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash10-wash.Definition: Percentage of schools with drinking water from an improved source available at the time of the survey.
unicef-wash10-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash11-wash.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash15-wash.Definition: Percentage of schools with improved sanitation facilities, which are single-sex and usable.

unicef-wash16-wash.Definition: Percentage of schools with handwashing facilities with water and soap available.

unicef-wash20-wash.Definition: Percentage of health care facilities with basic sanitation services. Improved facilities include: flush/pour flush to piped sewerage systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines; composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

unicef-a1-adolescents.Source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition.

unicef-a3-adolescents.Definition: Percentage of adolescents aged 10-19 years with BMI < −2 SD of the median according to the WHO growth reference for school-age children and adolescents.

The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

unicef-a5-adolescents.Definition: Percentage of ever-partnered girls aged 15-19 years who have experienced physical and/or sexual violence by a current or former intimate partner during the last twelve months.
unicef-a5-adolescents.Source: DHS, MICS and other national surveys. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-a6-adolescents.Definition: Percentage of students aged 13-15 years who reported being bullied on one or more days in the past 30 days.

unicef-ei1-economicIndicators.Definition: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
unicef-ei1-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-ei2-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei2-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei3-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei3-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei4-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei4-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei5-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei6-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei6-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei7-economicIndicators.Indicator: Government Expenditure, as % of government budget
unicef-ei7-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei7-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei8-economicIndicators.Indicator: Government Expenditure, as % of government budget
unicef-ei8-economicIndicators.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defence and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
unicef-ei8-economicIndicators.Source: World Development Indicators. Last update: June 2021. IMF Government Finance Statistics. Last update: April 2021.

unicef-ei9-economicIndicators.Definition: Official development assistance flows are defined as those flows to countries and territories on the DAC List of ODA Recipients and to multilateral development institutions which are: (a) provided by official agencies, including state and local governments, or by their executive agencies;  (b) each transaction of which is administered with the promotion of the economic development and welfare of developing countries as its main objective; and (c) is concessional in character.
unicef-ei9-economicIndicators.Source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-ei10-economicIndicators.Definition: Official development assistance flows are defined as those flows to countries and territories on the DAC List of ODA Recipients and to multilateral development institutions which are: (a) provided by official agencies, including state and local governments, or by their executive agencies;  (b) each transaction of which is administered with the promotion of the economic development and welfare of developing countries as its main objective; and (c) is concessional in character.
unicef-ei10-economicIndicators.Dimension: Inflow as a % of recipient GNI
unicef-ei10-economicIndicators.Source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-ei11-economicIndicators.Definition: Official development assistance flows are defined as those flows to countries and territories on the DAC List of ODA Recipients and to multilateral development institutions which are: (a) provided by official agencies, including state and local governments, or by their executive agencies;  (b) each transaction of which is administered with the promotion of the economic development and welfare of developing countries as its main objective; and (c) is concessional in character.
unicef-ei11-economicIndicators.Source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-ei12-economicIndicators.Definition: Official development assistance flows are defined as those flows to countries and territories on the DAC List of ODA Recipients and to multilateral development institutions which are: (a) provided by official agencies, including state and local governments, or by their executive agencies;  (b) each transaction of which is administered with the promotion of the economic development and welfare of developing countries as its main objective; and (c) is concessional in character.
unicef-ei12-economicIndicators.Dimension: Ouflow as a % of donor GNI
unicef-ei12-economicIndicators.Source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Last update: May 2021.

unicef-wee1-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Level of gender discrimination in social institutions defined as discrimination in the family, restricted physical integrity, restricted access to reproductive and financial resources, and restricted liberties.
unicef-wee1-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Last update: March 2019.

unicef-wee2-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Indicator: Legal frameworks on gender equality in employment
unicef-wee2-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Measures as a percentage of achivement from 0 to 100 with 100 being best practice, government efforts to put in place legal frameworks that promote, enforce and monitor gender equality in the area of employment and economic benefits.
unicef-wee2-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: UN Women, World Bank Group, OECD Development Centre. Last update: May 2021

unicef-wee3-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Whether the law provides for 14 weeks or more of paid maternity leave in accordance with the International Labour Organization standards.
unicef-wee3-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: World Bank Women Business and the Law. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-wee4-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Whether the law provides for paid paternity leave (of any length).
unicef-wee4-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: World Bank Women Business and the Law. Last update: February 2021.

unicef-wee5-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Percentage of the population aged 25 years and older that completed at least upper secondary education (ISCED 3).
unicef-wee5-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2021.

unicef-wee6-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Percentage of the population aged 25 years and older that completed at least upper secondary education (ISCED 3).
unicef-wee6-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2021.

unicef-wee7-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The proportion of a country’s working-age population that engages actively in the labour market, either by working or looking for work.
unicef-wee7-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee8-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The proportion of a country’s working-age population that engages actively in the labour market, either by working or looking for work.
unicef-wee8-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee9-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The proportion of a country’s working-age population that engages actively in the labour market, either by working or looking for work.
unicef-wee9-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee10-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee11-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee12-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The proportion of a country’s working-age population that engages actively in the labour market, either by working or looking for work.
unicef-wee12-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee13-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The percentage of persons in the labour force who are unemployed.
unicef-wee13-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee17-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee18-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The percentage of persons in the labour force who are unemployed.
unicef-wee18-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Labour Organization (ILO). Last update: June 2021.

unicef-wee19-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Proportion of individuals who own a mobile telephone.
unicef-wee19-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU). Last update: May 2021

unicef-wee20-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: Proportion of individuals who own a mobile telephone.
unicef-wee20-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU). Last update: May 2021

unicef-wee21-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The percentage of adults (ages 15+) who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months.

unicef-wee22-womenSEconomicEmpowerment.Definition: The percentage of adults (ages 15+) who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months.

unicef-m1-migration.Definition: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m1-migration.Source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m2-migration.Definition: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m2-migration.Source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m3-migration.Definition: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m3-migration.Dimension: Total as share of national population
unicef-m3-migration.Source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m4-migration.Definition: Persons who are forced to flee their home country to escape persecution or a serious threat to their life, physical integrity or freedom. Numbers in this table refer to refugees under UNHCR mandate only. Additional Palestine refugees registered with UNRWA are present in State of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan but are not listed here.
unicef-m4-migration.Source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Global Trends: Forced Displacement in 2020, UNHCR, Geneva, 2021

unicef-m10-migration.Definition: Persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border at a given point in time.
unicef-m10-migration.Source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m12-migration.Definition: Persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border at a given point in time.
unicef-m12-migration.Dimension: Share due to conflict and violence
