Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline. World Bank imports of good and services estimates are used for the denominator.

DT.ODA.ODAT.PC.ZS-officialDevelopmentAss.Definition: Net official development assistance per capita is disbursement flows (net of repayment of principal) that meet the DAC definition of ODA and are made to countries and territories on the DAC list of aid recipients; and is calculated by dividing net ODA received by the midyear population estimate.
DT.ODA.ODAT.PC.ZS-officialDevelopmentAss.Source: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline. World Bank population estimates are used for the denominator.

DT.ODA.ODAT.XP.ZS-officialDevelopmentAss.Definition: Net official development assistance is disbursement flows (net of repayment of principal) that meet the DAC definition of ODA and are made to countries and territories on the DAC list of aid recipients.
DT.ODA.ODAT.XP.ZS-officialDevelopmentAss.Source: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline. IMF central government expense estimates are used for the denominator.

DT.TDS.DECT.CD-debtService.Definition: Total debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term debt, interest paid on short-term debt, and repayments (repurchases and charges) to the IMF. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

DT.TDS.DECT.EX.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Definition: Total debt service to exports of goods, services and primary income. Total debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term debt, interest paid on short-term debt, and repayments (repurchases and charges) to the IMF.
DT.TDS.DECT.EX.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Units: % of exports of goods, services and primary income
DT.TDS.DECT.EX.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Dimension: % of exports of goods, services and primary income

DT.TDS.DECT.GN.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Definition: Total debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term debt, interest paid on short-term debt, and repayments (repurchases and charges) to the IMF.

DT.TDS.DIMF.CD-debtService.Definition: IMF repurchases are total repayments of outstanding drawings from the General Resources Account during the year specified, excluding repayments due in the reserve tranche. IMF charges cover interest payments with respect to all uses of IMF resources, excluding those resulting from drawings in the reserve tranche. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

DT.TDS.DPPF.XP.ZS-worldBankInternational.Definition: Debt service is the sum of principle repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services. This series differs from the standard debt to exports series. It covers only long-term public and publicly guaranteed debt and repayments (repurchases and charges) to the IMF. Exports of goods and services include income, but do not include workers' remittances. Data for Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) are from HIPC Initiative's Status of Implementation Report.
DT.TDS.DPPF.XP.ZS-worldBankInternational.Source: Debt service is the sum of principle repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services. This series differs from the standard debt to exports series. It covers only long-term public and publicly guaranteed debt and repayments (repurchases and charges) to the IMF. Exports of goods and services include primary income, but do not include workers' remittances.

DT.TDS.DPPG.CD-debtService.Definition: Public and publicly guaranteed debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term obligations of public debtors and long-term private obligations guaranteed by a public entity. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

DT.TDS.DPPG.GN.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Indicator: Public and publicly guaranteed debt service
DT.TDS.DPPG.GN.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Definition: Public and publicly guaranteed debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term obligations of public debtors and long-term private obligations guaranteed by a public entity.

DT.TDS.DPPG.XP.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Indicator: Public and publicly guaranteed debt service
DT.TDS.DPPG.XP.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Definition: Public and publicly guaranteed debt service is the sum of principal repayments and interest actually paid in currency, goods, or services on long-term obligations of public debtors and long-term private obligations guaranteed by a public entity. Exports refer to exports of goods, services, and income.
DT.TDS.DPPG.XP.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Units: % of exports of goods, services and primary income
DT.TDS.DPPG.XP.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Dimension: % of exports of goods, services and primary income

DT.TDS.MLAT.CD-debtService.Definition: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Debt service payments are the sum of principal repayments and interest payments actually made in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

DT.TDS.MLAT.PG.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Definition: Multilateral debt service is the repayment of principal and interest to the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral agencies.
DT.TDS.MLAT.PG.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Units: % of public and publicly guaranteed debt service
DT.TDS.MLAT.PG.ZS-debtRatiosOtherItems.Dimension: % of public and publicly guaranteed debt service

EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Indicator: Access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking
EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking is the proportion of total population primarily using clean cooking fuels and technologies for cooking. Under WHO guidelines, kerosene is excluded from clean cooking fuels.
EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from WHO Global Household Energy database.

EG.EGY.PRIM.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Indicator: Energy intensity level of primary energy
EG.EGY.PRIM.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Definition: Energy intensity level of primary energy is the ratio between energy supply and gross domestic product measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output. Lower ratio indicates that less energy is used to produce one unit of output.
EG.EGY.PRIM.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from the SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework led jointly by the World Bank, International Energy Agency, and the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program.

EG.ELC.ACCS.RU.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Access to electricity, rural is the percentage of rural population with access to electricity.
EG.ELC.ACCS.RU.ZS-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

EG.ELC.ACCS.UR.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Access to electricity, urban is the percentage of urban population with access to electricity.
EG.ELC.ACCS.UR.ZS-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.
EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

EG.ELC.COAL.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Coal refers to all coal and brown coal, both primary (including hard coal and lignite-brown coal) and derived fuels (including patent fuel, coke oven coke, gas coke, coke oven gas, and blast furnace gas). Peat is also included in this category.

EG.ELC.FOSL.ZS-energyProductionUse.Indicator: Electricity production from oil, gas and coal sources
EG.ELC.FOSL.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Oil refers to crude oil and petroleum products. Gas refers to natural gas but excludes natural gas liquids. Coal refers to all coal and brown coal, both primary (including hard coal and lignite-brown coal) and derived fuels (including patent fuel, coke oven coke, gas coke, coke oven gas, and blast furnace gas). Peat is also included in this category.

EG.ELC.HYRO.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Hydropower refers to electricity produced by hydroelectric power plants.

EG.ELC.LOSS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Indicator: Electric power transmission and distribution losses
EG.ELC.LOSS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Electric power transmission and distribution losses include losses in transmission between sources of supply and points of distribution and in the distribution to consumers, including pilferage.

EG.ELC.NGAS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Indicator: Electricity production from natural gas sources
EG.ELC.NGAS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Gas refers to natural gas but excludes natural gas liquids.

EG.ELC.NUCL.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Nuclear power refers to electricity produced by nuclear power plants.

EG.ELC.PETR.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Sources of electricity refer to the inputs used to generate electricity. Oil refers to crude oil and petroleum products.

EG.ELC.RNEW.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Renewable electricity is the share of electrity generated by renewable power plants in total electricity generated by all types of plants.

EG.ELC.RNWX.KH-energyProductionUse.Definition: Electricity production from renewable sources, excluding hydroelectric, includes geothermal, solar, tides, wind, biomass, and biofuels.

EG.ELC.RNWX.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Electricity production from renewable sources, excluding hydroelectric, includes geothermal, solar, tides, wind, biomass, and biofuels.

EG.FEC.RNEW.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Renewable energy consumption is the share of renewables energy in total final energy consumption.
EG.FEC.RNEW.ZS-energyProductionUse.Source: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from the SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework led jointly by the World Bank, International Energy Agency, and the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program.

EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP-energyProductionUse.Indicator: GDP per unit of energy use
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP-energyProductionUse.Definition: GDP per unit of energy use is the PPP GDP per kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to current international dollars using purchasing power parity rates based on the 2017 ICP round. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP-energyProductionUse.Units: PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP-energyProductionUse.Dimension: PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent

EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Indicator: GDP per unit of energy use
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Definition: GDP per unit of energy use is the PPP GDP per kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to 2017 constant international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Units: constant 2017 PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent
EG.GDP.PUSE.KO.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Dimension: constant 2017 PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent

EG.IMP.CONS.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Net energy imports are estimated as energy use less production, both measured in oil equivalents. A negative value indicates that the country is a net exporter. Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport.

EG.USE.COMM.CL.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Clean energy is noncarbohydrate energy that does not produce carbon dioxide when generated. It includes hydropower and nuclear, geothermal, and solar power, among others.

EG.USE.COMM.FO.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Fossil fuel comprises coal, oil, petroleum, and natural gas products.

EG.USE.COMM.GD.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Definition: Energy use per PPP GDP is the kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use per constant PPP GDP. Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to 2017 constant international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
EG.USE.COMM.GD.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Units: kg of oil equivalent) per $1,000 GDP (constant 2017 PPP
EG.USE.COMM.GD.PP.KD-energyProductionUse.Dimension: kg of oil equivalent) per $1,000 GDP (constant 2017 PPP

EG.USE.CRNW.ZS-energyProductionUse.Definition: Combustible renewables and waste comprise solid biomass, liquid biomass, biogas, industrial waste, and municipal waste, measured as a percentage of total energy use.

EG.USE.ELEC.KH.PC-energyProductionUse.Definition: Electric power consumption measures the production of power plants and combined heat and power plants less transmission, distribution, and transformation losses and own use by heat and power plants.

EG.USE.PCAP.KG.OE-energyProductionUse.Definition: Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport.
EG.USE.PCAP.KG.OE-energyProductionUse.Units: kg of oil equivalent per capita
EG.USE.PCAP.KG.OE-energyProductionUse.Dimension: kg of oil equivalent per capita

EN.ATM.CO2E.EG.ZS-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from solid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of coal as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.EG.ZS-emissions.Units: kg per kg of oil equivalent energy use
EN.ATM.CO2E.EG.ZS-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.KT-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from gaseous fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.KT-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from liquid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of natural gas as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.KT-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from gaseous fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.ZS-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from liquid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of natural gas as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.GF.ZS-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.KD.GD-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
EN.ATM.CO2E.KD.GD-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.KD for the denominator's source.

EN.ATM.CO2E.KT-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
EN.ATM.CO2E.KT-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
EN.ATM.CO2E.KT-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.KT-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from liquid fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.KT-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from liquid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of petroleum-derived fuels as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.KT-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from liquid fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.ZS-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from liquid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of petroleum-derived fuels as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.LF.ZS-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.PC-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
EN.ATM.CO2E.PC-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See SP.POP.TOTL for the denominator's source.

EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD for the denominator's source.

EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.KD-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.KD-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD for the denominator's source.

EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.KT-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from solid fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.KT-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from solid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of coal as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.KT-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from solid fuel consumption
EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.ZS-emissions.Definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from solid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of coal as an energy source.
EN.ATM.CO2E.SF.ZS-emissions.Source: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

EN.ATM.GHGO.KT.CE-emissions.Indicator: Other greenhouse gas emissions, HFC, PFC and SF6
EN.ATM.GHGO.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Other greenhouse gas emissions are by-product emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride.
EN.ATM.GHGO.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.GHGO.KT.CE-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.GHGO.ZG-emissions.Definition: Other greenhouse gas emissions are by-product emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each year of data shows the percentage change to that year from 1990.
EN.ATM.GHGO.ZG-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.GHGT.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Total greenhouse gas emissions in kt of CO2 equivalent are composed of CO2 totals excluding short-cycle biomass burning (such as agricultural waste burning and savanna burning) but including other biomass burning (such as forest fires, post-burn decay, peat fires and decay of drained peatlands), all anthropogenic CH4 sources, N2O sources and F-gases (HFCs, PFCs and SF6).
EN.ATM.GHGT.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
EN.ATM.GHGT.KT.CE-emissions.Dimension: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
EN.ATM.GHGT.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.GHGT.ZG-emissions.Definition: Total greenhouse gas emissions are composed of CO2 totals excluding short-cycle biomass burning (such as agricultural waste burning and savanna burning) but including other biomass burning (such as forest fires, post-burn decay, peat fires and decay of drained peatlands), all anthropogenic CH4 sources, N2O sources and F-gases (HFCs, PFCs and SF6). Each year of data shows the percentage change to that year from 1990.
EN.ATM.GHGT.ZG-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.HFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Hydrofluorocarbons, used as a replacement for chlorofluorocarbons, are used mainly in refrigeration and semiconductor manufacturing.
EN.ATM.HFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.HFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/

EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Agricultural methane emissions are emissions from animals, animal waste, rice production, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Dimension: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.METH.AG.ZS-emissions.Definition: Agricultural methane emissions are emissions from animals, animal waste, rice production, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
EN.ATM.METH.AG.ZS-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.METH.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Methane emissions from energy processes are emissions from the production, handling, transmission, and combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels.
EN.ATM.METH.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.METH.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.METH.EG.ZS-emissions.Definition: Methane emissions from energy processes are emissions from the production, handling, transmission, and combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels.
EN.ATM.METH.EG.ZS-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.METH.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Methane emissions are those stemming from human activities such as agriculture and from industrial methane production.
EN.ATM.METH.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
EN.ATM.METH.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.METH.ZG-emissions.Definition: Methane emissions are those stemming from human activities such as agriculture and from industrial methane production. Each year of data shows the percentage change to that year from 1990.
EN.ATM.METH.ZG-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced through fertilizer use (synthetic and animal manure), animal waste management, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Dimension: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.ZS-emissions.Definition: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced through fertilizer use (synthetic and animal manure), animal waste management, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.ZS-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Indicator: Nitrous oxide emissions in energy sector
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Nitrous oxide emissions from energy processes are emissions produced by the combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels.
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Dimension: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.ZS-emissions.Indicator: Nitrous oxide emissions in energy sector
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.ZS-emissions.Definition: Nitrous oxide emissions from energy processes are emissions produced by the combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels.
EN.ATM.NOXE.EG.ZS-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.NOXE.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Nitrous oxide emissions are emissions from agricultural biomass burning, industrial activities, and livestock management.
EN.ATM.NOXE.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
EN.ATM.NOXE.KT.CE-emissions.Source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

EN.ATM.NOXE.ZG-emissions.Definition: Nitrous oxide emissions are emissions from agricultural biomass burning, industrial activities, and livestock management. Each year of data shows the percentage change to that year from 1990.
EN.ATM.NOXE.ZG-emissions.Source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

EN.ATM.PFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Perfluorocarbons, used as a replacement for chlorofluorocarbons in manufacturing semiconductors, are a byproduct of aluminum smelting and uranium enrichment.
EN.ATM.PFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.PFCG.KT.CE-emissions.Source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/

EN.ATM.PM25.MC.M3-emissions.Definition: Population-weighted exposure to ambient PM2.5 pollution is defined as the average level of exposure of a nation's population to concentrations of suspended particles measuring less than 2.5 microns in aerodynamic diameter, which are capable of penetrating deep into the respiratory tract and causing severe health damage. Exposure is calculated by weighting mean annual concentrations of PM2.5 by population in both urban and rural areas.
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.M3-emissions.Source: Brauer, M. et al. 2017, for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.

EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T1.ZS-emissions.Definition: Percent of population exposed to ambient concentrations of PM2.5 that exceed the World Health Organization (WHO) Interim Target 1 (IT-1) is defined as the portion of a country’s population living in places where mean annual concentrations of PM2.5 are greater than 35 micrograms per cubic meter. The Air Quality Guideline (AQG) of 10 micrograms per cubic meter is recommended by the WHO as the lower end of the range of concentrations over which adverse health effects due to PM2.5 exposure have been observed.
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T1.ZS-emissions.Dimension: population exposed to levels exceeding WHO Interim Target-1 value
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T1.ZS-emissions.Source: Brauer, M. et al. 2017, for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.

EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T2.ZS-emissions.Definition: Percent of population exposed to ambient concentrations of PM2.5 that exceed the World Health Organization (WHO) Interim Target 2 (IT-2) is defined as the portion of a country’s population living in places where mean annual concentrations of PM2.5 are greater than 25 micrograms per cubic meter. The Air Quality Guideline (AQG) of 10 micrograms per cubic meter is recommended by the WHO as the lower end of the range of concentrations over which adverse health effects due to PM2.5 exposure have been observed.
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T2.ZS-emissions.Dimension: population exposed to levels exceeding WHO Interim Target-2 value
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T2.ZS-emissions.Source: Brauer, M. et al. 2017, for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.

EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T3.ZS-emissions.Definition: Percent of population exposed to ambient concentrations of PM2.5 that exceed the World Health Organization (WHO) Interim Target 3 (IT-3) is defined as the portion of a country’s population living in places where mean annual concentrations of PM2.5 are greater than 15 micrograms per cubic meter. The Air Quality Guideline (AQG) of 10 micrograms per cubic meter is recommended by the WHO as the lower end of the range of concentrations over which adverse health effects due to PM2.5 exposure have been observed.
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T3.ZS-emissions.Dimension: population exposed to levels exceeding WHO Interim Target-3 value
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.T3.ZS-emissions.Source: Brauer, M. et al. 2017, for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.

EN.ATM.PM25.MC.ZS-emissions.Definition: Percent of population exposed to ambient concentrations of PM2.5 that exceed the WHO guideline value is defined as the portion of a country’s population living in places where mean annual concentrations of PM2.5 are greater than 10 micrograms per cubic meter, the guideline value recommended by the World Health Organization as the lower end of the range of concentrations over which adverse health effects due to PM2.5 exposure have been observed.
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.ZS-emissions.Dimension: population exposed to levels exceeding WHO guideline value
EN.ATM.PM25.MC.ZS-emissions.Source: Brauer, M. et al. 2017, for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017.

EN.ATM.SF6G.KT.CE-emissions.Definition: Sulfur hexafluoride is used largely to insulate high-voltage electric power equipment.
EN.ATM.SF6G.KT.CE-emissions.Units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
EN.ATM.SF6G.KT.CE-emissions.Source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/

EN.BIR.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Birds are listed for countries included within their breeding or wintering ranges. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
EN.BIR.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

EN.CLC.DRSK.XQ-landUse.Definition: Disaster risk reduction progress score is an average of self-assessment scores, ranging from 1 to 5, submitted by countries under Priority 1 of the Hyogo Framework National Progress Reports. The Hyogo Framework is a global blueprint for disaster risk reduction efforts that was adopted by 168 countries in 2005. Assessments of "Priority 1" include four indicators that reflect the degree to which countries have prioritized disaster risk reduction and the strengthening of relevant institutions.

EN.CLC.GHGR.MT.CE-emissions.Definition: GHG net emissions/removals by LUCF refers to changes in atmospheric levels of all greenhouse gases attributable to forest and land-use change activities, including but not limited to (1) emissions and removals of CO2 from decreases or increases in biomass stocks due to forest management, logging, fuelwood collection, etc.; (2) conversion of existing forests and natural grasslands to other land uses; (3) removal of CO2 from the abandonment of formerly managed lands (e.g. croplands and pastures); and (4) emissions and removals of CO2 in soil associated with land-use change and management. For Annex-I countries under the UNFCCC, these data are drawn from the annual GHG inventories submitted to the UNFCCC by each country; for non-Annex-I countries, data are drawn from the most recently submitted National Communication where available. Because of differences in reporting years and methodologies, these data are not generally considered comparable across countries. Data are in million metric tons.
EN.CLC.GHGR.MT.CE-emissions.Source: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

EN.CLC.MDAT.ZS-landUse.Definition: Droughts, floods and extreme temperatures is the annual average percentage of the population that is affected by natural disasters classified as either droughts, floods, or extreme temperature events. A drought is an extended period of time characterized by a deficiency in a region's water supply that is the result of constantly below average precipitation. A drought can lead to losses to agriculture, affect inland navigation and hydropower plants, and cause a lack of drinking water and famine. A flood is a significant rise of water level in a stream, lake, reservoir or coastal region. Extreme temperature events are either cold waves or heat waves. A cold wave can be both a prolonged period of excessively cold weather and the sudden invasion of very cold air over a large area. Along with frost it can cause damage to agriculture, infrastructure, and property. A heat wave is a prolonged period of excessively hot and sometimes also humid weather relative to normal climate patterns of a certain region. Population affected is the number of people injured, left homeless or requiring immediate assistance during a period of emergency resulting from a natural disaster; it can also include displaced or evacuated people. Average percentage of population affected is calculated by dividing the sum of total affected for the period stated by the sum of the annual population figures for the period stated.
EN.CLC.MDAT.ZS-landUse.Source: EM-DAT: The OFDA/CRED International Disaster Database: www.emdat.be, Université Catholique de Louvain, Brussels (Belgium), World Bank.

EN.CO2.BLDG.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from residential buildings and commercial and public services
EN.CO2.BLDG.ZS-emissions.Definition: CO2 emissions from residential buildings and commercial and public services contains all emissions from fuel combustion in households. This corresponds to IPCC Source/Sink Category 1 A 4 b. Commercial and public services includes emissions from all activities of ISIC Divisions 41, 50-52, 55, 63-67, 70-75, 80, 85, 90-93 and 99.

EN.CO2.ETOT.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from electricity and heat production, total
EN.CO2.ETOT.ZS-emissions.Definition: CO2 emissions from electricity and heat production is the sum of three IEA categories of CO2 emissions: (1) Main Activity Producer Electricity and Heat which contains the sum of emissions from main activity producer electricity generation, combined heat and power generation and heat plants. Main activity producers (formerly known as public utilities) are defined as those undertakings whose primary activity is to supply the public. They may be publicly or privately owned. This corresponds to IPCC Source/Sink Category 1 A 1 a. For the CO2 emissions from fuel combustion (summary) file, emissions from own on-site use of fuel in power plants (EPOWERPLT) are also included. (2) Unallocated Autoproducers which contains the emissions from the generation of electricity and/or heat by autoproducers. Autoproducers are defined as undertakings that generate electricity and/or heat, wholly or partly for their own use as an activity which supports their primary activity. They may be privately or publicly owned. In the 1996 IPCC Guidelines, these emissions would normally be distributed between industry, transport and "other" sectors. (3) Other Energy Industries contains emissions from fuel combusted in petroleum refineries, for the manufacture of solid fuels, coal mining, oil and gas extraction and other energy-producing industries. This corresponds to the IPCC Source/Sink Categories 1 A 1 b and 1 A 1 c. According to the 1996 IPCC Guidelines, emissions from coke inputs to blast furnaces can either be counted here or in the Industrial Processes source/sink category. Within detailed sectoral calculations, certain non-energy processes can be distinguished. In the reduction of iron in a blast furnace through the combustion of coke, the primary purpose of the coke oxidation is to produce pig iron and the emissions can be considered as an industrial process. Care must be taken not to double count these emissions in both Energy and Industrial Processes. In the IEA estimations, these emissions have been included in this category.

EN.CO2.MANF.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from manufacturing industries and construction
EN.CO2.MANF.ZS-emissions.Definition: CO2 emissions from manufacturing industries and construction contains the emissions from combustion of fuels in industry. The IPCC Source/Sink Category 1 A 2 includes these emissions. However, in the 1996 IPCC Guidelines, the IPCC category also includes emissions from industry autoproducers that generate electricity and/or heat. The IEA data are not collected in a way that allows the energy consumption to be split by specific end-use and therefore, autoproducers are shown as a separate item (Unallocated Autoproducers). Manufacturing industries and construction also includes emissions from coke inputs into blast furnaces, which may be reported either in the transformation sector, the industry sector or the separate IPCC Source/Sink Category 2, Industrial Processes.

EN.CO2.OTHX.ZS-emissions.Indicator: CO2 emissions from other sectors, excluding residential buildings and commercial and public services
EN.CO2.OTHX.ZS-emissions.Definition: CO2 emissions from other sectors, less residential buildings and commercial and public services, contains the emissions from commercial/institutional activities, residential, agriculture/forestry, fishing and other emissions not specified elsewhere that are included in the IPCC Source/Sink Categories 1 A 4 and 1 A 5. In the 1996 IPCC Guidelines, the category also includes emissions from autoproducers in the commercial/residential/agricultural sectors that generate electricity and/or heat. The IEA data are not collected in a way that allows the energy consumption to be split by specific end-use and therefore, autoproducers are shown as a separate item (Unallocated Autoproducers).

EN.CO2.TRAN.ZS-emissions.Definition: CO2 emissions from transport contains emissions from the combustion of fuel for all transport activity, regardless of the sector, except for international marine bunkers and international aviation. This includes domestic aviation, domestic navigation, road, rail and pipeline transport, and corresponds to IPCC Source/Sink Category 1 A 3. In addition, the IEA data are not collected in a way that allows the autoproducer consumption to be split by specific end-use and therefore, autoproducers are shown as a separate item (Unallocated Autoproducers).

EN.FSH.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Fish species are based on Froese, R. and Pauly, D. (eds). 2008. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
EN.FSH.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: Froese, R. and Pauly, D. (eds). 2008. FishBase database, www.fishbase.org.

EN.HPT.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Higher plants are native vascular plant species. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
EN.HPT.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

EN.MAM.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Mammal species are mammals excluding whales and porpoises. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
EN.MAM.THRD.NO-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

EN.POP.DNST-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population density is midyear population divided by land area in square kilometers. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin. Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.
EN.POP.DNST-densityUrbanization.Units: people per sq. km of land area
EN.POP.DNST-densityUrbanization.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization and World Bank population estimates.

EN.POP.EL5M.RU.ZS-landUse.Indicator: Rural population living in areas where elevation is below 5 meters
EN.POP.EL5M.RU.ZS-landUse.Definition: Rural population below 5m is the percentage of the total population, living in areas where the elevation is 5 meters or less.
EN.POP.EL5M.RU.ZS-landUse.Source: Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN)/Columbia University. 2013. Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates Version 2. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lecz-urban-rural-population-land-area-estimates-v2.

EN.POP.EL5M.UR.ZS-landUse.Indicator: Urban population living in areas where elevation is below 5 meters
EN.POP.EL5M.UR.ZS-landUse.Definition: Urban population below 5m is the percentage of the total population, living in areas where the elevation is 5 meters or less.
EN.POP.EL5M.UR.ZS-landUse.Source: Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN)/Columbia University. 2013. Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates Version 2. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lecz-urban-rural-population-land-area-estimates-v2.

EN.POP.EL5M.ZS-landUse.Indicator: Population living in areas where elevation is below 5 meters
EN.POP.EL5M.ZS-landUse.Definition: Population below 5m is the percentage of the total population living in areas where the elevation is 5 meters or less.
EN.POP.EL5M.ZS-landUse.Source: Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN)/Columbia University. 2013. Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates Version 2. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lecz-urban-rural-population-land-area-estimates-v2.

EN.POP.SLUM.UR.ZS-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population living in slums is the proportion of the urban population living in slum households. A slum household is defined as a group of individuals living under the same roof lacking one or more of the following conditions: access to improved water, access to improved sanitation, sufficient living area, housing durability, and security of tenure, as adopted in the Millennium Development Goal Target 7.D. The successor, the Sustainable Development Goal 11.1.1, considers inadequate housing (housing affordability) to complement the above definition of slums/informal settlements.

EN.URB.LCTY-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population in largest city is the urban population living in the country's largest metropolitan area.

EN.URB.LCTY.UR.ZS-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population in largest city is the percentage of a country's urban population living in that country's largest metropolitan area.

EN.URB.MCTY-densityUrbanization.Indicator: Population in urban agglomerations of more than 1 million
EN.URB.MCTY-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population in urban agglomerations of more than one million is the country's population living in metropolitan areas that in 2018 had a population of more than one million people.

EN.URB.MCTY.TL.ZS-densityUrbanization.Indicator: Population in urban agglomerations of more than 1 million
EN.URB.MCTY.TL.ZS-densityUrbanization.Definition: Population in urban agglomerations of more than one million is the percentage of a country's population living in metropolitan areas that in 2018 had a population of more than one million people.

EP.PMP.DESL.CD-transportation.Definition: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of diesel fuel. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.

EP.PMP.SGAS.CD-transportation.Definition: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of gasoline. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.

ER.FSH.AQUA.MT-agriculturalProduction.Definition: Aquaculture is understood to mean the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Aquaculture production specifically refers to output from aquaculture activities, which are designated for final harvest for consumption.

ER.FSH.CAPT.MT-agriculturalProduction.Definition: Capture fisheries production measures the volume of fish catches landed by a country for all commercial, industrial, recreational and subsistence purposes.

ER.FSH.PROD.MT-agriculturalProduction.Definition: Total fisheries production measures the volume of aquatic species caught by a country for all commercial, industrial, recreational and subsistence purposes. The harvest from mariculture, aquaculture and other kinds of fish farming is also included.

ER.GDP.FWTL.M3.KD-freshwater.Definition: Water productivity is calculated as GDP in constant prices divided by annual total water withdrawal.
ER.GDP.FWTL.M3.KD-freshwater.Units: constant 2010 US$ GDP per cubic meter of total freshwater withdrawal
ER.GDP.FWTL.M3.KD-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS-freshwater.Definition: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS-freshwater.Definition: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS-freshwater.Definition: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for industry are total withdrawals for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.FWST.ZS-freshwater.Indicator: Level of water stress: freshwater withdrawal as a proportion of available freshwater resources
ER.H2O.FWST.ZS-freshwater.Definition: The level of water stress: freshwater withdrawal as a proportion of available freshwater resources is the ratio between total freshwater withdrawn by all major sectors and total renewable freshwater resources, after taking into account environmental water requirements. Main sectors, as defined by ISIC standards, include agriculture; forestry and fishing; manufacturing; electricity industry; and services. This indicator is also known as water withdrawal intensity.
ER.H2O.FWST.ZS-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.FWTL.K3-freshwater.Definition: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
ER.H2O.FWTL.K3-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.FWTL.ZS-freshwater.Definition: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
ER.H2O.FWTL.ZS-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.INTR.K3-freshwater.Definition: Renewable internal freshwater resources flows refer to internal renewable resources (internal river flows and groundwater from rainfall) in the country.
ER.H2O.INTR.K3-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.H2O.INTR.PC-freshwater.Indicator: Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita
ER.H2O.INTR.PC-freshwater.Definition: Renewable internal freshwater resources flows refer to internal renewable resources (internal river flows and groundwater from rainfall) in the country. Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita are calculated using the World Bank's population estimates.
ER.H2O.INTR.PC-freshwater.Source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

ER.LND.PTLD.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Terrestrial protected areas are totally or partially protected areas of at least 1,000 hectares that are designated by national authorities as scientific reserves with limited public access, national parks, natural monuments, nature reserves or wildlife sanctuaries, protected landscapes, and areas managed mainly for sustainable use. Marine areas, unclassified areas, littoral (intertidal) areas, and sites protected under local or provincial law are excluded.
ER.LND.PTLD.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) where the compilation and management is carried out by United Nations Environment World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) in collaboration with governments, non-governmental organizations, academia and industry. The data is available online through the Protected Planet website (https://www.protectedplanet.net/).

ER.MRN.PTMR.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Marine protected areas are areas of intertidal or subtidal terrain--and overlying water and associated flora and fauna and historical and cultural features--that have been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment.
ER.MRN.PTMR.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) where the compilation and management is carried out by United Nations Environment World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) in collaboration with governments, non-governmental organizations, academia and industry. The data is available online through the Protected Planet website (https://www.protectedplanet.net/).

ER.PTD.TOTL.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Definition: Terrestrial protected areas are totally or partially protected areas of at least 1,000 hectares that are designated by national authorities as scientific reserves with limited public access, national parks, natural monuments, nature reserves or wildlife sanctuaries, protected landscapes, and areas managed mainly for sustainable use. Marine protected areas are areas of intertidal or subtidal terrain--and overlying water and associated flora and fauna and historical and cultural features--that have been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment. Sites protected under local or provincial law are excluded.
ER.PTD.TOTL.ZS-biodiversityProtectedArea.Source: World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) where the compilation and management is carried out by United Nations Environment World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) in collaboration with governments, non-governmental organizations, academia and industry. The data is available online through the Protected Planet website (https://www.protectedplanet.net/).

FB.AST.NPER.ZS-assets.Indicator: Bank nonperforming loans to total gross loans
FB.AST.NPER.ZS-assets.Definition: Bank nonperforming loans to total gross loans are the value of nonperforming loans divided by the total value of the loan portfolio (including nonperforming loans before the deduction of specific loan-loss provisions). The loan amount recorded as nonperforming should be the gross value of the loan as recorded on the balance sheet, not just the amount that is overdue.
FB.AST.NPER.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Soundness Indicators.

FB.ATM.TOTL.P5-access.Definition: Automated teller machines are computerized telecommunications devices that provide clients of a financial institution with access to financial transactions in a public place.
FB.ATM.TOTL.P5-access.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

FB.BNK.CAPA.ZS-assets.Definition: Bank capital to assets is the ratio of bank capital and reserves to total assets. Capital and reserves include funds contributed by owners, retained earnings, general and special reserves, provisions, and valuation adjustments. Capital includes tier 1 capital (paid-up shares and common stock), which is a common feature in all countries' banking systems, and total regulatory capital, which includes several specified types of subordinated debt instruments that need not be repaid if the funds are required to maintain minimum capital levels (these comprise tier 2 and tier 3 capital). Total assets include all nonfinancial and financial assets.
FB.BNK.CAPA.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Soundness Indicators.

FB.CBK.BRCH.P5-access.Definition: Commercial bank branches are retail locations of resident commercial banks and other resident banks that function as commercial banks that provide financial services to customers and are physically separated from the main office but not organized as legally separated subsidiaries.
FB.CBK.BRCH.P5-access.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

FB.CBK.BRWR.P3-access.Definition: Borrowers from commercial banks are the reported number of resident customers that are nonfinancial corporations (public and private) and households who obtained loans from commercial banks and other banks functioning as commercial banks. For many countries data cover the total number of loan accounts due to lack of information on loan account holders.
FB.CBK.BRWR.P3-access.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

FB.CBK.DPTR.P3-access.Definition: Depositors with commercial banks are the reported number of deposit account holders at commercial banks and other resident banks functioning as commercial banks that are resident nonfinancial corporations (public and private) and households. For many countries data cover the total number of deposit accounts due to lack of information on account holders. The major types of deposits are checking accounts, savings accounts, and time deposits.
FB.CBK.DPTR.P3-access.Source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

FD.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Indicator: Domestic credit to private sector by banks
FD.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Domestic credit to private sector by banks refers to financial resources provided to the private sector by other depository corporations (deposit taking corporations except central banks), such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises.
FD.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS-assets.Indicator: Bank liquid reserves to bank assets ratio
FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS-assets.Definition: Ratio of bank liquid reserves to bank assets is the ratio of domestic currency holdings and deposits with the monetary authorities to claims on other governments, nonfinancial public enterprises, the private sector, and other banking institutions.
FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FI.RES.TOTL.CD-reservesOtherItems.Definition: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
FI.RES.TOTL.CD-reservesOtherItems.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FI.RES.TOTL.DT.ZS-reservesOtherItems.Definition: International reserves to total external debt stocks.

FI.RES.TOTL.MO-reservesOtherItems.Indicator: Total reserves in months of imports
FI.RES.TOTL.MO-reservesOtherItems.Definition: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices. This item shows reserves expressed in terms of the number of months of imports of goods and services they could pay for [Reserves/(Imports/12)].
FI.RES.TOTL.MO-reservesOtherItems.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FI.RES.XGLD.CD-reservesOtherItems.Definition: Total reserves minus gold comprise special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. Gold holdings are excluded. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
FI.RES.XGLD.CD-reservesOtherItems.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.AST.CGOV.ZG.M3-assets.Definition: Claims on central government (IFS line 32AN..ZK) include loans to central government institutions net of deposits.
FM.AST.CGOV.ZG.M3-assets.Units: annual growth as % of broad money
FM.AST.CGOV.ZG.M3-assets.Dimension: annual growth as % of broad money
FM.AST.CGOV.ZG.M3-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.AST.DOMO.ZG.M3-assets.Indicator: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy
FM.AST.DOMO.ZG.M3-assets.Definition: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 32S..ZK) include gross credit from the financial system to households, nonprofit institutions serving households, nonfinancial corporations, state and local governments, and social security funds.
FM.AST.DOMO.ZG.M3-assets.Units: annual growth as % of broad money
FM.AST.DOMO.ZG.M3-assets.Dimension: annual growth as % of broad money
FM.AST.DOMO.ZG.M3-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.AST.DOMS.CN-assets.Definition: Net domestic credit is the sum of net claims on the central government and claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 32). Data are in current local currency.
FM.AST.DOMS.CN-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.AST.NFRG.CN-assets.Definition: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks, less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current local currency.
FM.AST.NFRG.CN-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Indicator: Monetary Sector credit to private sector
FM.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises.
FM.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FM.AST.PRVT.ZG.M3-assets.Definition: Claims on private sector (IFS line 32D..ZK or 32D..ZF) include gross credit from the financial system to individuals, enterprises, nonfinancial public entities not included under net domestic credit, and financial institutions not included elsewhere.
FM.AST.PRVT.ZG.M3-assets.Units: annual growth as % of broad money
FM.AST.PRVT.ZG.M3-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.LBL.BMNY.CN-monetaryHoldingsLiabiliti.Definition: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
FM.LBL.BMNY.CN-monetaryHoldingsLiabiliti.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.LBL.BMNY.GD.ZS-monetaryHoldingsLiabil.Definition: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
FM.LBL.BMNY.GD.ZS-monetaryHoldingsLiabil.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FM.LBL.BMNY.IR.ZS-monetaryHoldingsLiabil.Indicator: Broad money to total reserves ratio
FM.LBL.BMNY.IR.ZS-monetaryHoldingsLiabil.Definition: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
FM.LBL.BMNY.IR.ZS-monetaryHoldingsLiabil.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FM.LBL.BMNY.ZG-monetaryHoldingsLiabiliti.Definition: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
FM.LBL.BMNY.ZG-monetaryHoldingsLiabiliti.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FP.CPI.TOTL-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Consumer price index reflects changes in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used. Data are period averages.
FP.CPI.TOTL-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FP.CPI.TOTL.ZG-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Inflation as measured by the consumer price index reflects the annual percentage change in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
FP.CPI.TOTL.ZG-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FP.WPI.TOTL-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Wholesale price index refers to a mix of agricultural and industrial goods at various stages of production and distribution, including import duties. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
FP.WPI.TOTL-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FR.INR.DPST-interestRates.Definition: Deposit interest rate is the rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
FR.INR.DPST-interestRates.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FR.INR.LEND-interestRates.Definition: Lending rate is the bank rate that usually meets the short- and medium-term financing needs of the private sector. This rate is normally differentiated according to creditworthiness of borrowers and objectives of financing. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
FR.INR.LEND-interestRates.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FR.INR.LNDP-interestRates.Definition: Interest rate spread is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to private sector customers minus the interest rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
FR.INR.LNDP-interestRates.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

FR.INR.RINR-interestRates.Definition: Real interest rate is the lending interest rate adjusted for inflation as measured by the GDP deflator. The terms and conditions attached to lending rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
FR.INR.RINR-interestRates.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files using World Bank data on the GDP deflator.

FR.INR.RISK-interestRates.Definition: Risk premium on lending is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to private sector customers minus the "risk free" treasury bill interest rate at which short-term government securities are issued or traded in the market. In some countries this spread may be negative, indicating that the market considers its best corporate clients to be lower risk than the government. The terms and conditions attached to lending rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
FR.INR.RISK-interestRates.Units: lending rate minus treasury bill rate, %
FR.INR.RISK-interestRates.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics database.

FS.AST.CGOV.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Claims on central government (IFS line 52AN or 32AN) include loans to central government institutions net of deposits.
FS.AST.CGOV.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FS.AST.DOMO.GD.ZS-assets.Indicator: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy
FS.AST.DOMO.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 52S or 32S) include gross credit from the financial system to households, nonprofit institutions serving households, nonfinancial corporations, state and local governments, and social security funds.
FS.AST.DOMO.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FS.AST.DOMS.GD.ZS-assets.Indicator: Domestic credit provided by financial sector
FS.AST.DOMS.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Domestic credit provided by the financial sector includes all credit to various sectors on a gross basis, with the exception of credit to the central government, which is net. The financial sector includes monetary authorities and deposit money banks, as well as other financial corporations where data are available (including corporations that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other financial corporations are finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds, and foreign exchange companies.
FS.AST.DOMS.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FS.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Definition: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector by financial corporations, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises. The financial corporations include monetary authorities and deposit money banks, as well as other financial corporations where data are available (including corporations that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other financial corporations are finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds, and foreign exchange companies.
FS.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS-assets.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

FX.OWN.TOTL.40.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.40.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (poorest 40%, share of population ages 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.40.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.60.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
