FX.OWN.TOTL.60.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (richest 60%, share of population ages 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.60.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.FE.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.FE.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (female, % age 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.FE.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.MA.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.MA.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (male, % age 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.MA.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.OL.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.OL.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (older adults, % of population ages 25+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.OL.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.PL.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.PL.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (primary education or less, % of population ages 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.PL.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.SO.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.SO.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (secondary education or more, % of population ages 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.SO.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.YG.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.YG.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (young adults, % of population ages 15-24).
FX.OWN.TOTL.YG.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

FX.OWN.TOTL.ZS-access.Indicator: Account ownership at a financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider
FX.OWN.TOTL.ZS-access.Definition: Account denotes the percentage of respondents who report having an account (by themselves or together with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution or report personally using a mobile money service in the past 12 months (% age 15+).
FX.OWN.TOTL.ZS-access.Source: Demirguc-Kunt et al., 2018, Global Financial Inclusion Database, World Bank.

GB.XPD.RSDV.GD.ZS-technology.Definition: Gross domestic expenditures on research and development (R&D), expressed as a percent of GDP. They include both capital and current expenditures in the four main sectors: Business enterprise, Government, Higher education and Private non-profit. R&D covers basic research, applied research, and experimental development.

GC.AST.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net acquisition of government financial assets includes domestic and foreign financial claims, SDRs, and gold bullion held by monetary authorities as a reserve asset. The net acquisition of financial assets should be offset by the net incurrence of liabilities.
GC.AST.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.AST.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net acquisition of government financial assets includes domestic and foreign financial claims, SDRs, and gold bullion held by monetary authorities as a reserve asset. The net acquisition of financial assets should be offset by the net incurrence of liabilities.
GC.AST.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.DOD.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Definition: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
GC.DOD.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Definition: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
GC.DOD.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

GC.LBL.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets.
GC.LBL.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.LBL.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets.
GC.LBL.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.NFN.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net investment in government nonfinancial assets includes fixed assets, inventories, valuables, and nonproduced assets. Nonfinancial assets are stores of value and provide benefits either through their use in the production of goods and services or in the form of property income and holding gains. Net investment in nonfinancial assets also includes consumption of fixed capital.
GC.NFN.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.NFN.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net investment in government nonfinancial assets includes fixed assets, inventories, valuables, and nonproduced assets. Nonfinancial assets are stores of value and provide benefits either through their use in the production of goods and services or in the form of property income and holding gains. Net investment in nonfinancial assets also includes consumption of fixed capital.
GC.NFN.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.NLD.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net lending (+) / net borrowing (–) equals government revenue minus expense, minus net investment in nonfinancial assets. It is also equal to the net result of transactions in financial assets and liabilities. Net lending/net borrowing is a summary measure indicating the extent to which government is either putting financial resources at the disposal of other sectors in the economy or abroad, or utilizing the financial resources generated by other sectors in the economy or from abroad.
GC.NLD.TOTL.CN-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.NLD.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Definition: Net lending (+) / net borrowing (–) equals government revenue minus expense, minus net investment in nonfinancial assets. It is also equal to the net result of transactions in financial assets and liabilities. Net lending/net borrowing is a summary measure indicating the extent to which government is either putting financial resources at the disposal of other sectors in the economy or abroad, or utilizing the financial resources generated by other sectors in the economy or from abroad.
GC.NLD.TOTL.GD.ZS-deficitFinancing.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.GOTR.CN-revenue.Definition: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
GC.REV.GOTR.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.GOTR.ZS-revenue.Definition: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
GC.REV.GOTR.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.SOCL.CN-revenue.Definition: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
GC.REV.SOCL.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.SOCL.ZS-revenue.Definition: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
GC.REV.SOCL.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.XGRT.CN-revenue.Definition: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
GC.REV.XGRT.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.REV.XGRT.GD.ZS-revenue.Definition: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
GC.REV.XGRT.GD.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

GC.TAX.EXPT.CN-revenue.Definition: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
GC.TAX.EXPT.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.EXPT.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
GC.TAX.EXPT.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.GSRV.CN-revenue.Definition: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
GC.TAX.GSRV.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.GSRV.RV.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
GC.TAX.GSRV.RV.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.GSRV.VA.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
GC.TAX.GSRV.VA.ZS-revenue.Units: % value added of industry and services
GC.TAX.GSRV.VA.ZS-revenue.Dimension: % value added of industry and services
GC.TAX.GSRV.VA.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD value added estimates.

GC.TAX.IMPT.CN-revenue.Definition: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
GC.TAX.IMPT.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.IMPT.ZS-revenue.Definition: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
GC.TAX.IMPT.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.INTT.CN-revenue.Definition: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
GC.TAX.INTT.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.INTT.RV.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
GC.TAX.INTT.RV.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.OTHR.CN-revenue.Definition: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
GC.TAX.OTHR.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.OTHR.RV.ZS-revenue.Definition: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
GC.TAX.OTHR.RV.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.TOTL.CN-revenue.Definition: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
GC.TAX.TOTL.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.TOTL.GD.ZS-revenue.Definition: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
GC.TAX.TOTL.GD.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

GC.TAX.YPKG.CN-revenue.Definition: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
GC.TAX.YPKG.CN-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.YPKG.RV.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
GC.TAX.YPKG.RV.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.TAX.YPKG.ZS-revenue.Definition: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
GC.TAX.YPKG.ZS-revenue.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.COMP.CN-expense.Definition: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
GC.XPN.COMP.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.COMP.ZS-expense.Definition: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
GC.XPN.COMP.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.GSRV.CN-expense.Definition: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
GC.XPN.GSRV.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.GSRV.ZS-expense.Definition: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
GC.XPN.GSRV.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.INTP.CN-expense.Definition: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
GC.XPN.INTP.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.INTP.RV.ZS-expense.Definition: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
GC.XPN.INTP.RV.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.INTP.ZS-expense.Definition: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
GC.XPN.INTP.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.OTHR.CN-expense.Definition: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
GC.XPN.OTHR.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.OTHR.ZS-expense.Definition: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
GC.XPN.OTHR.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.TOTL.CN-expense.Definition: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
GC.XPN.TOTL.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.TOTL.GD.ZS-expense.Definition: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
GC.XPN.TOTL.GD.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

GC.XPN.TRFT.CN-expense.Definition: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
GC.XPN.TRFT.CN-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GC.XPN.TRFT.ZS-expense.Definition: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
GC.XPN.TRFT.ZS-expense.Source: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

GF.XPD.BUDG.ZS-governmentFinance.Indicator: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget
GF.XPD.BUDG.ZS-governmentFinance.Definition: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget measures the extent to which aggregate budget expenditure outturn reflects the amount originally approved, as defined in government budget documentation and fiscal reports. The coverage is budgetary central government (BCG) and the time period covered is the last three completed fiscal years.
GF.XPD.BUDG.ZS-governmentFinance.Source: Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA). Ministry of Finance (MoF).

HD.HCI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI calculates the contributions of health and education to worker productivity. The final index score ranges from zero to one and measures the productivity as a future worker of child born today relative to the benchmark of full health and complete education.
HD.HCI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.FE-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI calculates the contributions of health and education to worker productivity. The final index score ranges from zero to one and measures the productivity as a future worker of child born today relative to the benchmark of full health and complete education.
HD.HCI.OVRL.FE-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.LB-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI lower bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the lower bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.LB-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.LB.FE-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI lower bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the lower bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.LB.FE-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.LB.MA-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI lower bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the lower bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.LB.MA-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.MA-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI calculates the contributions of health and education to worker productivity. The final index score ranges from zero to one and measures the productivity as a future worker of child born today relative to the benchmark of full health and complete education.
HD.HCI.OVRL.MA-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.UB-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI upper bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the upper bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.UB-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.UB.FE-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI upper bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the upper bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.UB.FE-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

HD.HCI.OVRL.UB.MA-policyInstitutions.Definition: The HCI upper bound reflects uncertainty in the measurement of the components and the overall index. It is obtained by recalculating the HCI using estimates of the upper bounds of each of the components of the HCI. The range between the upper and lower bound is the uncertainty interval. While the uncertainty intervals constructed here do not have a rigorous statistical interpretation, a rule of thumb is that if for two countries they overlap substantially, the differences between their HCI values are not likely to be practically meaningful.
HD.HCI.OVRL.UB.MA-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank staff calculations based on the methodology described in World Bank (2018). https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/30498

IC.BUS.DFRN.XQ-businessEnvironment.Definition: Distance to frontier score illustrates the distance of an economy to the "frontier," which represents the best performance observed on each Doing Business topic across all economies and years included since 2005. An economy's distance to frontier is indicated on a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 represents the lowest performance and 100 the frontier. For example, a score of 75 in 2012 means an economy was 25 percentage points away from the frontier constructed from the best performances across all economies and across time. A score of 80 in 2013 would indicate the economy is improving.

IC.BUS.DISC.XQ-businessEnvironment.Definition: Disclosure index measures the extent to which investors are protected through disclosure of ownership and financial information. The index ranges from 0 to 10, with higher values indicating more disclosure.

IC.BUS.EASE.XQ-businessEnvironment.Definition: Ease of doing business ranks economies from 1 to 190, with first place being the best. A high ranking (a low numerical rank) means that the regulatory environment is conducive to business operation. The index averages the country's percentile rankings on 10 topics covered in the World Bank's Doing Business. The ranking on each topic is the simple average of the percentile rankings on its component indicators.

IC.BUS.NDNS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: New businesses registered are the number of new limited liability corporations registered in the calendar year.
IC.BUS.NDNS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Source: World Bank's Entrepreneurship Survey and database (http://www.doingbusiness.org/data/exploretopics/entrepreneurship).

IC.BUS.NREG-businessEnvironment.Definition: New businesses registered are the number of new limited liability corporations registered in the calendar year.
IC.BUS.NREG-businessEnvironment.Source: World Bank's Entrepreneurship Survey and database (http://www.doingbusiness.org/data/exploretopics/entrepreneurship).

IC.CRD.INFO.XQ-businessEnvironment.Definition: Depth of credit information index measures rules affecting the scope, accessibility, and quality of credit information available through public or private credit registries. The index ranges from 0 to 8, with higher values indicating the availability of more credit information, from either a public registry or a private bureau, to facilitate lending decisions.

IC.CRD.PRVT.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Private credit bureau coverage reports the number of individuals or firms listed by a private credit bureau with current information on repayment history, unpaid debts, or credit outstanding. The number is expressed as a percentage of the adult population.

IC.CRD.PUBL.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Public credit registry coverage reports the number of individuals and firms listed in a public credit registry with current information on repayment history, unpaid debts, or credit outstanding. The number is expressed as a percentage of the adult population.

IC.CUS.DURS.EX-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Average time to clear exports through customs
IC.CUS.DURS.EX-businessEnvironment.Definition: Average time to clear exports through customs is the average number of days to clear direct exports through customs.

IC.ELC.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time to obtain an electrical connection
IC.ELC.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: The average wait, in days, experienced to obtain an electrical connection from the day an establishment applies for it to the day it receives the service.

IC.ELC.OUTG-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Power outages in firms in a typical month
IC.ELC.OUTG-businessEnvironment.Definition: Power outages are the average number of power outages that establishments experience in a typical month.

IC.ELC.OUTG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Percent of firms experiencing electrical outages during the previous fiscal year.

IC.ELC.TIME-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to get electricity is the number of days to obtain a permanent electricity connection. The measure captures the median duration that the electricity utility and experts indicate is necessary in practice, rather than required by law, to complete a procedure.

IC.EXP.CSBC.CD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Border compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the economy’s customs regulations and with regulations relating to other inspections that are mandatory in order for the shipment to cross the economy’s border, as well as the time and cost for handling that takes place at its port or border. The time and cost for this segment include time and cost for customs clearance and inspection procedures conducted by other government agencies.

IC.EXP.CSDC.CD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Documentary compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the documentary requirements of all government agencies of the origin economy, the destination economy and any transit economies. The aim is to measure the total burden of preparing the bundle of documents that will enable completion of the international trade for the product and partner pair assumed in the case study.

IC.EXP.TMBC-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Border compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the economy’s customs regulations and with regulations relating to other inspections that are mandatory in order for the shipment to cross the economy’s border, as well as the time and cost for handling that takes place at its port or border. The time and cost for this segment include time and cost for customs clearance and inspection procedures conducted by other government agencies.

IC.EXP.TMDC-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Documentary compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the documentary requirements of all government agencies of the origin economy, the destination economy and any transit economies. The aim is to measure the total burden of preparing the bundle of documents that will enable completion of the international trade for the product and partner pair assumed in the case study.

IC.FRM.BKWC.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms using banks to finance working capital
IC.FRM.BKWC.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms using banks to finance working capital are the percentage of firms using bank loans to finance working capital.

IC.FRM.BNKS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms using banks to finance investment
IC.FRM.BNKS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms using banks to finance investment are the percentage of firms using banks to finance investments.

IC.FRM.BRIB.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Bribery incidence is the percentage of firms experiencing at least one bribe payment request across 6 public transactions dealing with utilities access, permits, licenses, and taxes.
IC.FRM.BRIB.ZS-businessEnvironment.Units: % of firms experiencing at least one bribe payment request

IC.FRM.CMPU.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms competing against unregistered firms are the percentage of firms competing against unregistered or informal firms.

IC.FRM.CORR.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Informal payments to public officials are the percentage of firms expected to make informal payments to public officials to "get things done" with regard to customs, taxes, licenses, regulations, services, and the like.

IC.FRM.CRIM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Losses due to theft and vandalism
IC.FRM.CRIM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Average losses as a result of theft, robbery, vandalism or arson that occurred on the establishment’s premises calculated as a percentage of annual sales. The value represents the average losses for all firms which reported losses (please see indicator IC.FRM.THEV.ZS).
IC.FRM.CRIM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Units: % of annual sales for affected firms

IC.FRM.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to obtain an operating license
IC.FRM.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to obtain operating license is the average wait to obtain an operating license from the day the establishment applied for it to the day it was granted.

IC.FRM.FEMM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms with female top manager refers to the percentage of firms in the private sector who have females as top managers. Top manager refers to the highest ranking manager or CEO of the establishment. This person may be the owner if he/she works as the manager of the firm. The results are based on surveys of more than 100,000 private firms.

IC.FRM.FEMO.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms with female participation in ownership
IC.FRM.FEMO.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms with female participation in ownership are the percentage of firms with a woman among the principal owners.

IC.FRM.FREG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms formally registered when operations started
IC.FRM.FREG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms formally registered when operations started are the percentage of firms formally registered when they started operations in the country.

IC.FRM.INFM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms that do not report all sales for tax purposes
IC.FRM.INFM.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms that do not report all sales for tax purposes are the percentage of firms that expressed that a typical firm reports less than 100 percent of sales for tax purposes; such firms are termed "informal firms."

IC.FRM.METG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms visited or required meetings with tax officials
IC.FRM.METG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Percent of firms that were visited or required to meet with tax officials.

IC.FRM.OUTG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Value lost due to electrical outages
IC.FRM.OUTG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Average losses due to electrical outages, as percentage of total annual sales. The value represents average losses for all firms which reported outages (please see indicator IC.ELC.OUTG.ZS).

IC.FRM.RSDV.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Percent of firms that spend on research and development.

IC.FRM.THEV.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms experiencing losses due to theft and vandalism
IC.FRM.THEV.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Percent of firms experiencing losses due to theft, robbery, vandalism or arson that occurred on the establishment's premises.

IC.FRM.TRNG.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms offering formal training are the percentage of firms offering formal training programs for their permanent, full-time employees.

IC.GOV.DURS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time spent dealing with the requirements of government regulations
IC.GOV.DURS.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time spent dealing with the requirements of government regulations is the proportion of senior management's time, in a typical week, that is spent dealing with the requirements imposed by government regulations (e.g., taxes, customs, labor regulations, licensing and registration, including dealings with officials, and completing forms).

IC.IMP.CSBC.CD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Border compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the economy’s customs regulations and with regulations relating to other inspections that are mandatory in order for the shipment to cross the economy’s border, as well as the time and cost for handling that takes place at its port or border. The time and cost for this segment include time and cost for customs clearance and inspection procedures conducted by other government agencies.

IC.IMP.CSDC.CD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Documentary compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the documentary requirements of all government agencies of the origin economy, the destination economy and any transit economies. The aim is to measure the total burden of preparing the bundle of documents that will enable completion of the international trade for the product and partner pair assumed in the case study.

IC.IMP.TMBC-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Border compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the economy’s customs regulations and with regulations relating to other inspections that are mandatory in order for the shipment to cross the economy’s border, as well as the time and cost for handling that takes place at its port or border. The time and cost for this segment include time and cost for customs clearance and inspection procedures conducted by other government agencies.

IC.IMP.TMDC-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Documentary compliance captures the time and cost associated with compliance with the documentary requirements of all government agencies of the origin economy, the destination economy and any transit economies. The aim is to measure the total burden of preparing the bundle of documents that will enable completion of the international trade for the product and partner pair assumed in the case study.

IC.ISV.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time to resolve insolvency is the number of years from the filing for insolvency in court until the resolution of distressed assets.

IC.LGL.CRED.XQ-businessEnvironment.Definition: Strength of legal rights index measures the degree to which collateral and bankruptcy laws protect the rights of borrowers and lenders and thus facilitate lending. The index ranges from 0 to 12, with higher scores indicating that these laws are better designed to expand access to credit.

IC.LGL.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to enforce a contract
IC.LGL.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to enforce a contract is the number of calendar days from the filing of the lawsuit in court until the final determination and, in appropriate cases, payment.

IC.PRP.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to register property is the number of calendar days needed for businesses to secure rights to property.

IC.PRP.PROC-businessEnvironment.Definition: Number of procedures to register property is the number of procedures required for a businesses to secure rights to property.

IC.REG.COST.PC.FE.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Cost to register a business is normalized by presenting it as a percentage of gross national income (GNI) per capita.

IC.REG.COST.PC.MA.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Cost to register a business is normalized by presenting it as a percentage of gross national income (GNI) per capita.

IC.REG.COST.PC.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Cost to register a business is normalized by presenting it as a percentage of gross national income (GNI) per capita.

IC.REG.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to start a business
IC.REG.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to start a business is the number of calendar days needed to complete the procedures to legally operate a business. If a procedure can be speeded up at additional cost, the fastest procedure, independent of cost, is chosen.

IC.REG.DURS.FE-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to start a business
IC.REG.DURS.FE-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to start a business is the number of calendar days needed to complete the procedures to legally operate a business. If a procedure can be speeded up at additional cost, the fastest procedure, independent of cost, is chosen.

IC.REG.DURS.MA-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to start a business
IC.REG.DURS.MA-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to start a business is the number of calendar days needed to complete the procedures to legally operate a business. If a procedure can be speeded up at additional cost, the fastest procedure, independent of cost, is chosen.

IC.REG.PROC-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Start-up procedures to register a business
IC.REG.PROC-businessEnvironment.Definition: Start-up procedures are those required to start a business, including interactions to obtain necessary permits and licenses and to complete all inscriptions, verifications, and notifications to start operations. Data are for businesses with specific characteristics of ownership, size, and type of production.

IC.REG.PROC.FE-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Start-up procedures to register a business
IC.REG.PROC.FE-businessEnvironment.Definition: Start-up procedures are those required to start a business, including interactions to obtain necessary permits and licenses and to complete all inscriptions, verifications, and notifications to start operations. Data are for businesses with specific characteristics of ownership, size, and type of production.

IC.REG.PROC.MA-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Start-up procedures to register a business
IC.REG.PROC.MA-businessEnvironment.Definition: Start-up procedures are those required to start a business, including interactions to obtain necessary permits and licenses and to complete all inscriptions, verifications, and notifications to start operations. Data are for businesses with specific characteristics of ownership, size, and type of production.

IC.TAX.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time to prepare and pay taxes
IC.TAX.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time to prepare and pay taxes is the time, in hours per year, it takes to prepare, file, and pay (or withhold) three major types of taxes: the corporate income tax, the value added or sales tax, and labor taxes, including payroll taxes and social security contributions.

IC.TAX.GIFT.ZS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Firms expected to give gifts in meetings with tax officials
IC.TAX.GIFT.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Firms expected to give gifts in meetings with tax officials is the percentage of firms that answered positively to the question "was a gift or informal payment expected or requested during a meeting with tax officials?"

IC.TAX.LABR.CP.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Labor tax and contributions is the amount of taxes and mandatory contributions on labor paid by the business.

IC.TAX.METG-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Number of visits or required meetings with tax officials
IC.TAX.METG-businessEnvironment.Definition: Average number of visits or required meetings with tax officials during the year. The value represents the average number of visits for all firms which reported being visited or required to meet with tax officials (please see indicator IC.FRM.METG.ZS).

IC.TAX.OTHR.CP.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Other taxes payable by businesses include the amounts paid for property taxes, turnover taxes, and other small taxes such as municipal fees and vehicle and fuel taxes.

IC.TAX.PAYM-businessEnvironment.Definition: Tax payments by businesses are the total number of taxes paid by businesses, including electronic filing. The tax is counted as paid once a year even if payments are more frequent.

IC.TAX.PRFT.CP.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Profit tax is the amount of taxes on profits paid by the business.

IC.TAX.TOTL.CP.ZS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Total tax rate measures the amount of taxes and mandatory contributions payable by businesses after accounting for allowable deductions and exemptions as a share of commercial profits. Taxes withheld (such as personal income tax) or collected and remitted to tax authorities (such as value added taxes, sales taxes or goods and service taxes) are excluded.

IC.WRH.DURS-businessEnvironment.Indicator: Time required to build a warehouse
IC.WRH.DURS-businessEnvironment.Definition: Time required to build a warehouse is the number of calendar days needed to complete the required procedures for building a warehouse. If a procedure can be speeded up at additional cost, the fastest procedure, independent of cost, is chosen.

IC.WRH.PROC-businessEnvironment.Definition: Number of procedures to build a warehouse is the number of interactions of a company's employees or managers with external parties, including government agency staff, public inspectors, notaries, land registry and cadastre staff, and technical experts apart from architects and engineers.

IE.PPI.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Investment in energy with private participation
IE.PPI.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Investment in energy with private participation is the value of commitments to energy projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including lease and management contracts, operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility), and divestitures. Movable assets and small projects such as windmills are excluded.
IE.PPI.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPI.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Investment in ICT with private participation
IE.PPI.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Investment in ICT with private participation is the value of commitments to information and communications technology backbone infrastructure projects (including land based and submarine cables) that have an active government component (eg, the government is a contracting authority). These are projects which have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including operation and lease contracts, operation and management  contracts with major capital expenditure, greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility), and divestitures. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPI.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPI.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Investment in transport with private participation
IE.PPI.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Investment in transport with private participation is the value of commitments to transportation projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including management and lease contracts, operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility), and divestitures. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPI.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPI.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Investment in water and sanitation with private participation
IE.PPI.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Investment in water and sanitation with private participation is the commitments to value of water and sanitation projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility), and divestitures. Incinerators, movable assets, standalone solid waste projects, and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPI.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPN.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Public private partnerships investment in energy
IE.PPN.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Public Private Partnerships in energy (current US$)  is the value of commitments to energy projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including lease and management contracts, operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, and greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility). It excludes divestitures and merchant projects. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPN.ENGY.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPN.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Public private partnerships investment in ICT
IE.PPN.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Public Private Partnerships in ICT (current US$) is the value of information and communications technology backbone infrastructure projects (including land based and submarine cables) that have an active government component (eg, the government is a contracting authority). These are projects which have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure and greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility). It excludes divestitures and merchant projects. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPN.ICTI.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPN.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Public private partnerships investment in transport
IE.PPN.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Public Private Partnerships in transport (current US$)  is the value of commitments to transportation projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including lease and management contracts, operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, and greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility). It excludes divestitures and merchant projects. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPN.TRAN.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IE.PPN.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Indicator: Public private partnerships investment in water and sanitation
IE.PPN.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Definition: Public Private Partnerships in water and sanitation (current US$)  is the value of commitments to water and sanitation projects that have reached financial closure and directly or indirectly serve the public, including lease and management contracts, operation and management contracts with major capital expenditure, and greenfield projects (in which a private entity or public-private joint venture builds and operates a new facility). It excludes divestitures and merchant projects. Movable assets and small projects are excluded.
IE.PPN.WATR.CD-privateInfrastructureInve.Source: World Bank, Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Database (http://ppi.worldbank.org).

IP.IDS.NRCT-technology.Indicator: Industrial design applications, nonresident, by count
IP.IDS.NRCT-technology.Definition: Industrial design applications are applications to register an industrial design with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) offices and designations received by relevant offices through the Hague System. Industrial designs are applied to a wide variety of industrial products and handicrafts. They refer to the ornamental or aesthetic aspects of a useful article, including compositions of lines or colors or any three-dimensional forms that give a special appearance to a product or handicraft. The holder of a registered industrial design has exclusive rights against unauthorized copying or imitation of the design by third parties. Industrial design registrations are valid for a limited period. The term of protection is usually 15 years for most jurisdictions. However, differences in legislation do exist, notably in China (which provides for a 10-year term from the application date). Non-resident application refers to an application filed with the IP office of or acting on behalf of a state or jurisdiction in which the first-named applicant in the application is not domiciled. Design count is used to render application data for industrial applications across offices comparable, as some offices follow a single-class/single-design filing system while other have a multiple class/design filing system.
IP.IDS.NRCT-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), Statistics Database at www.wipo.int/ipstats/. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.IDS.RSCT-technology.Indicator: Industrial design applications, resident, by count
IP.IDS.RSCT-technology.Definition: Industrial design applications are applications to register an industrial design with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) offices and designations received by relevant offices through the Hague System. Industrial designs are applied to a wide variety of industrial products and handicrafts. They refer to the ornamental or aesthetic aspects of a useful article, including compositions of lines or colors or any three-dimensional forms that give a special appearance to a product or handicraft. The holder of a registered industrial design has exclusive rights against unauthorized copying or imitation of the design by third parties. Industrial design registrations are valid for a limited period. The term of protection is usually 15 years for most jurisdictions. However, differences in legislation do exist, notably in China (which provides for a 10-year term from the application date). Resident application refers to an application filed with the IP office of or acting on behalf of the state or jurisdiction in which the first-named applicant in the application has residence. Design count is used to render application data for industrial applications across offices comparable, as some offices follow a single-class/single-design filing system while other have a multiple class/design filing system.
IP.IDS.RSCT-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), Statistics Database at www.wipo.int/ipstats/. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.JRN.ARTC.SC-technology.Definition: Scientific and technical journal articles refer to the number of scientific and engineering articles published in the following fields: physics, biology, chemistry, mathematics, clinical medicine, biomedical research, engineering and technology, and earth and space sciences.
IP.JRN.ARTC.SC-technology.Source: National Science Foundation, Science and Engineering Indicators.

IP.PAT.NRES-technology.Definition: Patent applications are worldwide patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office.
IP.PAT.NRES-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.PAT.RESD-technology.Definition: Patent applications are worldwide patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office.
IP.PAT.RESD-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.TMK.NRCT-technology.Definition: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) offices and designations received by relevant offices through the Madrid System. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Non-resident application refers to an application filed with the IP office of or acting on behalf of a state or jurisdiction in which the first-named applicant in the application is not domiciled. Class count is used to render application data for trademark applications across offices comparable, as some offices follow a single-class/single-design filing system while other have a multiple class/design filing system.
IP.TMK.NRCT-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), Statistics Database at www.wipo.int/ipstats/. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.TMK.NRES-technology.Definition: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. Direct nonresident trademark applications are those filed by applicants from abroad directly at a given national IP office.
IP.TMK.NRES-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.TMK.RESD-technology.Definition: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. Direct resident trademark applications are those filed by domestic applicants directly at a given national IP office.
IP.TMK.RESD-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.TMK.RSCT-technology.Definition: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) offices and designations received by relevant offices through the Madrid System. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Resident application refers to an application filed with the IP office of or acting on behalf of the state or jurisdiction in which the first-named applicant in the application has residence. Class count is used to render application data for trademark applications across offices comparable, as some offices follow a single-class/single-design filing system while other have a multiple class/design filing system.
IP.TMK.RSCT-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), Statistics Database at www.wipo.int/ipstats/. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IP.TMK.TOTL-technology.Definition: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office.
IP.TMK.TOTL-technology.Source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

IQ.CPA.BREG.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Business regulatory environment assesses the extent to which the legal, regulatory, and policy environments help or hinder private businesses in investing, creating jobs, and becoming more productive.

IQ.CPA.DEBT.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Debt policy assesses whether the debt management strategy is conducive to minimizing budgetary risks and ensuring long-term debt sustainability.

IQ.CPA.ECON.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: The economic management cluster includes macroeconomic management, fiscal policy, and debt policy.

IQ.CPA.ENVR.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA policy and institutions for environmental sustainability rating
IQ.CPA.ENVR.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Policy and institutions for environmental sustainability assess the extent to which environmental policies foster the protection and sustainable use of natural resources and the management of pollution.

IQ.CPA.FINQ.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA quality of budgetary and financial management rating
IQ.CPA.FINQ.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Quality of budgetary and financial management assesses the extent to which there is a comprehensive and credible budget linked to policy priorities, effective financial management systems, and timely and accurate accounting and fiscal reporting, including timely and audited public accounts.

IQ.CPA.FINS.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Financial sector assesses the structure of the financial sector and the policies and regulations that affect it.

IQ.CPA.FISP.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Fiscal policy assesses the short- and medium-term sustainability of fiscal policy (taking into account monetary and exchange rate policy and the sustainability of the public debt) and its impact on growth.

IQ.CPA.GNDR.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Gender equality assesses the extent to which the country has installed institutions and programs to enforce laws and policies that promote equal access for men and women in education, health, the economy, and protection under law.

IQ.CPA.HRES.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Building human resources assesses the national policies and public and private sector service delivery that affect the access to and quality of health and education services, including prevention and treatment of HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria.

IQ.CPA.IRAI.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: IDA Resource Allocation Index is obtained by calculating the average score for each cluster and then by averaging those scores. For each of 16 criteria countries are rated on a scale of 1 (low) to 6 (high).

IQ.CPA.MACR.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Macroeconomic management assesses the monetary, exchange rate, and aggregate demand policy framework.

IQ.CPA.PADM.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA quality of public administration rating
IQ.CPA.PADM.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Quality of public administration assesses the extent to which civilian central government staff is structured to design and implement government policy and deliver services effectively.

IQ.CPA.PRES.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA equity of public resource use rating
IQ.CPA.PRES.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Equity of public resource use assesses the extent to which the pattern of public expenditures and revenue collection affects the poor and is consistent with national poverty reduction priorities.

IQ.CPA.PROP.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA property rights and rule-based governance rating
IQ.CPA.PROP.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Property rights and rule-based governance assess the extent to which private economic activity is facilitated by an effective legal system and rule-based governance structure in which property and contract rights are reliably respected and enforced.

IQ.CPA.PROT.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Social protection and labor assess government policies in social protection and labor market regulations that reduce the risk of becoming poor, assist those who are poor to better manage further risks, and ensure a minimal level of welfare to all people.

IQ.CPA.PUBS.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA public sector management and institutions cluster average
IQ.CPA.PUBS.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: The public sector management and institutions cluster includes property rights and rule-based governance, quality of budgetary and financial management, efficiency of revenue mobilization, quality of public administration, and transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector.

IQ.CPA.REVN.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA efficiency of revenue mobilization rating
IQ.CPA.REVN.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Efficiency of revenue mobilization assesses the overall pattern of revenue mobilization--not only the de facto tax structure, but also revenue from all sources as actually collected.

IQ.CPA.SOCI.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA policies for social inclusion/equity cluster average
IQ.CPA.SOCI.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: The policies for social inclusion and equity cluster includes gender equality, equity of public resource use, building human resources, social protection and labor, and policies and institutions for environmental sustainability.

IQ.CPA.STRC.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: The structural policies cluster includes trade, financial sector, and business regulatory environment.

IQ.CPA.TRAD.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Trade assesses how the policy framework fosters trade in goods.

IQ.CPA.TRAN.XQ-policyInstitutions.Indicator: CPIA transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector rating
IQ.CPA.TRAN.XQ-policyInstitutions.Definition: Transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector assess the extent to which the executive can be held accountable for its use of funds and for the results of its actions by the electorate and by the legislature and judiciary, and the extent to which public employees within the executive are required to account for administrative decisions, use of resources, and results obtained. The three main dimensions assessed here are the accountability of the executive to oversight institutions and of public employees for their performance, access of civil society to information on public affairs, and state capture by narrow vested interests.

IQ.SCI.MTHD-policyInstitutions.Definition: The methodology indicator measures a country’s ability to adhere to internationally recommended standards and methods. The methodology score is calculated as the weighted average of 10 underlying indicator scores. The final methodology score contributes 1/3 of the overall Statistical Capacity Indicator score.
IQ.SCI.MTHD-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank, Bulletin Board on Statistical Capacity (http://bbsc.worldbank.org).

IQ.SCI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Definition: The Statistical Capacity Indicator is a composite score assessing the capacity of a country’s statistical system. It is based on a diagnostic framework assessing the following areas: methodology; data sources; and periodicity and timeliness. Countries are scored against 25 criteria in these areas, using publicly available information and/or country input. The overall Statistical Capacity score is then calculated as a simple average of all three area scores on a scale of 0-100.
IQ.SCI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank, Bulletin Board on Statistical Capacity (http://bbsc.worldbank.org).

IQ.SCI.PRDC-policyInstitutions.Indicator: Periodicity and timeliness assessment of statistical capacity
IQ.SCI.PRDC-policyInstitutions.Definition: The periodicity and timeliness indicator assesses the availability and periodicity of key socioeconomic indicators. It measures the extent to which data are made accessible to users through transformation of source data into timely statistical outputs. The periodicity score is calculated as the weighted average of 10 underlying indicator scores. The final periodicity score contributes 1/3 of the overall Statistical Capacity Indicator score.
IQ.SCI.PRDC-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank, Bulletin Board on Statistical Capacity (http://bbsc.worldbank.org).

IQ.SCI.SRCE-policyInstitutions.Indicator: Source data assessment of statistical capacity
IQ.SCI.SRCE-policyInstitutions.Definition: The source data indicator reflects whether a country conducts data collection activities in line with internationally recommended periodicity, and whether data from administrative systems are available. The source data score is calculated as the weighted average of 5 underlying indicator scores. The final source data score contributes 1/3 of the overall Statistical Capacity Indicator score.
IQ.SCI.SRCE-policyInstitutions.Source: World Bank, Bulletin Board on Statistical Capacity (http://bbsc.worldbank.org).

IQ.SPI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Definition: The SPI overall score is a composite score measuing country performance across five pillars: data use, data services, data products, data sources, and data infrastructure.
IQ.SPI.OVRL-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IQ.SPI.PIL1-policyInstitutions.Definition: The data use overall score is a composite score covering five dimensions: (i) the legislature, (ii) the executive branch, (iii) civil society (including sub-national actors), (iv) academia and (v) international bodies.  Scores range from 0-100 with 100 representing the best score.
IQ.SPI.PIL1-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IQ.SPI.PIL2-policyInstitutions.Definition: The data services overall score is a composite score covering dimensions on data releases, online access, advisory and analytical services, and data access services
IQ.SPI.PIL2-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IQ.SPI.PIL3-policyInstitutions.Definition: The data products overall score is a composite score measureing whether the country is able to produce relevant indicators, primarily related to SDGs
IQ.SPI.PIL3-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IQ.SPI.PIL4-policyInstitutions.Definition: The data sources overall score is a composity measure of whether countries have data available from the following sources: Censuses and surveys, administrative data, geospatial data, and private sector/citizen generated data
IQ.SPI.PIL4-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IQ.SPI.PIL5-policyInstitutions.Definition: The data infrastructure  pillar  overall score measures the hard and soft infrastructure segments, itemizing essential cross cutting requirements for an effective statistical system.
IQ.SPI.PIL5-policyInstitutions.Source: Statistical Performance Indicators, The World Bank (https://datacatalog.worldbank.org/dataset/statistical-performance-indicators)

IS.AIR.DPRT-transportation.Definition: Registered carrier departures worldwide are domestic takeoffs and takeoffs abroad of air carriers registered in the country.
IS.AIR.DPRT-transportation.Source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

IS.AIR.GOOD.MT.K1-transportation.Definition: Air freight is the volume of freight, express, and diplomatic bags carried on each flight stage (operation of an aircraft from takeoff to its next landing), measured in metric tons times kilometers traveled.
IS.AIR.GOOD.MT.K1-transportation.Source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

IS.AIR.PSGR-transportation.Definition: Air passengers carried include both domestic and international aircraft passengers of air carriers registered in the country.
IS.AIR.PSGR-transportation.Source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.
