IS.RRS.GOOD.MT.K6-transportation.Definition: Goods transported by railway are the volume of goods transported by railway, measured in metric tons times kilometers traveled.
IS.RRS.GOOD.MT.K6-transportation.Source: Internation Union of Railways (UIC), OECD Statistics

IS.RRS.PASG.KM-transportation.Definition: Passengers carried by railway are the number of passengers transported by rail times kilometers traveled.
IS.RRS.PASG.KM-transportation.Source: Internation Union of Railways (UIC), OECD Statistics

IS.RRS.TOTL.KM-transportation.Definition: Rail lines are the length of railway route available for train service, irrespective of the number of parallel tracks.

IS.SHP.GCNW.XQ-transportation.Definition:
Liner Shipping Connectivity Index score indicates how well countries are connected to global shipping networks
based on the status of their maritime transport sector. The highest value in 2004 is 100.
IS.SHP.GCNW.XQ-transportation.Source: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Review of Maritime Transport 2010.

IS.SHP.GOOD.TU-transportation.Definition: Port container traffic measures the flow of containers from land to sea transport modes., and vice versa, in twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs), a standard-size container. Data refer to coastal shipping as well as international journeys. Transshipment traffic is counted as two lifts at the intermediate port (once to off-load and again as an outbound lift) and includes empty units.

IT.CEL.SETS-communications.Definition: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service that provide access to the PSTN using cellular technology. The indicator includes (and is split into) the number of postpaid subscriptions, and the number of active prepaid accounts (i.e. that have been used during the last three months). The indicator applies to all mobile cellular subscriptions that offer voice communications. It excludes subscriptions via data cards or USB modems, subscriptions to public mobile data services, private trunked mobile radio, telepoint, radio paging and telemetry services.
IT.CEL.SETS-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.CEL.SETS.P2-communications.Definition: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service that provide access to the PSTN using cellular technology. The indicator includes (and is split into) the number of postpaid subscriptions, and the number of active prepaid accounts (i.e. that have been used during the last three months). The indicator applies to all mobile cellular subscriptions that offer voice communications. It excludes subscriptions via data cards or USB modems, subscriptions to public mobile data services, private trunked mobile radio, telepoint, radio paging and telemetry services.
IT.CEL.SETS.P2-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.MLT.MAIN-communications.Definition: Fixed telephone subscriptions refers to the sum of active number of analogue fixed telephone lines, voice-over-IP (VoIP) subscriptions, fixed wireless local loop (WLL) subscriptions, ISDN voice-channel equivalents and fixed public payphones.
IT.MLT.MAIN-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.MLT.MAIN.P2-communications.Definition: Fixed telephone subscriptions refers to the sum of active number of analogue fixed telephone lines, voice-over-IP (VoIP) subscriptions, fixed wireless local loop (WLL) subscriptions, ISDN voice-channel equivalents and fixed public payphones.
IT.MLT.MAIN.P2-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.NET.BBND-communications.Definition: Fixed broadband subscriptions refers to fixed subscriptions to high-speed access to the public Internet (a TCP/IP connection), at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 kbit/s. This includes cable modem, DSL, fiber-to-the-home/building, other fixed (wired)-broadband subscriptions, satellite broadband and terrestrial fixed wireless broadband. This total is measured irrespective of the method of payment. It excludes subscriptions that have access to data communications (including the Internet) via mobile-cellular networks. It should include fixed WiMAX and any other fixed wireless technologies. It includes both residential subscriptions and subscriptions for organizations.
IT.NET.BBND-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.NET.BBND.P2-communications.Definition: Fixed broadband subscriptions refers to fixed subscriptions to high-speed access to the public Internet (a TCP/IP connection), at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 kbit/s. This includes cable modem, DSL, fiber-to-the-home/building, other fixed (wired)-broadband subscriptions, satellite broadband and terrestrial fixed wireless broadband. This total is measured irrespective of the method of payment. It excludes subscriptions that have access to data communications (including the Internet) via mobile-cellular networks. It should include fixed WiMAX and any other fixed wireless technologies. It includes both residential subscriptions and subscriptions for organizations.
IT.NET.BBND.P2-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

IT.NET.SECR-communications.Definition: The number of distinct, publicly-trusted TLS/SSL certificates found in the Netcraft Secure Server Survey.

IT.NET.SECR.P6-communications.Definition: The number of distinct, publicly-trusted TLS/SSL certificates found in the Netcraft Secure Server Survey.
IT.NET.SECR.P6-communications.Source: Netcraft (http://www.netcraft.com/) and World Bank population estimates.

IT.NET.USER.ZS-communications.Definition: Internet users are individuals who have used the Internet (from any location) in the last 3 months. The Internet can be used via a computer, mobile phone, personal digital assistant, games machine, digital TV etc.
IT.NET.USER.ZS-communications.Source: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database

LP.EXP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Indicator: Lead time to export, median case
LP.EXP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Lead time to export is the median time (the value for 50 percent of shipments) from shipment point to port of loading.
LP.EXP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.IMP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Indicator: Lead time to import, median case
LP.IMP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Lead time to import is the median time (the value for 50 percent of shipments) from port of discharge to arrival at the consignee.
LP.IMP.DURS.MD-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.CUST.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of the efficiency of country's customs clearance processes (i.e. speed, simplicity and predictability of formalities), on a rating ranging from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.CUST.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.INFR.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of country's quality of trade and transport related infrastructure (e.g. ports, railroads, roads, information technology), on a rating ranging from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.INFR.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Dimension: Quality of trade and transport-related infrastructure
LP.LPI.INFR.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.ITRN.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of the ease of arranging competitively priced shipments to a country, on a rating ranging from 1 (very difficult) to 5 (very easy). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.ITRN.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Dimension: Ease of arranging competitively priced shipments
LP.LPI.ITRN.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.LOGS.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of country's overall level of competence and quality of logistics services (e.g. transport operators, customs brokers), on a rating ranging from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.LOGS.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Dimension: Competence and quality of logistics services
LP.LPI.LOGS.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.OVRL.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics Performance Index overall score reflects perceptions of a country's logistics based on efficiency of customs clearance process, quality of trade- and transport-related infrastructure, ease of arranging competitively priced shipments, quality of logistics services, ability to track and trace consignments, and frequency with which shipments reach the consignee within the scheduled time. The index ranges from 1 to 5, with a higher score representing better performance.
LP.LPI.OVRL.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.TIME.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of how often the shipments to assessed country reach the consignee within the scheduled or expected delivery time, on a rating ranging from 1 (hardly ever) to 5 (nearly always). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.TIME.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Dimension: Frequency with which shipments reach consignee within scheduled or expected time
LP.LPI.TIME.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

LP.LPI.TRAC.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Definition: Logistics professionals' perception of the ability to track and trace consignments when shipping to the country, on a rating ranging from 1 (very low) to 5 (very high). Scores are averaged across all respondents.
LP.LPI.TRAC.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Dimension: Ability to track and trace consignments
LP.LPI.TRAC.XQ-tradeFacilitation.Source: World Bank and Turku School of Economics, Logistic Performance Index Surveys. Data are available online at : http://www.worldbank.org/lpi. Summary results are published in Arvis and others' Connecting to Compete: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy, The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators report.

MS.MIL.MPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m. A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m.
MS.MIL.MPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).

MS.MIL.TOTL.P1-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces.
MS.MIL.TOTL.P1-defenseArmsTrade.Source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces. Labor force comprises all people who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

MS.MIL.XPND.CD-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces.
MS.MIL.XPND.CD-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.CN-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)
MS.MIL.XPND.CN-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)
MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)
MS.MIL.XPND.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.Definition: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m.  A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m
MS.MIL.XPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.Source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).

NE.CON.GOVT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.GOVT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.GOVT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current local currency.
NE.CON.GOVT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.GOVT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.GOVT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.GOVT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth of general government final consumption expenditure based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. General government final consumption expenditure (general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
NE.CON.GOVT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.GOVT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant local currency.
NE.CON.GOVT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.GOVT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: General government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation.
NE.CON.GOVT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.PRVT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current local currency.
NE.CON.PRVT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.CN.AD-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: Households and NPISHs final consumption expenditure
NE.CON.PRVT.CN.AD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. This series has been linked to produce a consistent time series to counteract breaks in series over time due to changes in base years, source data and methodologies. Thus, it may not be comparable with other national accounts series in the database for historical years. Data are in local currency, at current prices.
NE.CON.PRVT.CN.AD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on World Bank national accounts data archives, OECD National Accounts, and the IMF WEO database.

NE.CON.PRVT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.PRVT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth of household final consumption expenditure based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country.
NE.CON.PRVT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant local currency.
NE.CON.PRVT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: Household final consumption expenditure per capita
NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure per capita (private consumption per capita) is calculated using private consumption in constant 2010 prices and World Bank population estimates. Household final consumption expenditure is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD.ZG-growthRates.Indicator: Household final consumption expenditure per capita growth
NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth of household final consumption expenditure per capita, which is calculated using household final consumption expenditure in constant 2010 prices and World Bank population estimates. Household final consumption expenditure (private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country.
NE.CON.PRVT.PC.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.PRVT.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Indicator: Households and NPISHs Final consumption expenditure
NE.CON.PRVT.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition:
This indicator provides values for households and NPISHs final consumption expenditure expressed in current international dollars converted by purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor. 

Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. 

PPP conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that eliminates the effects of the differences in price levels between countries.

From July 2020, “Households and NPISHs final consumption expenditure: linked series (current LCU)” [NE.CON.PRVT.CN.AD] is used as underlying expenditure in local currency unit so that it’s in line with time series of PPP conversion factor, private consumption (LCU per international $), which are extrapolated with linked CPI.
NE.CON.PRVT.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NE.CON.PRVT.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Indicator: Households and NPISHs Final consumption expenditure
NE.CON.PRVT.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are converted to constant 2017 international dollars using purchasing power parity rates.
NE.CON.PRVT.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NE.CON.PRVT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Indicator: Households and NPISHs final consumption expenditure
NE.CON.PRVT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. This item also includes any statistical discrepancy in the use of resources relative to the supply of resources.
NE.CON.PRVT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (general government consumption). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (general government consumption). Data are in current local currency.
NE.CON.TOTL.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption). Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.CON.TOTL.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Average annual growth of final consumption expenditure based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption). This estimate includes any statistical discrepancy in the use of resources relative to the supply of resources.
NE.CON.TOTL.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption). Data are in constant local currency.
NE.CON.TOTL.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.CON.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Final consumption expenditure (formerly total consumption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (private consumption) and general government final consumption expenditure (general government consumption). This estimate includes any statistical discrepancy in the use of resources relative to the supply of resources.
NE.CON.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.DEFL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment).
NE.DAB.DEFL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.DAB.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.TOTL.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment). Data are in current local currency.
NE.DAB.TOTL.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.TOTL.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment). Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.DAB.TOTL.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.TOTL.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment). Data are in constant local currency.
NE.DAB.TOTL.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.DAB.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross national expenditure (formerly domestic absorption) is the sum of household final consumption expenditure (formerly private consumption), general government final consumption expenditure (formerly general government consumption), and gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment).
NE.DAB.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.EXP.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current local currency.
NE.EXP.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.EXP.GNFS.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual growth rate of exports of goods and services based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments.
NE.EXP.GNFS.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant local currency.
NE.EXP.GNFS.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.EXP.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments.
NE.EXP.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FPRV.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Private investment covers gross outlays by the private sector (including private nonprofit agencies) on additions to its fixed domestic assets.
NE.GDI.FPRV.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FPRV.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Private investment covers gross outlays by the private sector (including private nonprofit agencies) on additions to its fixed domestic assets.
NE.GDI.FPRV.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.GDI.FTOT.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current local currency.
NE.GDI.FTOT.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NE.GDI.FTOT.KD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Average annual growth of gross fixed capital formation based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation.
NE.GDI.FTOT.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant local currency.
NE.GDI.FTOT.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.FTOT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation.
NE.GDI.FTOT.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.STKB.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.GDI.STKB.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.STKB.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in current local currency.
NE.GDI.STKB.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.STKB.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in constant local currency.
NE.GDI.STKB.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment) consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.GDI.TOTL.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.GDI.TOTL.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment) consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current local currency.

NE.IMP.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.IMP.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.IMP.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. NE.RSB.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: External balance on goods and services
NE.RSB.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NE.RSB.GNFS.CD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.RSB.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: External balance on goods and services
NE.RSB.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in current local currency.
NE.RSB.GNFS.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.RSB.GNFS.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: External balance on goods and services
NE.RSB.GNFS.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in constant local currency.
NE.RSB.GNFS.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.RSB.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Indicator: External balance on goods and services
NE.RSB.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services).
NE.RSB.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NE.TRD.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services measured as a share of gross domestic product.
NE.TRD.GNFS.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.AGR.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Definition: Value added per worker is a measure of labor productivity—value added per unit of input. Value added denotes the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Agriculture corresponds to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) tabulation categories A and B (revision 3) or tabulation category A (revision 4), and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production.
NV.AGR.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Source: Derived using World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files, and employment data from International Labour Organization, ILOSTAT database.

NV.AGR.TOTL.CD-valueAdded.Definition: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NV.AGR.TOTL.CD-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.AGR.TOTL.CN-valueAdded.Definition: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.
NV.AGR.TOTL.CN-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.FSM.TOTL.CN-valueAdded.Definition: Financial intermediation services indirectly measured (FISIM) is an indirect measure of the value of financial intermediation services (i.e. output) provided but for which financial institutions do not charge explicitly as compared to explicit bank charges. Although the 1993 SNA recommends that the FISIM are allocated as intermediate and final consumption to the users, many countries still make a global (negative) adjustment to the sum of gross value added.
NV.FSM.TOTL.CN-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.FSM.TOTL.KN-valueAdded.Definition: Financial intermediation services indirectly measured (FISIM) is an indirect measure of the value of financial intermediation services (i.e. output) provided but for which financial institutions do not charge explicitly as compared to explicit bank charges. Although the 1993 SNA recommends that the FISIM are allocated as intermediate and final consumption to the users, many countries still make a global (negative) adjustment to the sum of gross value added.
NV.FSM.TOTL.KN-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.IND.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Definition: Value added per worker is a measure of labor productivity—value added per unit of input. Value added denotes the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Industry corresponds to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) tabulation categories C-F (revision 3) or tabulation categories B-F (revision 4), and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
NV.IND.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Source: Derived using World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files, and employment data from International Labour Organization, ILOSTAT database.

NV.IND.MANF.CD-valueAdded.Definition: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NV.IND.TOTL.CD-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.MNF.CHEM.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Chemicals correspond to ISIC division 24.
NV.MNF.CHEM.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

NV.MNF.FBTO.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Food, beverages, and tobacco correspond to ISIC divisions 15 and 16.
NV.MNF.FBTO.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

NV.MNF.MTRN.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Machinery and transport equipment correspond to ISIC divisions 29, 30, 32, 34, and 35.
NV.MNF.MTRN.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

NV.MNF.OTHR.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Other manufacturing, a residual, covers wood and related products (ISIC division 20), paper and related products (ISIC divisions 21 and 22), petroleum and related products (ISIC division 23), basic metals and mineral products (ISIC division27), fabricated metal products and professional goods (ISIC division 28), and other industries (ISIC divisions 25, 26, 31, 33, 36, and 37). Includes unallocated data. When data for textiles, machinery, or chemicals are shown as not available, they are included in other manufacturing.
NV.MNF.OTHR.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

NV.MNF.TECH.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: The proportion of medium and high-tech industry value added in total value added of manufacturing
NV.MNF.TECH.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO), Competitive Industrial Performance (CIP) database

NV.MNF.TXTL.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Textiles and clothing correspond to ISIC divisions 17-19.
NV.MNF.TXTL.ZS.UN-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

NV.SRV.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Definition: Value added per worker is a measure of labor productivity—value added per unit of input. Value added denotes the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Services corresponds to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) tabulation categories G-P (revision 3) or tabulation categories G-U (revision 4), and includes wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social and personal services.
NV.SRV.EMPL.KD-valueAdded.Source: Derived using World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files, and employment data from International Labour Organization, ILOSTAT database.

NV.SRV.TOTL.CD-valueAdded.Definition: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NV.SRV.TOTL.CD-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.SRV.TOTL.CN-valueAdded.Definition: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.

It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. NV.SRV.TOTL.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.SRV.TOTL.KN-valueAdded.Definition: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources.
