NV.SRV.TOTL.KN-valueAdded.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NV.SRV.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99 and they include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges, import duties, and any statistical discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from rescaling. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3 or 4.
NV.SRV.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.ADJ.AEDU.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.
NY.ADJ.AEDU.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: UNESCO; data are extrapolated to the most recent year available

NY.ADJ.AEDU.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.
NY.ADJ.AEDU.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: UNESCO; data are extrapolated to the most recent year available

NY.ADJ.DCO2.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Cost of damage due to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use and the manufacture of cement, estimated to be US$40 per ton of CO2 (the unit damage in 2017 US dollars for CO2 emitted in 2020) times the number of tons of CO2 emitted.
NY.ADJ.DCO2.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DCO2.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Cost of damage due to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use and the manufacture of cement, estimated to be US$40 per ton of CO2 (the unit damage in 2017 US dollars for CO2 emitted in 2020) times the number of tons of CO2 emitted.
NY.ADJ.DCO2.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DFOR.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. If growth exceeds harvest, this figure is zero.
NY.ADJ.DFOR.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DFOR.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. If growth exceeds harvest, this figure is zero.
NY.ADJ.DFOR.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DKAP.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.
NY.ADJ.DKAP.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DKAP.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.
NY.ADJ.DKAP.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DMIN.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
NY.ADJ.DMIN.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DMIN.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
NY.ADJ.DMIN.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DNGY.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.
NY.ADJ.DNGY.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DNGY.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.
NY.ADJ.DNGY.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DPEM.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Particulate emissions damage is the damage due to exposure of a country's population to ambient concentrations of particulates measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), ambient ozone pollution, and indoor concentrations of PM2.5 in households cooking with solid fuels. Damages are calculated as foregone labor income due to premature death. Estimates of health impacts from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2019. Data for other years have been extrapolated from trends in mortality rates.
NY.ADJ.DPEM.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DPEM.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Particulate emissions damage is the damage due to exposure of a country's population to ambient concentrations of particulates measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), ambient ozone pollution, and indoor concentrations of PM2.5 in households cooking with solid fuels. Damages are calculated as foregone labor income due to premature death. Estimates of health impacts from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2019. Data for other years have been extrapolated from trends in mortality rates.
NY.ADJ.DPEM.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.DRES.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Natural resource depletion is the sum of net forest depletion, energy depletion, and mineral depletion. Net forest depletion is unit resource rents times the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas. Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
NY.ADJ.DRES.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.ICTR.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption, plus net current transfers.
NY.ADJ.ICTR.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank national accounts data files.

NY.ADJ.NNAT.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
NY.ADJ.NNAT.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.NNAT.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
NY.ADJ.NNAT.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.NNTY.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.ZG-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.ZG-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG-adjustedSavingsInco.Indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG-adjustedSavingsInco.Definition: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG-adjustedSavingsInco.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

NY.ADJ.SVNG.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
NY.ADJ.SVNG.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.SVNG.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
NY.ADJ.SVNG.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.SVNX.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
NY.ADJ.SVNX.CD-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.ADJ.SVNX.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Definition: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
NY.ADJ.SVNX.GN.ZS-adjustedSavingsIncome.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.EXP.CAPM.KN-otherItems.Indicator: Exports as a capacity to import
NY.EXP.CAPM.KN-otherItems.Definition: Exports as a capacity to import equals the current price value of exports of goods and services deflated by the import price index. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.EXP.CAPM.KN-otherItems.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.COAL.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Coal rents are the difference between the value of both hard and soft coal production at world prices and their total costs of production.
NY.GDP.COAL.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDP.DEFL.KD.ZG-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Inflation as measured by the annual growth rate of the GDP implicit deflator shows the rate of price change in the economy as a whole. The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency.
NY.GDP.DEFL.KD.ZG-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.DEFL.KD.ZG.AD-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Inflation as measured by the annual growth rate of the GDP implicit deflator shows the rate of price change in the economy as a whole. This series has been linked to produce a consistent time series to counteract breaks in series over time due to changes in base years, source data and methodologies. Thus, it may not be comparable with other national accounts series in the database for historical years.
NY.GDP.DEFL.KD.ZG.AD-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on World Bank national accounts data archives, OECD National Accounts, and the IMF WEO database.

NY.GDP.DEFL.ZS-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
NY.GDP.DEFL.ZS-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.DEFL.ZS.AD-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: The GDP implicit deflator is calculated as the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. This series has been linked to produce a consistent time series to counteract breaks in series over time due to changes in base years, source data and methodologies. Thus, it may not be comparable with other national accounts series in the database for historical years. The base year varies by country.
NY.GDP.DEFL.ZS.AD-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on World Bank national accounts data archives, OECD National Accounts, and the IMF WEO database.

NY.GDP.DISC.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP
NY.GDP.DISC.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP is the discrepancy included in final consumption expenditure, etc. (total consumption, etc.). This discrepancy is included to ensure that GDP from the expenditure side equals GDP measured by the income or output approach. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDP.DISC.CN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.DISC.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Indicator: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP
NY.GDP.DISC.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GDP.DISC.KN-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.FCST.CD-aggregateIndicators.Indicator: Gross value added at factor cost
NY.GDP.FCST.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GDP.FCST.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.FCST.CN-aggregateIndicators.Indicator: Gross value added at factor cost
NY.GDP.FCST.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDP.FCST.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.FCST.KD-aggregateIndicators.Indicator: Gross value added at factor cost
NY.GDP.FCST.KD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NY.GDP.FCST.KD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.FCST.KN-aggregateIndicators.Indicator: Gross value added at factor cost
NY.GDP.FCST.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GDP.FCST.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.FRST.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Forest rents are roundwood harvest times the product of regional prices and a regional rental rate.
NY.GDP.FRST.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDP.MINR.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Mineral rents are the difference between the value of production for a stock of minerals at world prices and their total costs of production. Minerals included in the calculation are tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
NY.GDP.MINR.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDP.MKTP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using single year official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.
NY.GDP.MKTP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.MKTP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDP.MKTP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.MKTP.CN.AD-aggregateIndicators.Indicator: GDP at market prices: linked series
NY.GDP.MKTP.CN.AD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. This series has been linked to produce a consistent time series to counteract breaks in series over time due to changes in base years, source data and methodologies. Thus, it may not be comparable with other national accounts series in the database for historical years. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDP.MKTP.CN.AD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on World Bank national accounts data archives, OECD National Accounts, and the IMF WEO database.

NY.GDP.MKTP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using 2010 official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.
NY.GDP.MKTP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP at market prices based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources.
NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.MKTP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GDP.MKTP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition:
This indicator provides values for gross domestic product (GDP) expressed in current international dollars, converted by purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor. 
GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the country plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. PPP conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that eliminates the effects of the differences in price levels between countries. 
From April 2020, “GDP: linked series (current LCU)” [NY.GDP.MKTP.CN.AD] is used as underlying GDP in local currency unit so that it’s in line with time series of PPP conversion factors for GDP, which are extrapolated with linked GDP deflators.
NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the country plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2017 international dollars.
NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GDP.NGAS.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Natural gas rents are the difference between the value of natural gas production at regional prices and total costs of production.
NY.GDP.NGAS.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDP.PCAP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GDP.PCAP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.PCAP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDP.PCAP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.PCAP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NY.GDP.PCAP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP per capita based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources.
NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.PCAP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GDP.PCAP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition:
This indicator provides per capita values for gross domestic product (GDP) expressed in current international dollars converted by purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor. 

GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the country plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that controls for price level differences between countries. Total population is a mid-year population based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship.
NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the country plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2017 international dollars.
NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GDP.PETR.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Oil rents are the difference between the value of crude oil production at regional prices and total costs of production.
NY.GDP.PETR.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDP.TOTL.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Definition: Total natural resources rents are the sum of oil rents, natural gas rents, coal rents (hard and soft), mineral rents, and forest rents.
NY.GDP.TOTL.RT.ZS-naturalResourcesContri.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

NY.GDS.TOTL.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GDS.TOTL.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDS.TOTL.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption). Data are in current local currency.
NY.GDS.TOTL.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDS.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption).
NY.GDS.TOTL.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GDY.TOTL.KN-otherItems.Definition: Gross domestic income is derived as the sum of GDP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GDY.TOTL.KN-otherItems.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.ATLS.CD-atlasGniGniPerCapita.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current U.S. dollars. GNI, calculated in national currency, is usually converted to U.S. dollars at official exchange rates for comparisons across economies, although an alternative rate is used when the official exchange rate is judged to diverge by an exceptionally large margin from the rate actually applied in international transactions. To smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates, a special Atlas method of conversion is used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
NY.GNP.ATLS.CD-atlasGniGniPerCapita.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GNP.MKTP.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GNP.MKTP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.CN.AD-expenditureOnGdp.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad.  This series has been linked to produce a consistent time series to counteract breaks in series over time due to changes in base years, source data and methodologies. Thus, it may not be comparable with other national accounts series in the database for historical years.  Data are in local currency, at current prices.
NY.GNP.MKTP.CN.AD-expenditureOnGdp.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on World Bank national accounts data archives, OECD National Accounts, and the IMF WEO database.

NY.GNP.MKTP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NY.GNP.MKTP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad.
NY.GNP.MKTP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GNP.MKTP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.MKTP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition:
This indicator provides values for gross national income (GNI. Formerly GNP) expressed in current international dollars converted by purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor. 
Gross national income is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. PPP conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that eliminates the effects of the differences in price levels between countries.

From July 2020, “GNI: linked series (current LCU)” [NY.GNP.MKTP.CN.AD] is used as underlying GNI in local currency unit so that it’s in line with time series of PPP conversion factors, which are extrapolated with linked deflators.
NY.GNP.MKTP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GNP.MKTP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: PPP GNI (formerly PPP GNP) is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. Gross national income is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2017 international dollars.
NY.GNP.MKTP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GNP.PCAP.CD-atlasGniGniPerCapita.Definition: GNI per capita (formerly GNP per capita) is the gross national income, converted to U.S. dollars using the World Bank Atlas method, divided by the midyear population. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. GNI, calculated in national currency, is usually converted to U.S. dollars at official exchange rates for comparisons across economies, although an alternative rate is used when the official exchange rate is judged to diverge by an exceptionally large margin from the rate actually applied in international transactions. To smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates, a special Atlas method of conversion is used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
NY.GNP.PCAP.CD-atlasGniGniPerCapita.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.PCAP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GNP.PCAP.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.PCAP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
NY.GNP.PCAP.KD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.PCAP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Definition: Annual percentage growth rate of GNI per capita based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad.
NY.GNP.PCAP.KD.ZG-growthRates.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.PCAP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GNP.PCAP.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNP.PCAP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition:
This indicator provides per capita values for gross national income (GNI. Formerly GNP) expressed in current international dollars converted by purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor. 
GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. PPP conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that eliminates the effects of the differences in price levels between countries.
NY.GNP.PCAP.PP.CD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GNP.PCAP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: GNI per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GNI is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2017 international dollars.
NY.GNP.PCAP.PP.KD-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

NY.GNS.ICTR.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GNS.ICTR.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNS.ICTR.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers. Data are in current local currency.
NY.GNS.ICTR.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNS.ICTR.GN.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers.
NY.GNS.ICTR.GN.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GNS.ICTR.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Definition: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers.
NY.GNS.ICTR.ZS-sharesOfGdpOther.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GSR.NFCY.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.GSR.NFCY.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GSR.NFCY.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in current local currency.
NY.GSR.NFCY.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.GSR.NFCY.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in constant local currency.
NY.GSR.NFCY.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TAX.NIND.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.TAX.NIND.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TAX.NIND.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in current local currency.
NY.TAX.NIND.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TAX.NIND.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.TAX.NIND.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TRF.NCTR.CD-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
NY.TRF.NCTR.CD-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TRF.NCTR.CN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in current local currency.
NY.TRF.NCTR.CN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TRF.NCTR.KN-aggregateIndicators.Definition: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.TRF.NCTR.KN-aggregateIndicators.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

NY.TTF.GNFS.KN-otherItems.Definition: The terms of trade effect equals capacity to import less exports of goods and services in constant prices. Data are in constant local currency.
NY.TTF.GNFS.KN-otherItems.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

PA.NUS.ATLS-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: The DEC alternative conversion factor is the underlying annual exchange rate used for the World Bank Atlas method. As a rule, it is the official exchange rate reported in the IMF's International Financial Statistics (line rf). Exceptions arise where further refinements are made by World Bank staff. It is expressed in local currency units per U.S. dollar.
PA.NUS.ATLS-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics, supplemented by World Bank staff estimates.

PA.NUS.FCRF-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).
PA.NUS.FCRF-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

PA.NUS.PPP-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: Purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that controls for price level differences between countries, thereby allowing volume comparisons of gross domestic product (GDP) and its expenditure components. This conversion factor is for GDP.
PA.NUS.PPP-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

PA.NUS.PPPC.RF-purchasingPowerParity.Indicator: Price level ratio of PPP conversion factor
PA.NUS.PPPC.RF-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: Price level ratio is the ratio of a purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor to an exchange rate. It provides a measure of the differences in price levels between countries by indicating the number of units of the common currency needed to buy the same volume of the aggregation level in each country. At the level of GDP, they provide a measure of the differences in the general price levels of countries.
PA.NUS.PPPC.RF-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

PA.NUS.PRVT.PP-purchasingPowerParity.Definition: Purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion factor is a spatial price deflator and currency converter that controls for price level differences between countries, thereby allowing volume comparisons of gross domestic product (GDP) and its expenditure components. This conversion factor is for household final consumption expenditure.
PA.NUS.PRVT.PP-purchasingPowerParity.Source: International Comparison Program, World Bank | World Development Indicators database, World Bank | Eurostat-OECD PPP Programme.

per_allsp.adq_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Adequacy of social protection and labor programs
per_allsp.adq_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Adequacy of social protection and labor programs (SPL) is measured by the total transfer amount received by the population participating in social insurance, social safety net, and unemployment benefits and active labor market programs as a share of their total welfare. Welfare is defined as the total income or total expenditure of beneficiary households. Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_allsp.adq_pop_tot-performance.Units: % of total welfare of beneficiary households
per_allsp.adq_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_allsp.ben_q1_tot-performance.Indicator: Benefit incidence of social protection and labor programs to poorest quintile
per_allsp.ben_q1_tot-performance.Definition: Benefit incidence of social protection and labor programs (SPL) to poorest quintile shows the percentage of total social protection and labor programs benefits received by the poorest 20% of the population. Social protection and labor programs include social insurance, social safety nets, and unemployment benefits and active labor market programs. Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_allsp.ben_q1_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_allsp.cov_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Coverage of social protection and labor programs
per_allsp.cov_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Coverage of social protection and labor programs (SPL) shows the percentage of population participating in social insurance, social safety net, and unemployment benefits and active labor market programs. Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_allsp.cov_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_lm_alllm.adq_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Adequacy of unemployment benefits and ALMP
per_lm_alllm.adq_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Adequacy of unemployment benefits and active labor market programs (ALMP) is measured by the total transfer amount received by the population participating in unemployment benefits and active labor market programs as a share of their total welfare. Welfare is defined as the total income or total expenditure of beneficiary households. Unemployment benefits and active labor market programs include unemployment compensation, severance pay, and early retirement due to labor market reasons, labor market services (intermediation), training (vocational, life skills, and cash for training), job rotation and job sharing, employment incentives and wage subsidies, supported employment and rehabilitation, and employment measures for the disabled. Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_lm_alllm.adq_pop_tot-performance.Units: % of total welfare of beneficiary households
per_lm_alllm.adq_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_lm_alllm.ben_q1_tot-performance.Indicator: Benefit incidence of unemployment benefits and ALMP to poorest quintile
per_lm_alllm.ben_q1_tot-performance.Definition: Benefit incidence of unemployment benefits and active labor market programs (ALMP) to poorest quintile shows the percentage of total unemployment and active labor market programs benefits received by the poorest 20% of the population. Unemployment benefits and active labor market programs include unemployment compensation, severance pay, and early retirement due to labor market reasons, labor market services (intermediation), training (vocational, life skills, and cash for training), job rotation and job sharing, employment incentives and wage subsidies, supported employment and rehabilitation, and employment measures for the disabled. Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_lm_alllm.ben_q1_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_lm_alllm.cov_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Coverage of unemployment benefits and ALMP
per_lm_alllm.cov_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Coverage of unemployment benefits and active labor market programs (ALMP) shows the percentage of population participating in unemployment compensation, severance pay, and early retirement due to labor market reasons, labor market services (intermediation), training (vocational, life skills, and cash for training), job rotation and job sharing, employment incentives and wage subsidies, supported employment and rehabilitation, and employment measures for the disabled. per_lm_alllm.cov_q5_tot-performance.Definition: Coverage of unemployment benefits and active labor market programs (ALMP) shows the percentage of population participating in unemployment compensation, severance pay, and early retirement due to labor market reasons, labor market services (intermediation), training (vocational, life skills, and cash for training), job rotation and job sharing, employment incentives and wage subsidies, supported employment and rehabilitation, and employment measures for the disabled. per_sa_allsa.adq_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Adequacy of social safety net programs
per_sa_allsa.adq_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Adequacy of social safety net programs is measured by the total transfer amount received by the population participating in social safety net programs as a share of their total welfare. Welfare is defined as the total income or total expenditure of beneficiary households. Social safety net programs include cash transfers and last resort programs, noncontributory social pensions, other cash transfers programs (child, family and orphan allowances, birth and death grants, disability benefits, and other allowances), conditional cash transfers, in-kind food transfers (food stamps and vouchers, food rations, supplementary feeding, and emergency food distribution), school feeding, other social assistance programs (housing allowances, scholarships, fee waivers, health subsidies, and other social assistance) and public works programs (cash for work and food for work). Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_sa_allsa.adq_pop_tot-performance.Units: % of total welfare of beneficiary households
per_sa_allsa.adq_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_sa_allsa.ben_q1_tot-performance.Indicator: Benefit incidence of social safety net programs to poorest quintile
per_sa_allsa.ben_q1_tot-performance.Definition: Benefit incidence of social safety net programs to poorest quintile shows the percentage of total social safety net benefits received by the poorest 20% of the population. Social safety net programs include cash transfers and last resort programs, noncontributory social pensions, other cash transfers programs (child, family and orphan allowances, birth and death grants, disability benefits, and other allowances), conditional cash transfers, in-kind food transfers (food stamps and vouchers, food rations, supplementary feeding, and emergency food distribution), school feeding, other social assistance programs (housing allowances, scholarships, fee waivers, health subsidies, and other social assistance) and public works programs (cash for work and food for work). per_sa_allsa.cov_pop_tot-performance.Indicator: Coverage of social safety net programs
per_sa_allsa.cov_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Coverage of social safety net programs shows the percentage of population participating in cash transfers and last resort programs, noncontributory social pensions, other cash transfers programs (child, family and orphan allowances, birth and death grants, disability benefits, and other allowances), conditional cash transfers, in-kind food transfers (food stamps and vouchers, food rations, supplementary feeding, and emergency food distribution), school feeding, other social assistance programs (housing allowances, scholarships, fee waivers, health subsidies, and other social assistance) and public works programs (cash for work and food for work). Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_sa_allsa.cov_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_si_allsi.adq_pop_tot-performance.Definition: Adequacy of social insurance programs is measured by the total transfer amount received by the population participating in social insurance programs as a share of their total welfare. Welfare is defined as the total income or total expenditure of beneficiary households. Social insurance programs include old age contributory pensions (including survivors and disability) and social security and health insurance benefits (including occupational injury benefits, paid sick leave, maternity and other social insurance). Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_si_allsi.adq_pop_tot-performance.Units: % of total welfare of beneficiary households
per_si_allsi.adq_pop_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)

per_si_allsi.ben_q1_tot-performance.Indicator: Benefit incidence of social insurance programs to poorest quintile
per_si_allsi.ben_q1_tot-performance.Definition: Benefit incidence of social insurance programs to poorest quintile shows the percentage of total social insurance benefits received by the poorest 20% of the population. Social insurance programs include old age contributory pensions (including survivors and disability) and social security and health insurance benefits (including occupational injury benefits, paid sick leave, maternity and other social insurance). Estimates include both direct and indirect beneficiaries.
per_si_allsi.ben_q1_tot-performance.Source: ASPIRE: The Atlas of Social Protection - Indicators of Resilience and Equity, The World Bank. Data are based on national representative household surveys. (datatopics.worldbank.org/aspire/)
