PX.REX.REER-exchangeRatesPrices.Definition: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs.
PX.REX.REER-exchangeRatesPrices.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

SE.ADT.1524.LT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Youth literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15-24 who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.1524.LT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.1524.LT.FM.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Gender parity index for youth literacy rate is the ratio of females to males ages 15-24 who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.1524.LT.FM.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.1524.LT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Youth literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15-24 who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.1524.LT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.1524.LT.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Youth literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15-24 who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.1524.LT.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.LITR.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Adult literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15 and above who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.LITR.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.LITR.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Adult literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15 and above who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.LITR.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ADT.LITR.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Adult literacy rate is the percentage of people ages 15 and above who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement about their everyday life.
SE.ADT.LITR.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.COM.DURS-outcomes.Definition: Duration of compulsory education is the number of years that children are legally obliged to attend school.
SE.COM.DURS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ENR.PRIM.FM.ZS-participation.Definition: Gender parity index for gross enrollment ratio in primary education is the ratio of girls to boys enrolled at primary level in public and private schools.
SE.ENR.PRIM.FM.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ENR.PRSC.FM.ZS-participation.Definition: Gender parity index for gross enrollment ratio in primary and secondary education is the ratio of girls to boys enrolled at primary and secondary levels in public and private schools.
SE.ENR.PRSC.FM.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ENR.SECO.FM.ZS-participation.Definition: Gender parity index for gross enrollment ratio in secondary education is the ratio of girls to boys enrolled at secondary level in public and private schools.
SE.ENR.SECO.FM.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.ENR.TERT.FM.ZS-participation.Definition: Gender parity index for gross enrollment ratio in tertiary education is the ratio of women to men enrolled at tertiary level in public and private schools.
SE.ENR.TERT.FM.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.DURS-inputs.Definition: Preprimary duration refers to the number of grades (years) in preprimary school.
SE.PRE.DURS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Preprimary school pupil-teacher ratio is the average number of pupils per teacher in preprimary school.
SE.PRE.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRE.ENRR-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Preprimary education refers to programs at the initial stage of organized instruction, designed primarily to introduce very young children to a school-type environment and to provide a bridge between home and school.
SE.PRE.ENRR-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.ENRR.FE-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Preprimary education refers to programs at the initial stage of organized instruction, designed primarily to introduce very young children to a school-type environment and to provide a bridge between home and school.
SE.PRE.ENRR.FE-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.ENRR.MA-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Preprimary education refers to programs at the initial stage of organized instruction, designed primarily to introduce very young children to a school-type environment and to provide a bridge between home and school.
SE.PRE.ENRR.MA-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.TCAQ.FE.ZS-inputs.Definition: Trained teachers in preprimary education are the percentage of preprimary school teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country.
SE.PRE.TCAQ.FE.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.TCAQ.MA.ZS-inputs.Definition: Trained teachers in preprimary education are the percentage of preprimary school teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country.
SE.PRE.TCAQ.MA.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRE.TCAQ.ZS-inputs.Definition: Trained teachers in preprimary education are the percentage of preprimary school teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country.
SE.PRE.TCAQ.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.AGES-inputs.Definition: Primary school starting age is the age at which students would enter primary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.
SE.PRM.AGES-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CMPT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Primary completion rate, or gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education, is the number of new entrants (enrollments minus repeaters) in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the entrance age for the last grade of primary education. Data limitations preclude adjusting for students who drop out during the final year of primary education.
SE.PRM.CMPT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CMPT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Primary completion rate, or gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education, is the number of new entrants (enrollments minus repeaters) in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the entrance age for the last grade of primary education. Data limitations preclude adjusting for students who drop out during the final year of primary education.
SE.PRM.CMPT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CMPT.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Primary completion rate, or gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education, is the number of new entrants (enrollments minus repeaters) in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the entrance age for the last grade of primary education. Data limitations preclude adjusting for students who drop out during the final year of primary education.
SE.PRM.CMPT.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CUAT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed primary, population 25+ years
SE.PRM.CUAT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed primary education.
SE.PRM.CUAT.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CUAT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed primary, population 25+ years
SE.PRM.CUAT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed primary education.
SE.PRM.CUAT.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.CUAT.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed primary, population 25+ years
SE.PRM.CUAT.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed primary education.
SE.PRM.CUAT.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.DURS-outcomes.Definition: Primary duration refers to the number of grades (years) in primary school.
SE.PRM.DURS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRL-participation.Definition: Primary education pupils is the total number of pupils enrolled at primary level in public and private schools.
SE.PRM.ENRL-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRL.FE.ZS-participation.Definition: Female pupils as a percentage of total pupils at primary level include enrollments in public and private schools.
SE.PRM.ENRL.FE.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Primary school pupil-teacher ratio is the average number of pupils per teacher in primary school.
SE.PRM.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRR-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.ENRR-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRR.FE-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.ENRR.FE-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.ENRR.MA-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.ENRR.MA-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.GINT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education
SE.PRM.GINT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
SE.PRM.GINT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.GINT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education
SE.PRM.GINT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
SE.PRM.GINT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.GINT.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education
SE.PRM.GINT.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
SE.PRM.GINT.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NENR-participation.Definition: Net enrollment rate is the ratio of children of official school age who are enrolled in school to the population of the corresponding official school age. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.NENR-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NENR.FE-participation.Definition: Net enrollment rate is the ratio of children of official school age who are enrolled in school to the population of the corresponding official school age. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.NENR.FE-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NENR.MA-participation.Definition: Net enrollment rate is the ratio of children of official school age who are enrolled in school to the population of the corresponding official school age. Primary education provides children with basic reading, writing, and mathematics skills along with an elementary understanding of such subjects as history, geography, natural science, social science, art, and music.
SE.PRM.NENR.MA-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NINT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Net intake rate in grade 1 is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the corresponding age.
SE.PRM.NINT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NINT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Net intake rate in grade 1 is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the corresponding age.
SE.PRM.NINT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.NINT.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Net intake rate in grade 1 is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the corresponding age.
SE.PRM.NINT.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.OENR.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Over-age students are the percentage of those enrolled who are older than the official school-age range for primary education.
SE.PRM.OENR.FE.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.OENR.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Over-age students are the percentage of those enrolled who are older than the official school-age range for primary education.
SE.PRM.OENR.MA.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.OENR.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Over-age students are the percentage of those enrolled who are older than the official school-age range for primary education.
SE.PRM.OENR.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.PRM.PRIV.ZS-participation.Definition: Private enrollment refers to pupils or students enrolled in institutions that are not operated by a public authority but controlled and managed, whether for profit or not, by a private body such as a nongovernmental organization, religious body, special interest group, foundation or business enterprise.
SE.PRM.PRIV.ZS-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.PRS5.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Persistence to grade 5 (percentage of cohort reaching grade 5) is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 5. The estimate is based on the reconstructed cohort method.
SE.PRM.PRS5.FE.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.PRS5.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Persistence to grade 5 (percentage of cohort reaching grade 5) is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 5. The estimate is based on the reconstructed cohort method.

SE.PRM.PRSL.FE.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Persistence to last grade of primary
SE.PRM.PRSL.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Persistence to last grade of primary is the percentage of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary education. The estimate is based on the reconstructed cohort method.
SE.PRM.PRSL.FE.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.PRSL.MA.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Persistence to last grade of primary
SE.PRM.PRSL.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Persistence to last grade of primary is the percentage of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary education. The estimate is based on the reconstructed cohort method.
SE.PRM.PRSL.MA.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.PRSL.ZS-efficiency.Indicator: Persistence to last grade of primary

SE.PRM.PRSL.ZS-efficiency.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.REPT.FE.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Repeaters in primary school are the number of students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all students enrolled in primary school.

SE.PRM.REPT.MA.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Repeaters in primary school are the number of students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all students enrolled in primary school.

SE.PRM.REPT.ZS-efficiency.Definition: Repeaters in primary school are the number of students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all students enrolled in primary school.

SE.PRM.TCAQ.FE.ZS-inputs.Definition: Trained teachers in primary education are the percentage of primary school teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching in a given country.
SE.PRM.TCAQ.FE.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.PRM.TENR-participation.Definition: Adjusted net enrollment is the number of pupils of the school-age group for primary education, enrolled either in primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age group.

SE.SEC.AGES-inputs.Definition: Lower secondary school starting age is the age at which students would enter lower secondary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.

SE.SEC.CMPT.LO.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Lower secondary education completion rate is measured as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of lower secondary education (general and pre-vocational). It is calculated as the number of new entrants in the last grade of lower secondary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the entrance age for the last grade of lower secondary education.
SE.SEC.CMPT.LO.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.SEC.CMPT.LO.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: Lower secondary education completion rate is measured as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of lower secondary education (general and pre-vocational). SE.SEC.ENRR-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Secondary education completes the provision of basic education that began at the primary level, and aims at laying the foundations for lifelong learning and human development, by offering more subject- or skill-oriented instruction using more specialized teachers.
SE.SEC.ENRR-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.SEC.ENRR.FE-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. SE.SEC.ENRR.FE-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.SEC.PRIV.ZS-participation.Definition: Private enrollment refers to pupils or students enrolled in institutions that are not operated by a public authority but controlled and managed, whether for profit or not, by a private body such as a nongovernmental organization, religious body, special interest group, foundation or business enterprise.
