SE.TER.CUAT.MS.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed Master's or equivalent.
SE.TER.CUAT.MS.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.CUAT.MS.MA.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least Master's or equivalent, population 25+
SE.TER.CUAT.MS.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed Master's or equivalent.
SE.TER.CUAT.MS.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.CUAT.MS.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least Master's or equivalent, population 25+
SE.TER.CUAT.MS.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed Master's or equivalent.
SE.TER.CUAT.MS.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.CUAT.ST.FE.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed short-cycle tertiary, population 25+
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.FE.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed short-cycle tertiary education.
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.FE.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.CUAT.ST.MA.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed short-cycle tertiary, population 25+
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.MA.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed short-cycle tertiary education.
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.MA.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.CUAT.ST.ZS-outcomes.Indicator: Educational attainment, at least completed short-cycle tertiary, population 25+
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.ZS-outcomes.Definition: The percentage of population ages 25 and over that attained or completed short-cycle tertiary education.
SE.TER.CUAT.ST.ZS-outcomes.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Tertiary school pupil-teacher ratio is the average number of pupils per teacher in tertiary school.
SE.TER.ENRL.TC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.TER.ENRR-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Tertiary education, whether or not to an advanced research qualification, normally requires, as a minimum condition of admission, the successful completion of education at the secondary level.
SE.TER.ENRR-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.ENRR.FE-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Tertiary education, whether or not to an advanced research qualification, normally requires, as a minimum condition of admission, the successful completion of education at the secondary level.
SE.TER.ENRR.FE-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.ENRR.MA-participation.Definition: Gross enrollment ratio is the ratio of total enrollment, regardless of age, to the population of the age group that officially corresponds to the level of education shown. Tertiary education, whether or not to an advanced research qualification, normally requires, as a minimum condition of admission, the successful completion of education at the secondary level.
SE.TER.ENRR.MA-participation.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.TER.TCHR.FE.ZS-inputs.Definition: Tertiary education, academic staff (% female) is the share of female academic staff in tertiary education.
SE.TER.TCHR.FE.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.CPRM.ZS-inputs.Definition: Current expenditure is expressed as a percentage of direct expenditure in public educational institutions (instructional and non-instructional) of the specified level of education. Financial aid to students and other transfers are excluded from direct expenditure. Current expenditure is consumed within the current year and would have to be renewed if needed in the following year. It includes staff compensation and current expenditure other than for staff compensation (ex. on teaching materials, ancillary services and administration).
SE.XPD.CPRM.ZS-inputs.Units: % of total expenditure in primary public institutions
SE.XPD.CPRM.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.CSEC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Current expenditure is expressed as a percentage of direct expenditure in public educational institutions (instructional and non-instructional) of the specified level of education. Financial aid to students and other transfers are excluded from direct expenditure. Current expenditure is consumed within the current year and would have to be renewed if needed in the following year. It includes staff compensation and current expenditure other than for staff compensation (ex. on teaching materials, ancillary services and administration).
SE.XPD.CSEC.ZS-inputs.Units: % of total expenditure in secondary public institutions
SE.XPD.CSEC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.CTER.ZS-inputs.Definition: Current expenditure is expressed as a percentage of direct expenditure in public educational institutions (instructional and non-instructional) of the specified level of education. Financial aid to students and other transfers are excluded from direct expenditure. Current expenditure is consumed within the current year and would have to be renewed if needed in the following year. It includes staff compensation and current expenditure other than for staff compensation (ex. on teaching materials, ancillary services and administration).
SE.XPD.CTER.ZS-inputs.Units: % of total expenditure in tertiary public institutions
SE.XPD.CTER.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.CTOT.ZS-inputs.Definition: Current expenditure is expressed as a percentage of direct expenditure in public educational institutions (instructional and non-instructional) of the specified level of education. Financial aid to students and other transfers are excluded from direct expenditure. Current expenditure is consumed within the current year and would have to be renewed if needed in the following year. It includes staff compensation and current expenditure other than for staff compensation (ex. on teaching materials, ancillary services and administration).
SE.XPD.CTOT.ZS-inputs.Units: % of total expenditure in public institutions
SE.XPD.CTOT.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.PRIM.PC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Government expenditure per student is the average general government expenditure (current, capital, and transfers) per student in the given level of education, expressed as a percentage of GDP per capita.
SE.XPD.PRIM.PC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.PRIM.ZS-inputs.Definition: Expenditure on primary education is expressed as a percentage of total general government expenditure on education. General government usually refers to local, regional and central governments.
SE.XPD.PRIM.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.SECO.PC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Government expenditure per student is the average general government expenditure (current, capital, and transfers) per student in the given level of education, expressed as a percentage of GDP per capita.
SE.XPD.SECO.PC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.SECO.ZS-inputs.Definition: Expenditure on secondary education is expressed as a percentage of total general government expenditure on education. General government usually refers to local, regional and central governments.
SE.XPD.SECO.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.TERT.PC.ZS-inputs.Definition: Government expenditure per student is the average general government expenditure (current, capital, and transfers) per student in the given level of education, expressed as a percentage of GDP per capita.
SE.XPD.TERT.PC.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.TERT.ZS-inputs.Definition: Expenditure on tertiary education is expressed as a percentage of total general government expenditure on education. General government usually refers to local, regional and central governments.
SE.XPD.TERT.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of February 2020.

SE.XPD.TOTL.GB.ZS-inputs.Definition: General government expenditure on education (current, capital, and transfers) is expressed as a percentage of total general government expenditure on all sectors (including health, education, social services, etc.). It includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government. General government usually refers to local, regional and central governments.
SE.XPD.TOTL.GB.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SE.XPD.TOTL.GD.ZS-inputs.Definition: General government expenditure on education (current, capital, and transfers) is expressed as a percentage of GDP. It includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government. General government usually refers to local, regional and central governments.
SE.XPD.TOTL.GD.ZS-inputs.Source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (http://uis.unesco.org/). Data as of September 2020.

SG.DMK.ALLD.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Indicator: Women participating in the three decisions
SG.DMK.ALLD.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Definition: Women participating in the three decisions (own health care, major household purchases, and visiting family) is the percentage of currently married women aged 15-49 who say that they alone or jointly have the final say in all of the three decisions (own health care, large purchases and visits to family, relatives, and friends).
SG.DMK.ALLD.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Units: own health care, major household purchases, and visiting family) (% of women age 15-49

SG.DMK.SRCR.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Indicator: Women making their own informed decisions regarding sexual relations, contraceptive use and reproductive health care
SG.DMK.SRCR.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Definition: Proportion of women ages 15-49 years (married or in union) who make their own decision on all three selected areas i.e. can say no to sexual intercourse with their husband or partner if they do not want; decide on use of contraception; and decide on their own health care. Only women who provide a “yes” answer to all three components are considered as women who “make her own decisions regarding sexual and reproductive”.
SG.DMK.SRCR.FN.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaki.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys compiled by United Nations Population Fund

SG.GEN.PARL.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Indicator: Proportion of seats held by women in national parliaments
SG.GEN.PARL.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Definition: Women in parliaments are the percentage of parliamentary seats in a single or lower chamber held by women.
SG.GEN.PARL.ZS-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Source: Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) (www.ipu.org).  For the year of 1998, the data is as of August 10, 1998.

SG.LAW.INDX-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Indicator: Women Business and the Law Index Score
SG.LAW.INDX-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Definition: The index measures how laws and regulations affect women’s economic opportunity.  Overall scores are calculated by taking the average score of each of the eight areas (Going Places, Starting a Job, Getting Paid, Getting Married, Having Children, Running a Business, Managing Assets and Getting a Pension), with 100 representing the highest possible score.
SG.LAW.INDX-publicLifeDecisionMaking.Source: World Bank: Women, Business and the Law. https://wbl.worldbank.org/

SG.TIM.UWRK.FE-participationAccess.Indicator: Proportion of time spent on unpaid domestic and care work
SG.TIM.UWRK.FE-participationAccess.Definition: The average time women spend on household provision of services for own consumption. Data are expressed as a proportion of time in a day. Domestic and care work includes food preparation, dishwashing, cleaning and upkeep of a dwelling, laundry, ironing, gardening, caring for pets, shopping, installation, servicing and repair of personal and household goods, childcare, and care of the sick, elderly or disabled household members, among others.
SG.TIM.UWRK.FE-participationAccess.Source:
National statistical offices or national database and publications compiled by United Nations Statistics Division.  The data were downloaded on December 3 from the Global SDG Indicators Database: 
https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/

SG.TIM.UWRK.MA-participationAccess.Indicator: Proportion of time spent on unpaid domestic and care work
SG.TIM.UWRK.MA-participationAccess.Definition: The average time men spend on household provision of services for own consumption.  Data are expressed as a proportion of time in a day. Domestic and care work includes food preparation, dishwashing, cleaning and upkeep of a dwelling, laundry, ironing, gardening, caring for pets, shopping, installation, servicing and repair of personal and household goods, childcare, and care of the sick, elderly or disabled household members, among others.
SG.TIM.UWRK.MA-participationAccess.Source: National statistical offices or national database and publications compiled by United Nations Statistics Division

SG.VAW.1549.ZS-health.Indicator: Proportion of women subjected to physical and/or sexual violence in the last 12 months
SG.VAW.1549.ZS-health.Definition: Proportion of women subjected to physical and/or sexual violence in the last 12 months is the percentage of ever partnered women age 15-49 who are subjected to physical violence, sexual violence or both by a current or former intimate partner in the last 12 months.

SG.VAW.ARGU.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him
SG.VAW.ARGU.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him.
SG.VAW.ARGU.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SG.VAW.BURN.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she burns the food
SG.VAW.BURN.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she burns the food.
SG.VAW.BURN.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SG.VAW.GOES.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she goes out without telling him
SG.VAW.GOES.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she goes out without telling him.
SG.VAW.GOES.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SG.VAW.NEGL.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she neglects the children
SG.VAW.NEGL.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she neglects the children.
SG.VAW.NEGL.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SG.VAW.REAS.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife
SG.VAW.REAS.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner for any of the following five reasons: argues with him; refuses to have sex; burns the food; goes out without telling him; or when she neglects the children.
SG.VAW.REAS.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SG.VAW.REFU.ZS-health.Indicator: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she refuses sex with him
SG.VAW.REFU.ZS-health.Definition: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she refuses sex with him.
SG.VAW.REFU.ZS-health.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys

SH.ALC.PCAP.FE.LI-riskFactors.Definition: Total alcohol per capita consumption is defined as the total (sum of recorded and unrecorded alcohol) amount of alcohol consumed per person (15 years of age or older) over a calendar year, in litres of pure alcohol, adjusted for tourist consumption.
SH.ALC.PCAP.FE.LI-riskFactors.Units: liters of pure alcohol, projected estimates, female 15+ years of age
SH.ALC.PCAP.FE.LI-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.ALC.PCAP.LI-riskFactors.Definition: Total alcohol per capita consumption is defined as the total (sum of recorded and unrecorded alcohol) amount of alcohol consumed per person (15 years of age or older) over a calendar year, in litres of pure alcohol, adjusted for tourist consumption.
SH.ALC.PCAP.LI-riskFactors.Units: liters of pure alcohol, projected estimates, 15+ years of age
SH.ALC.PCAP.LI-riskFactors.Dimension: liters of pure alcohol, projected estimates, 15+ years of age
SH.ALC.PCAP.LI-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.ALC.PCAP.MA.LI-riskFactors.Definition: Total alcohol per capita consumption is defined as the total (sum of recorded and unrecorded alcohol) amount of alcohol consumed per person (15 years of age or older) over a calendar year, in litres of pure alcohol, adjusted for tourist consumption.
SH.ALC.PCAP.MA.LI-riskFactors.Units: liters of pure alcohol, projected estimates, male 15+ years of age
SH.ALC.PCAP.MA.LI-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.ANM.ALLW.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of anemia among women of reproductive age
SH.ANM.ALLW.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of anemia among women of reproductive age refers to the combined prevalence of both non-pregnant with haemoglobin levels below 12 g/dL and pregnant women with haemoglobin levels below 11 g/dL.
SH.ANM.ALLW.ZS-nutrition.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository/World Health Statistics.

SH.ANM.CHLD.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of anemia, children ages 6-59 months, is the percentage of children ages 6-59 months whose hemoglobin level is less than 110 grams per liter, adjusted for altitude.
SH.ANM.CHLD.ZS-nutrition.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository/World Health Statistics.

SH.ANM.NPRG.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of anemia among non-pregnant women
SH.ANM.NPRG.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of anemia, non-pregnant women, is the percentage of non-pregnant women whose hemoglobin level is less than 120 grams per liter at sea level.
SH.ANM.NPRG.ZS-nutrition.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository/World Health Statistics.

SH.CON.1524.FE.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Condom use, female is the percentage of the female population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.
SH.CON.1524.FE.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys, and UNAIDS.

SH.CON.1524.MA.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Condom use, male is the percentage of the male population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.
SH.CON.1524.MA.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys, and UNAIDS.

SH.DTH.0509-mortality.Definition: Number of deaths of children ages 5-9 years
SH.DTH.0509-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.1014-mortality.Definition: Number of deaths of adolescents ages 10-14 years
SH.DTH.1014-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.1519-mortality.Definition: Number of deaths of adolescents ages 15-19 years
SH.DTH.1519-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.2024-mortality.Definition: Number of deaths of youths ages 20-24 years
SH.DTH.2024-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.COMM.ZS-riskFactors.Indicator: Cause of death, by communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions
SH.DTH.COMM.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions include infectious and parasitic diseases, respiratory infections, and nutritional deficiencies such as underweight and stunting.
SH.DTH.COMM.ZS-riskFactors.Source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

SH.DTH.IMRT-mortality.Definition: Number of infants dying before reaching one year of age.
SH.DTH.IMRT-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.INJR.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Injuries include unintentional and intentional injuries.
SH.DTH.INJR.ZS-riskFactors.Source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

SH.DTH.MORT-mortality.Definition: Number of children dying before reaching age five.
SH.DTH.MORT-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DTH.NCOM.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Non-communicable diseases include cancer, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, digestive diseases, skin diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, and congenital anomalies.
SH.DTH.NCOM.ZS-riskFactors.Source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

SH.DTH.NMRT-mortality.Definition: Number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age.
SH.DTH.NMRT-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.0509-mortality.Indicator: Probability of dying among children ages 5-9 years
SH.DYN.0509-mortality.Definition: Probability of dying between age 5-9 years of age expressed per 1,000 children aged 5, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.0509-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.1014-mortality.Indicator: Probability of dying among adolescents ages 10-14 years
SH.DYN.1014-mortality.Definition: Probability of dying between age 10-14 years of age expressed per 1,000 adolescents age 10, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.1014-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.1519-mortality.Indicator: Probability of dying among adolescents ages 15-19 years
SH.DYN.1519-mortality.Definition: Probability of dying between age 15-19 years of age expressed per 1,000 adolescents age 15, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.1519-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.2024-mortality.Indicator: Probability of dying among youth ages 20-24 years
SH.DYN.2024-mortality.Definition: Probability of dying between age 20-24 years of age expressed per 1,000 youths age 20, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.2024-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.AIDS.FE.ZS-riskFactors.Indicator: Women's share of population ages 15+ living with HIV
SH.DYN.AIDS.FE.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Female rate is as a percentage of the total population ages 15+ who are living with HIV.

SH.DYN.AIDS.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.

SH.DYN.MORT-mortality.Definition: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.MORT-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.MORT.FE-mortality.Definition: Under-five mortality rate, female is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn female baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to female age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.MORT.FE-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.MORT.MA-mortality.Definition: Under-five mortality rate, male is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn male baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to male age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
SH.DYN.MORT.MA-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.DYN.NCOM.FE.ZS-mortality.Indicator: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD between exact ages 30 and 70
SH.DYN.NCOM.FE.ZS-mortality.Definition: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD is the percent of 30-year-old-people who would die before their 70th birthday from any of cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes,  or chronic respiratory disease, assuming that s/he would experience current mortality rates at every age and s/he would not die from any other cause of death (e.g., injuries or HIV/AIDS).
SH.DYN.NCOM.FE.ZS-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.DYN.NCOM.MA.ZS-mortality.Indicator: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD between exact ages 30 and 70
SH.DYN.NCOM.MA.ZS-mortality.Definition: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD is the percent of 30-year-old-people who would die before their 70th birthday from any of cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes,  or chronic respiratory disease, assuming that s/he would experience current mortality rates at every age and s/he would not die from any other cause of death (e.g., injuries or HIV/AIDS).
SH.DYN.NCOM.MA.ZS-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.DYN.NCOM.ZS-mortality.Indicator: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD between exact ages 30 and 70
SH.DYN.NCOM.ZS-mortality.Definition: Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes or CRD is the percent of 30-year-old-people who would die before their 70th birthday from any of cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes,  or chronic respiratory disease, assuming that s/he would experience current mortality rates at every age and s/he would not die from any other cause of death (e.g., injuries or HIV/AIDS).
SH.DYN.NCOM.ZS-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.DYN.NMRT-mortality.Definition: Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.
SH.DYN.NMRT-mortality.Source: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

SH.FPL.SATM.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Indicator: Demand for family planning satisfied by modern methods
SH.FPL.SATM.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Demand for family planning satisfied by modern methods refers to the percentage of married women ages 15-49 years whose need for family planning is satisfied with modern methods.
SH.FPL.SATM.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Units: % of married women with demand for family planning

SH.H2O.BASW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic drinking water services
SH.H2O.BASW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic water services.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic water services as well as those using safely managed water services.  Basic drinking water services is defined as drinking water from an improved source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip.  Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.BASW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.H2O.BASW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic drinking water services
SH.H2O.BASW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic water services.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic water services as well as those using safely managed water services.  Basic drinking water services is defined as drinking water from an improved source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip.  Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.BASW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.H2O.BASW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic drinking water services
SH.H2O.BASW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic water services.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic water services as well as those using safely managed water services.  Basic drinking water services is defined as drinking water from an improved source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip.  Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.BASW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.H2O.SMDW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed drinking water services
SH.H2O.SMDW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using drinking water from an improved source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.SMDW.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.H2O.SMDW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed drinking water services
SH.H2O.SMDW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using drinking water from an improved source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.SMDW.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.H2O.SMDW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed drinking water services
SH.H2O.SMDW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using drinking water from an improved source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
SH.H2O.SMDW.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.HIV.0014-riskFactors.Definition: Children living with HIV refers to the number of children ages 0-14 who are infected with HIV.

SH.HIV.1524.FE.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Prevalence of HIV, female is the percentage of females who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.

SH.HIV.1524.MA.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Prevalence of HIV, male is the percentage of males who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.

SH.HIV.ARTC.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Antiretroviral therapy coverage indicates the percentage of all people living with HIV who are receiving antiretroviral therapy.

SH.HIV.INCD-riskFactors.Definition: Number of adults (ages 15-49) newly infected with HIV.

SH.HIV.INCD.14-riskFactors.Definition: Number of children (ages 0-14) newly infected with HIV.

SH.HIV.INCD.TL-riskFactors.Definition: Number of adults (ages 15+) and children (ages 0-14) newly infected with HIV.

SH.HIV.INCD.TL.P3-riskFactors.Definition: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected populations expressed per 1,000 uninfected population in the year before the period.

SH.HIV.INCD.YG-riskFactors.Definition: Number of young people (ages 15-24) newly infected with HIV.

SH.HIV.INCD.YG.P3-riskFactors.Definition: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected populations ages 15-24 expressed per 1,000 uninfected population ages 15-24 in the year before the period.

SH.HIV.INCD.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Number of new HIV infections among uninfected populations ages 15-49 expressed per 1,000 uninfected population in the year before the period.

SH.HIV.PMTC.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Percentage of pregnant women with HIV who receive antiretroviral medicine for prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT).
SH.HIV.PMTC.ZS-riskFactors.Units: % of pregnant women living with HIV

SH.IMM.HEPB-diseasePrevention.Definition: Child immunization rate, hepatitis B is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received hepatitis B vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.

SH.IMM.IDPT-diseasePrevention.Definition: Child immunization, DPT, measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received DPT vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against diphtheria, pertussis (or whooping cough), and tetanus (DPT) after receiving three doses of vaccine.

SH.IMM.MEAS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Child immunization, measles, measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received the measles vaccination before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against measles after receiving one dose of vaccine.

SH.MED.BEDS.ZS-healthSystems.Definition: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.
SH.MED.BEDS.ZS-healthSystems.Source: Data are from the World Health Organization, supplemented by country data.

SH.MED.CMHW.P3-healthSystems.Definition: Community health workers include various types of community health aides, many with country-specific occupational titles such as community health officers, community health-education workers, family health workers, lady health visitors and health extension package workers.
SH.MED.CMHW.P3-healthSystems.Source: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

SH.MED.NUMW.P3-healthSystems.Definition: Nurses and midwives include professional nurses, professional midwives, auxiliary nurses, auxiliary midwives, enrolled nurses, enrolled midwives and other associated personnel, such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
SH.MED.NUMW.P3-healthSystems.Source: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

SH.MED.PHYS.ZS-healthSystems.Definition: Physicians include generalist and specialist medical practitioners.
SH.MED.PHYS.ZS-healthSystems.Source: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

SH.MED.SAOP.P5-healthSystems.Definition: Specialist surgical workforce is the number of specialist surgical, anaesthetic, and obstetric (SAO) providers who are working in each country per 100,000 population.
SH.MED.SAOP.P5-healthSystems.Source: Data collected by the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery (www.lancetglobalsurgery.org); Data collected by WHO Collaborating Centre for Surgery and Public Health at Lund University from various sources including Ministries of Health or equivalent national regulatory bodies, national official entities such as medical councils, Eurostat, OECD, WHO Euro Health For All Database, WHO EURO Technical resources for health Database; BMJ Glob Health.

SH.MLR.INCD.P3-riskFactors.Definition: Incidence of malaria is the number of new cases of malaria in a year per 1,000 population at risk.
SH.MLR.INCD.P3-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository/World Health Statistics (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.MLR.NETS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets refers to the percentage of children under age five who slept under an insecticide-treated bednet to prevent malaria.
SH.MLR.NETS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.MLR.TRET.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs
SH.MLR.TRET.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
SH.MLR.TRET.ZS-diseasePrevention.Units: % of children under age 5 with fever
SH.MLR.TRET.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.MMR.DTHS-reproductiveHealth.Definition: A maternal death refers to the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.
SH.MMR.DTHS-reproductiveHealth.Source: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 2000 to 2017. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2019

SH.MMR.RISK-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
SH.MMR.RISK-reproductiveHealth.Source: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 2000 to 2017. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2019

SH.MMR.RISK.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
SH.MMR.RISK.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Source: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 2000 to 2017. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2019

SH.PRG.ANEM-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of anemia among pregnant women
SH.PRG.ANEM-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of anemia, pregnant women, is the percentage of pregnant women whose hemoglobin level is less than 110 grams per liter at sea level.
SH.PRG.ANEM-nutrition.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository/World Health Statistics.

SH.PRV.SMOK-riskFactors.Definition: The percentage of the population ages 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis. Tobacco products include cigarettes, pipes, cigars, cigarillos, waterpipes (hookah, shisha), bidis, kretek, heated tobacco products, and all forms of smokeless (oral and nasal) tobacco. Tobacco products exclude e-cigarettes (which do not contain tobacco), “e-cigars”, “e-hookahs”, JUUL and “e-pipes”. The rates are age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population.
SH.PRV.SMOK-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.PRV.SMOK.FE-riskFactors.Definition: The percentage of the female population ages 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis. Tobacco products include cigarettes, pipes, cigars, cigarillos, waterpipes (hookah, shisha), bidis, kretek, heated tobacco products, and all forms of smokeless (oral and nasal) tobacco. Tobacco products exclude e-cigarettes (which do not contain tobacco), “e-cigars”, “e-hookahs”, JUUL and “e-pipes”. The rates are age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population.
SH.PRV.SMOK.FE-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.PRV.SMOK.MA-riskFactors.Definition: The percentage of the male population ages 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis. Tobacco products include cigarettes, pipes, cigars, cigarillos, waterpipes (hookah, shisha), bidis, kretek, heated tobacco products, and all forms of smokeless (oral and nasal) tobacco. Tobacco products exclude e-cigarettes (which do not contain tobacco), “e-cigars”, “e-hookahs”, JUUL and “e-pipes”. The rates are age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population.
SH.PRV.SMOK.MA-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.SGR.CRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Indicator: Risk of catastrophic expenditure for surgical care
SH.SGR.CRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: The proportion of population at risk of catastrophic expenditure when surgical care is required. Catastrophic expenditure is defined as direct out of pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia care exceeding 10% of total income.
SH.SGR.CRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Source: The Program in Global Surgery and Social Change (PGSSC) at Harvard Medical School (https://www.pgssc.org/)

SH.SGR.IRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Indicator: Risk of impoverishing expenditure for surgical care
SH.SGR.IRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: The proportion of population at risk of impoverishing expenditure when surgical care is required. Impoverishing expenditure is defined as direct out of pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia care which drive people below a poverty threshold (using a threshold of $1.90 PPP/day).
SH.SGR.IRSK.ZS-riskFactors.Source: The Program in Global Surgery and Social Change (PGSSC) at Harvard Medical School (https://www.pgssc.org/)

SH.SGR.PROC.P5-healthSystems.Definition: The number of procedures undertaken in an operating theatre per 100,000 population per year in each country. A procedure is defined as the incision, excision, or manipulation of tissue that needs regional or general anaesthesia, or profound sedation to control pain.
SH.SGR.PROC.P5-healthSystems.Source: The Lancet Commission on Global Surgery (www.lancetglobalsurgery.org).

SH.STA.AIRP.FE.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution, age-standardized
SH.STA.AIRP.FE.P5-mortality.Definition: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution is the number of deaths attributable to the joint effects of household and ambient air pollution in a year per 100,000 population. The rates are age-standardized.  Following diseases are taken into account: acute respiratory infections (estimated for all ages); cerebrovascular diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); ischaemic heart diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in adults (estimated above 25 years); and lung cancer in adults (estimated above 25 years).
SH.STA.AIRP.FE.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.AIRP.MA.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution, age-standardized
SH.STA.AIRP.MA.P5-mortality.Definition: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution is the number of deaths attributable to the joint effects of household and ambient air pollution in a year per 100,000 population. The rates are age-standardized.  Following diseases are taken into account: acute respiratory infections (estimated for all ages); cerebrovascular diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); ischaemic heart diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in adults (estimated above 25 years); and lung cancer in adults (estimated above 25 years).
SH.STA.AIRP.MA.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.AIRP.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution, age-standardized
SH.STA.AIRP.P5-mortality.Definition: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution is the number of deaths attributable to the joint effects of household and ambient air pollution in a year per 100,000 population. The rates are age-standardized.  Following diseases are taken into account: acute respiratory infections (estimated for all ages); cerebrovascular diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); ischaemic heart diseases in adults (estimated above 25 years); chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in adults (estimated above 25 years); and lung cancer in adults (estimated above 25 years).
SH.STA.AIRP.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.ANVC.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care are the percentage of women attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
SH.STA.ANVC.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.ARIC.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Children with acute respiratory infection (ARI) who are taken to a health provider refers to the percentage of children under age five with ARI in the last two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider, including hospital, health center, dispensary, village health worker, clinic, and private physician.
SH.STA.ARIC.ZS-diseasePrevention.Units: % of children under 5 taken to a health provider
SH.STA.ARIC.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.BASS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic sanitation services
SH.STA.BASS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic sanitation services, that is, improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic sanitation services as well as those using safely managed sanitation services.   Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.BASS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.BASS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic sanitation services
SH.STA.BASS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic sanitation services, that is, improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic sanitation services as well as those using safely managed sanitation services.   Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.BASS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.BASS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using at least basic sanitation services
SH.STA.BASS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using at least basic sanitation services, that is, improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic sanitation services as well as those using safely managed sanitation services.   Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.BASS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.BFED.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Exclusive breastfeeding refers to the percentage of children less than six months old who are fed breast milk alone (no other liquids) in the past 24 hours.
SH.STA.BFED.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.BRTC.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Indicator: Births attended by skilled health staff
SH.STA.BRTC.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.
SH.STA.BRTC.ZS-reproductiveHealth.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.BRTW.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Low-birthweight babies are newborns weighing less than 2,500 grams, with the measurement taken within the first hour of life, before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.

SH.STA.DIAB.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Diabetes prevalence refers to the percentage of people ages 20-79 who have type 1 or type 2 diabetes. It is calculated by adjusting to a standard population age-structure.

SH.STA.FGMS.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: Percentage of women aged 15–49 who have gone through partial or total removal of the female external genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for cultural or other non-therapeutic reasons.
SH.STA.FGMS.ZS-riskFactors.Source: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), and other surveys: STATcompiler (http://www.statcompiler.com/) as of Auguest 28, 2020, UNICEF DATA (http://www.data.unicef.org/) as of August 30, 2020.

SH.STA.HYGN.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People with basic handwashing facilities including soap and water
SH.STA.HYGN.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people living in households that have a handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. Handwashing facilities may be fixed or mobile and include a sink with tap water, buckets with taps, tippy-taps, and jugs or basins designated for handwashing. Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, powder detergent, and soapy water but does not include ash, soil, sand or other handwashing agents.
SH.STA.HYGN.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.HYGN.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People with basic handwashing facilities including soap and water
SH.STA.HYGN.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people living in households that have a handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. Handwashing facilities may be fixed or mobile and include a sink with tap water, buckets with taps, tippy-taps, and jugs or basins designated for handwashing. Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, powder detergent, and soapy water but does not include ash, soil, sand or other handwashing agents.
SH.STA.HYGN.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.HYGN.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People with basic handwashing facilities including soap and water
SH.STA.HYGN.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people living in households that have a handwashing facility with soap and water available on the premises. Handwashing facilities may be fixed or mobile and include a sink with tap water, buckets with taps, tippy-taps, and jugs or basins designated for handwashing. Soap includes bar soap, liquid soap, powder detergent, and soapy water but does not include ash, soil, sand or other handwashing agents.
SH.STA.HYGN.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.MALN.FE.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age
SH.STA.MALN.FE.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of underweight, female, is the percentage of girls under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.MALN.FE.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.MALN.MA.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age
SH.STA.MALN.MA.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of underweight, male, is the percentage of boys under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.MALN.MA.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.MALN.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age
SH.STA.MALN.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of underweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.MALN.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.MMRT-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on the proportion of maternal deaths among non-AIDS deaths in women ages 15-49, fertility, birth attendants, and GDP measured using purchasing power parities (PPPs).
SH.STA.MMRT-reproductiveHealth.Source: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, World Bank Group, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 2000 to 2017. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2019

SH.STA.MMRT.NE-reproductiveHealth.Definition: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births.
SH.STA.MMRT.NE-reproductiveHealth.Source: The country data compiled, adjusted and used in the estimation model by the Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-Agency Group (MMEIG). The country data were compiled from the following sources:  civil registration and vital statistics; specialized studies on maternal mortality; population based surveys and censuses; other available data sources including data from surveillance sites.

SH.STA.ODFC.RU.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: People practicing open defecation refers to the percentage of the population defecating in the open, such as in fields, forest, bushes, open bodies of water, on beaches, in other open spaces or disposed of with solid waste.
SH.STA.ODFC.RU.ZS-riskFactors.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

SH.STA.ODFC.UR.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: People practicing open defecation refers to the percentage of the population defecating in the open, such as in fields, forest, bushes, open bodies of water, on beaches, in other open spaces or disposed of with solid waste.
SH.STA.ODFC.UR.ZS-riskFactors.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

SH.STA.ODFC.ZS-riskFactors.Definition: People practicing open defecation refers to the percentage of the population defecating in the open, such as in fields, forest, bushes, open bodies of water, on beaches, in other open spaces or disposed of with solid waste.
SH.STA.ODFC.ZS-riskFactors.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

SH.STA.ORCF.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Children with diarrhea who received oral rehydration and continued feeding refer to the percentage of children under age five with diarrhea in the two weeks prior to the survey who received either oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids, with continued feeding.
SH.STA.ORCF.ZS-diseasePrevention.Units: % of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding
SH.STA.ORCF.ZS-diseasePrevention.Dimension: % of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding
SH.STA.ORCF.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.ORTH-diseasePrevention.Definition: Percentage of children under age 5 with diarrhea in the two weeks preceding the survey who received oral rehydration salts (ORS packets or pre-packaged ORS fluids).
SH.STA.ORTH-diseasePrevention.Units: % of children under 5 who received ORS packet
SH.STA.ORTH-diseasePrevention.Dimension: % of children under 5 who received ORS packet
SH.STA.ORTH-diseasePrevention.Source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

SH.STA.OWGH.FE.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of overweight, weight for height
SH.STA.OWGH.FE.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of overweight, female, is the percentage of girls under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.OWGH.FE.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.OWGH.MA.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of overweight, weight for height
SH.STA.OWGH.MA.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of overweight, male, is the percentage of boys under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.OWGH.MA.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.OWGH.ME.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.OWGH.ME.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME).

SH.STA.OWGH.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.OWGH.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.POIS.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisoning
SH.STA.POIS.P5-mortality.Definition:
Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisonings is the number of deaths from unintentional poisonings in a year per 100,000 population.  Unintentional poisoning can
be caused by household chemicals, pesticides, kerosene, carbon monoxide and medicines, or can be the result of environmental contamination or occupational chemical exposure.
SH.STA.POIS.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.POIS.P5.FE-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisoning
SH.STA.POIS.P5.FE-mortality.Definition: Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisonings is the number of female deaths from unintentional poisonings in a year per 100,000 female population.  Unintentional poisoning can be caused by household chemicals, pesticides, kerosene, carbon monoxide and medicines, or can be the result of environmental contamination or occupational chemical exposure.
SH.STA.POIS.P5.FE-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.POIS.P5.MA-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisoning
SH.STA.POIS.P5.MA-mortality.Definition:
Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisonings is the number of male deaths from unintentional poisonings in a year per 100,000 male population. Unintentional poisoning can
be caused by household chemicals, pesticides, kerosene, carbon monoxide and medicines, or can be the result of environmental contamination or occupational chemical exposure.
SH.STA.POIS.P5.MA-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.SMSS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed sanitation services
SH.STA.SMSS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of in situ or transported and treated offsite. Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines: ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.SMSS.RU.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.SMSS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed sanitation services
SH.STA.SMSS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of in situ or transported and treated offsite. Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines: ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.SMSS.UR.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.SMSS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Indicator: People using safely managed sanitation services
SH.STA.SMSS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: The percentage of people using improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of in situ or transported and treated offsite. Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines: ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
SH.STA.SMSS.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (washdata.org).

SH.STA.STNT.FE.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of stunting, height for age
SH.STA.STNT.FE.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of stunting, female, is the percentage of girls under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.STNT.FE.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.STNT.MA.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of stunting, height for age
SH.STA.STNT.MA.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of stunting, male, is the percentage of boys under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.STNT.MA.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.STNT.ME.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of stunting is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.STNT.ME.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME).

SH.STA.STNT.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of stunting is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
SH.STA.STNT.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.SUIC.FE.P5-mortality.Definition: Suicide mortality rate is the number of suicide deaths in a year per 100,000 population. Crude suicide rate (not age-adjusted).
SH.STA.SUIC.FE.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.SUIC.MA.P5-mortality.Definition: Suicide mortality rate is the number of suicide deaths in a year per 100,000 population. Crude suicide rate (not age-adjusted).
SH.STA.SUIC.MA.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.SUIC.P5-mortality.Definition: Suicide mortality rate is the number of suicide deaths in a year per 100,000 population. Crude suicide rate (not age-adjusted).
SH.STA.SUIC.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.TRAF.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality caused by road traffic injury
SH.STA.TRAF.P5-mortality.Definition: Mortality caused by road traffic injury is estimated road traffic fatal injury deaths per 100,000 population.
SH.STA.TRAF.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.WASH.P5-mortality.Indicator: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene
SH.STA.WASH.P5-mortality.Definition: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene is deaths attributable to unsafe water, sanitation and hygiene focusing on inadequate WASH services per 100,000 population. Death rates are calculated by dividing the number of deaths by the total population. In this estimate, only the impact of diarrhoeal diseases, intestinal nematode infections, and protein-energy malnutrition are taken into account.
SH.STA.WASH.P5-mortality.Source: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

SH.STA.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height
SH.STA.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of wasting, female, is the proportion of girls under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.STA.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height
SH.STA.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of wasting, male,is the proportion of boys under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.STA.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.STA.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height
SH.STA.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of wasting is the proportion of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.STA.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.SVR.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height
SH.SVR.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of severe wasting, female, is the proportion of girls under age 5 whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.SVR.WAST.FE.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.SVR.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height
SH.SVR.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of severe wasting, male, is the proportion of boys under age 5 whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.SVR.WAST.MA.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.SVR.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Indicator: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height
SH.SVR.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Definition: Prevalence of severe wasting is the proportion of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
SH.SVR.WAST.ZS-nutrition.Source: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank: Joint child malnutrition estimates (JME). Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

SH.TBS.CURE.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Tuberculosis treatment success rate is the percentage of all new tuberculosis cases (or new and relapse cases for some countries) registered under a national tuberculosis control programme in a given year that successfully completed treatment, with or without bacteriological evidence of success ("cured" and "treatment completed" respectively).
SH.TBS.CURE.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

SH.TBS.DTEC.ZS-diseasePrevention.Definition: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms) is the number of new and relapse tuberculosis cases notified to WHO in a given year, divided by WHO's estimate of the number of incident tuberculosis cases for the same year, expressed as a percentage. Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
SH.TBS.DTEC.ZS-diseasePrevention.Source: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

SH.TBS.INCD-riskFactors.Definition: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new and relapse tuberculosis cases arising in a given year, expressed as the rate per 100,000 population. All forms of TB are included, including cases in people living with HIV. Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
SH.TBS.INCD-riskFactors.Source: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

SH.UHC.OOPC.10.TO-universalHealthCoverag.Definition: Catastrophic Health Expenditure, 10% of total expenditure/income
SH.UHC.OOPC.10.TO-universalHealthCoverag.Source: World Health Organization and World Bank. 2019. Global Monitoring Report on Financial Protection in Health 2019.

SH.UHC.OOPC.10.ZS-universalHealthCoverag.Definition: Catastrophic Health Expenditure, 10% of total expenditure/income (%)
SH.UHC.OOPC.10.ZS-universalHealthCoverag.Source: World Health Organization and World Bank. 2019. Global Monitoring Report on Financial Protection in Health 2019.

SH.UHC.OOPC.25.TO-universalHealthCoverag.Definition: Catastrophic Health Expenditure, 25% of total expenditure/income (thousands)
SH.UHC.OOPC.25.TO-universalHealthCoverag.Source: World Health Organization and World Bank. 2019. Global Monitoring Report on Financial Protection in Health 2019.
