key-DT.ODA.ODAT.PC.ZS-finance.Definition: Net official development assistance per capita is disbursement flows (net of repayment of principal) that meet the DAC definition of ODA and are made to countries and territories on the DAC list of aid recipients; and is calculated by dividing net ODA received by the midyear population estimate.
key-DT.ODA.ODAT.PC.ZS-finance.Source: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline. World Bank population estimates are used for the denominator.

key-DT.ODA.ODAT.GN.ZS-finance.Definition: Net official development assistance is disbursement flows (net of repayment of principal) that meet the DAC definition of ODA and are made to countries and territories on the DAC list of aid recipients.
key-DT.ODA.ODAT.GN.ZS-finance.Source: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline. World Bank GNI estimates are used for the denominator.

key-NE.TRD.GNFS.ZS-finance.Definition: Trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services measured as a share of gross domestic product.
key-NE.TRD.GNFS.ZS-finance.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

key-NY.GDP.MKTP.CD-finance.Definition: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using single year official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.
key-NY.GDP.MKTP.CD-finance.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

key-NY.GDP.PCAP.CD-finance.Definition: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
key-NY.GDP.PCAP.CD-finance.Source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

key-mvi-ldc-XCON-Index-mvi.Definition: Provides information on the exposure to trade shocks resulting from a concentrated export structure. Measures the product concentration of a country's exports
key-mvi-ldc-XCON-Index-mvi.Source: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD)

key-mvi-ldc-XIN-Index-mvi.Definition: The standard deivation of the difference between the value of annual export earnings and its 20-year trend
key-mvi-ldc-XIN-Index-mvi.Source: CDP Secretariat, based on data for exports and imports and goods and services and trade dependency (ratio of exports plus imports to GDP) from United Nations Statistics Division National Accounts Main Aggregates Database (AMA)

key-mvi-ldc-AIN-Index-mvi.Definition: Defined as the standard deviation of the difference between agricultural production and its 20-year trend
key-mvi-ldc-AIN-Index-mvi.Source: CDP Secretariat, based on agricultural production data from FAO, FAOSTAT

key-mvi-ST.INT.RCPT.XP.ZS-mvi.Indicator: Tourism revenues as share of exports
key-mvi-ST.INT.RCPT.XP.ZS-mvi.Definition: International tourism receipts are expenditures by international inbound visitors, including payments to national carriers for international transport. These receipts include any other prepayment made for goods or services received in the destination country. They also may include receipts from same-day visitors, except when these are important enough to justify separate classification. For some countries they do not include receipts for passenger transport items. Their share in exports is calculated as a ratio to exports of goods and services, which comprise all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world involving a change of ownership from residents to nonresidents of general merchandise, goods sent for processing and repairs, nonmonetary gold, and services.
key-mvi-ST.INT.RCPT.XP.ZS-mvi.Source: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files, and IMF and World Bank exports estimates.

key-mvi-BX.TRF.PWKR.DT.GD.ZS-mvi.Definition: Personal remittances comprise personal transfers and compensation of employees. Personal transfers consist of all current transfers in cash or in kind made or received by resident households to or from nonresident households. Personal transfers thus include all current transfers between resident and nonresident individuals. Compensation of employees refers to the income of border, seasonal, and other short-term workers who are employed in an economy where they are not resident and of residents employed by nonresident entities. Data are the sum of two items defined in the sixth edition of the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual: personal transfers and compensation of employees.
key-mvi-BX.TRF.PWKR.DT.GD.ZS-mvi.Source: World Bank staff estimates based on IMF balance of payments data, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

key-mvi-BX.KLT.DINV.WD.GD.ZS-mvi.Indicator: FDI inflows as percentage of GDP
key-mvi-BX.KLT.DINV.WD.GD.ZS-mvi.Definition: Foreign direct investment are the net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows net inflows (new investment inflows less disinvestment) in the reporting economy from foreign investors, and is divided by GDP.
key-mvi-BX.KLT.DINV.WD.GD.ZS-mvi.Source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and Balance of Payments databases, World Bank, International Debt Statistics, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

key-mvi-ldc-AFF-Index-mvi.Indicator: Agriculture and fishing as share of GDP
key-mvi-ldc-AFF-Index-mvi.Definition: Defined as the percentage share of the agriculture, hunting, forestry, and fishing sectors in the gross value added of a country
key-mvi-ldc-AFF-Index-mvi.Source: United Nations Statistics Division National Accounts Main Aggregates Database (AMA).

key-mvi-ldc-VIC-Index-mvi.Definition: Measures the share of population who are victims of disasters, defined as people killed or affected (i.e. requiring immediate food, water, shelter, sanitation, or medical assistance)
key-mvi-ldc-VIC-Index-mvi.Source: CDP Secretariat, based on disaster data from the OFDA/CRED International Disaster Database and population data from United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects (WPP) 2019 Revision

key-mvi-ldc-REM-Index-mvi.Definition: Defined as a trade-weighted average of a country's distance from world markets
key-mvi-ldc-REM-Index-mvi.Source: CDP Secretariat, based on data for exports and imports and goods and services from United Nations Statistics Division National Accounts Main Aggregates Database (AMA) and distance data from Centre d'Etudes Prospectives et d'Informations Internationales

key-mvi-ldc-LECZ-Index-mvi.Indicator: Share of population in low elevated coastal zones
key-mvi-ldc-LECZ-Index-mvi.Definition: Population below 5m is the percentage of the total population living in areas where the elevation is 5 meters or less.
key-mvi-ldc-LECZ-Index-mvi.Source: Center for International Earth Science Information Network - CIESIN - Columbia University and CUNY Institute for Demographic Research (CIDR), City University of New York. 2020. Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates, Version 3 Preliminary Release. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). Accessed 30 July 2020. For a number of small island and coastal States, data are from CIESIN, Population, Landscape, And Climate Estimates, Version 3 (PLACE III)

key-mvi-ldc-HAI-mvi.Definition: The Human Assets Index (HAI) is a composite index of education and health used as an identification criterion for LDCs by the UNCDP.
key-mvi-ldc-HAI-mvi.Source: United Nations Committee for Development Policy Secretariat

key-mvi-ldc-EVI-mvi.Definition: The Environmental Vulnerability Index (EVI) is a measurement devised by the South Pacific Applied Geoscience Commission (SOPAC), the United Nations Environment Program and others to characterize the relative severity of various types of environmental issues. The results of the EVI are used to focus on planned solutions to negative pressures on the environment, whilst promoting sustainability.
key-mvi-ldc-EVI-mvi.Source: United Nations Committee for Development Policy Secretariat

key-mvi-ldc-GNI-mvi.Definition: GNI per capita provides information on the income status and the overall level of resources available to a country. GNI is calculated from  national accounts data converted into USD using the World Bank Atlas method (to reduce impact of short-term exchange rate fluctuations). GNI per capita is derived by dividing GNI in USD by the annual population of a country.
key-mvi-ldc-GNI-mvi.Source: Calculated by the CDP Secretariat, based on United Nations Statistics Division National Accounts Main Aggregates Database (AMA) and the World Bank Atlas
